PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Laurinburg, North Carolina. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1987 Code, as supplemented through June 19, 2001, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1987 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Jan Shekitka, Senior Code Attorney, and Leesa Hampton, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Dolores Hammond, City Clerk and J. Robert Gordon, City Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. O-2003-22 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Laurinburg, North Carolina; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF LAURINBURG: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 44, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before May 20, 2003, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for more than 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after May 20, 2003, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall be in full force on and after the 18 th day of November, 2003. ADOPTED this the 18 th day of November 2003. ;sigl;  \Ann B. Slaughter, Mayor ;sigr;  \Dolores A. Hammond, City Clerk

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the Charter of the city, being Chapter 586 of the Session Laws of 1989 as adopted by the General Assembly on July 5, 1989 and effective on the same date. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates the provision remains unchanged from the original Charter. The provisions of the Charter are set out as enacted; however, a uniform system of capitalization has been employed and material added by the editor for clarity has been enclosed in brackets. For stylistic purposes a uniform system of headings, catchlines and citations to state statutes has been used. 
State Law reference- Procedure, etc., for local amendment of municipal charters, G.S. 160A-101-160A-110. 

CHAPTER I. - INCORPORATION AND CORPORATE POWERS 

Sec. 1-1. - Incorporation and corporate powers. 
    The inhabitants of the City of Laurinburg are a body corporate and politic under the name of the "City of Laurinburg." Under that name they have all the powers, duties, rights, privileges and immunities conferred and imposed on cities by the general law of North Carolina. 
CHAPTER II. - CORPORATE BOUNDARIES 

Sec. 2-1. - City boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the City of Laurinburg are set out on a map entitled "Boundary Map of the City of Laurinburg, North Carolina." The map is maintained in the office of the city clerk, as required by G.S. 160A-22. 
Editor's note- The city boundaries have changed due to annexations made since the effective date of the Charter. 
CHAPTER III. - GOVERNING BODY 

Sec. 3-1. - Structure of governing body; number of members. 
    The governing body of the City of Laurinburg is the city council, which has five members and a mayor. 
Sec. 3-2. - Manner of election of council. 
    Two (2) of the five (5) city councilmembers shall be elected from District 1, two (2) from District 2, and one (1) from the city at large. To be eligible to be a candidate for and to hold one of the council seats representing a district, a person must reside in that district. Only voters who reside in a district shall be eligible to vote for the councilmembers representing that district. All voters in the city may vote for the at large member. 
(Sess. Laws 1995, ch. 65) 
Sec. 3-3. - Term of office of members of the city council. 
(a)  In the regular city election in 1995 three (3) councilmembers shall be elected, two (2) from District 1 and one (1) from District 2. All candidates for the two (2) seats from District 1 shall be listed together on the ballot and each voter shall be allowed to cast up to two (2) votes. The candidate for District 1 receiving the most votes shall be elected for a term to expire in 1999, and the candidate receiving the next highest number of votes shall be elected for a term to expire in 1997. The councilmember elected in 1995 from District 2 shall be elected for a term to expire in 1999. 
(b)  In 1997 and every two (2) years thereafter, three (3) councilmembers shall be elected: One (1) from District 1, one (1) from District 2, and one (1) at large. The councilmembers elected from Districts 1 and 2 shall be elected for four-year terms, and the member elected at large shall be elected for a four-year term beginning with the 2001 election. 
(Sess. Laws 1995, ch. 65; Ord. No. O-2001-05, 6-19-2001) 
Sec. 3-4. - Election of mayor; term of office; voting rights. 
    The qualified voters of the entire city shall elect the mayor. He is elected to a four-year term of office beginning with the 2003 election. The mayor shall not vote on any question before the council except in case of a tie vote deadlocking a decision of the council. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-05, 6-19-2001) 
Sec. 3-5. - Council election districts. 
    Reserved. 
(Sess. Laws, 1995, ch. 65) 
Editor's note- The two (2) districts for the election of members of the city council shall be as approved by the U.S. Department of Justice per Resolution R-2001-29, adopted on June 21, 2001. 
CHAPTER IV. - ELECTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal elections, G.S. 163-291 et seq. 

Sec. 4-1. - Conduct of city elections. 
    City officers shall be elected on a nonpartisan basis, and the results determined by plurality as provided by G.S 163-292. 
Sec. 4-2. - Absentee voting. 
    Absentee voting shall be allowed in the City of Laurinburg if city elections are conducted by a municipal board of elections, and any references in G.S. 163-301 and G.S. 163-226-163-257 that refer to the county board of elections shall, for the City of Laurinburg, refer to the municipal board of elections if city elections are conducted by a municipal board of elections. The state board of elections may adopt rules to regulate this section. 
    This act becomes effective with respect to all elections held on or after January 1, 1999. 
CHAPTER V. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 5-1. - City to operate under council-manager plan. 
    The City of Laurinburg shall operate under the council-manager plan as provided in G.S. 160A-147 et seq. The positions of city clerk, city tax collector and treasurer, formerly appointed by the governing body, shall be appointed by the city manager.

PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina," and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Laurinburg City Code." 
(Code 1987, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Acts by agents. When any provision of this Code requires an act to be done which may by law as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent. 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" shall mean and refer to the Charter of the City of Laurinburg as printed in part I of this volume. 
    City. The term "the city" shall mean the City of Laurinburg in the County of Scotland and the State of North Carolina and shall extend to and include its various officers, agents and employees, when acting within the scope of their employment, except as otherwise provided. 
    City council. The term "city council" shall mean the city council of the City of Laurinburg. 
    Code. The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by this Code, the day of the act, event, default or publication after which the designated period of time begins to run is not to be included. The last day of the period so computed is to be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, in which event, the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and holidays shall be excluded in the computation. A half holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a holiday. 
    County. The term "the county" shall mean the County of Scotland in the State of North Carolina, except as otherwise provided. 
    Gender. Terms importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
    General Statutes (G.S.) The term "General Statutes" or the abbreviation "G.S." shall mean the latest edition of the General Statutes of North Carolina, as amended. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All terms giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    May. The term "may" is always directory and not mandatory. 
    Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical terms. All terms and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical terms and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    Number. Terms used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular number. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, departments, boards, commissions and other agencies. References to the city manager, city clerk, chief of police or other officers, any department, board, commission or any other agency, unless otherwise indicated, shall be construed as if followed by the term "of the City of Laurinburg." 
    Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this Code, they shall mean Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," where the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to any property, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such property. 
    Person . The term "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include moneys, goods, chattels, chooses in action and evidences of debt, including all things capable of ownership, not descendible to heirs at law. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property, as defined in this section. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    References to chapters or sections. All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is always mandatory and not directory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The term "the state" shall mean the State of North Carolina. 
    Street. The term "street" shall include avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city, and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines. 
    Tenant and occupant . The terms "tenant" and "occupant," when applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past, and present tense shall include the future as well as the past and present, when applicable. 
    Week. The term "week" shall be construed to mean seven days, but publication in the newspaper or any notice or other matter indicated to be for a stated number of weeks shall be construed to mean one insertion in each week, unless specifically stated to be for each day of the week or for more than one day in each week. 
    Writing, written. The terms "writing" and "written" shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1987, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Rules of construction G.S. 12-3; citation of General Statutes, G.S. 164-1. 
Sec. 1-3. - Section catchlines and other headings. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(Code 1987, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same or substantially the same as those of the 1987 Code, and all ordinances adopted subsequent to the 1987 Code and included in this Code shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1987, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal or expiration of ordinance. 
    The repeal of an ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued, any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. When any ordinance which repealed another shall itself be repealed the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(Code 1987, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions applicable to state laws, G.S. 12-2. 
Sec. 1-6. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any of the following, when not inconsistent herewith: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any annual tax levy, appropriation or budget; 
(3)  Any right or franchise conferred by ordinance on any person or corporation; 
(4)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(5)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
(6)  Any ordinance relating to the salaries of the city officers or employees; 
(7)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city; 
(8)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city; 
(9)  Any ordinance pertaining to traffic or parking regulations applying to specific streets; 
(10)  Any ordinance setting fees, charges or rates for city services; 
and all such ordinances shall remain in full force and effect as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- Authority for city to omit designated classes of ordinances from Code, G.S. 160A-77. 
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since they would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1987, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-8. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect any section or subsection of this Code, shall be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection, or any portion thereof, the repealed portions shall be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances, so numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted by the city council as a new Code. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: the "Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered section _____, which section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number in the following language: "Section (chapter or article) _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, is hereby repealed." 
(Code 1987, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during that period. The pages of a supplement shall be numbered so that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be prepared so that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinances included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the term "this ordinance," or terms of the same meaning, to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1987, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty; enforcement provisions; remedies available to city to rectify violations; continuing violations. 
(a)  Wherever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city or in any rule, regulation, order or notice of any officer or agency of the city, under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whether in such Code, ordinance, rule, regulation, order or notice the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, rule, regulation, order or notice shall be a misdemeanor as provided in G.S. 14-4 and shall subject each such violator to the punishment provided in such section. 
(b)  Pursuant to the authority of G.S. 160A-175, the city may secure injunctions and abatement orders to further ensure compliance with this Code and other city ordinances as provided by this section. 
(c)  Any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city, for the enforcement of which an appropriate remedy in equity exists, may be enforced by an appropriate equitable remedy issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction. In such case, the general court of justice has jurisdiction under G.S. 160A-175 to issue such orders as may be appropriate, and it is declared by that section that it shall not be a defense to the application of the city for such equitable relief that there is an adequate remedy at law. 
(d)  When a violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance occurs which makes unlawful a condition existing upon or use made of real property, the city may, pursuant to the authority of G.S. 160A-175, apply to the appropriate division of the general court of justice for a mandatory or prohibitory injunction and order of abatement commanding the defendant to correct the unlawful condition upon, or cease the unlawful use of, the property. The action shall be governed in all respects by the laws and rules governing civil proceedings, including the Rules of Civil Procedure in general, and Rule 65 in particular, as required by G.S. 160A-175. 
(e)  Subject to the express terms thereof, any portion of this Code or any other ordinance of the city may be enforced by any one, all or a combination of the remedies prescribed by this section and G.S. 160A-175. 
(f)  Unless otherwise provided, each day's continuing violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1987, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Violation of local ordinance misdemeanor, G.S. 14-4; authority of town to enforce ordinances, G.S. 160A-175. 
Sec. 1-11. - Errors, oversights of city personnel do not legalize violations. 
    No error, oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of any city official or employee shall be deemed to legalize the violation of any provision of this Code or any provision of any regulatory code adopted by this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 1-11) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(1); any ordinance setting fees, charges or rates for city services saved from repeal, § 1-6(10); administration of buildings and building regulations, § 6-31 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 12; elections, ch. 14; administration and enforcement of abandoned, nuisance and junked motor vehicles, § 16-114; administration and enforcement of fire prevention code; bureau of fire prevention, § 18-43; human relations, ch. 20; law enforcement, ch. 22; public records, ch. 26; taxation, ch. 34; utilities, ch. 40. 
State Law reference- Cities and towns, G.S. ch. 160A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Disposing of personal property. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.S. 160A-266(c), the city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to dispose of any surplus personal property owned by the city whenever the city manager or designee determines, in his discretion, that: 
(1)  The item or group of items has a fair market value of less than $30,000.00; 
(2)  The property is no longer necessary for the conduct of public business; and 
(3)  Sound property management principles and financial considerations indicate that the interests of the city would best be served by disposing of the property. 
(b)  The city manager or designee may dispose of any such surplus personal property by any means which he judges reasonably calculated to yield the highest attainable sale price in money or other consideration, including, but not limited to, the methods of sale provided in G.S. Ch. 160A, Art. 12. Such sale may be public or private, and with or without notice and a minimum waiting period. 
(c)  The surplus property shall be sold to the party who tenders the highest offer, or exchanged for any property or services useful to the city if greater value may be obtained in that manner, and the city manager or designee is hereby authorized to execute and deliver any applicable title documents. If no offers are received within a reasonable time, the city manager or designee may retain the property, obtain any reasonably available salvage value, or cause the property to be disposed of as waste material. No surplus property may be donated to any individual or organization, except by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  The city manager or designee shall keep a record of all property sold under authority of this section, and such record shall generally describe the property sold or exchanged, to whom it was sold, or with whom exchanges were made, and the amount of money or other considerations received for each sale or exchange. 
(e)  The city manager or designee shall submit a report to the city council on a semiannual basis, listing all items sold under the provisions of this section, the person to whom the items were sold, and the amount of each sale. Items sold between January 1 and June 30 shall be reported at the regular council meeting in July. Items sold between July 1 and December 31 shall be reported at the regular council meeting in January. 
(Code 1987, § 2-3; Ord. No. O-2013-07, § 1, 4-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Power to dispose of property, G.S. 160A-11. 
Sec. 2-2. - Purchase orders. 
    Before any order is given for items to be purchased for the city by any city officer or employee, a purchase order must first be obtained from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 2-2) 
State Law reference- Regulation of contracts, G.S. § 160A-16 et seq. 
Sec. 2-3. - Insurance; governmental immunity. 
(a)  The city council may authorize the city manager, on behalf of the city, to contract with one or more insurance companies authorized to do business in the state to protect the city and city officers, employees and agents while acting in the line of duty, against losses arising from public liability, fire, theft, hail, windstorm and other causes, the amount and terms of policies to be as prescribed by the city council and agreed upon by the insurers. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as a waiver by the city of its governmental immunity beyond the extent of the amount and type of any insurance coverage obtained by the city pursuant to subsection (a) of this section and which is in effect at the time of any claim. 
(Code 1987, § 2-5) 
State Law reference- Waiver of immunity through insurance purchase, G.S. 160A-485. 
Sec. 2-4. - Provision for transfer in budget prerequisite to disbursement. 
    No money shall be disbursed from the city treasury unless the item for which the disbursement is to be made has been provided for in the annual budget or can be provided for by a proper transfer within the budget as the city council may authorize except in the case of an extreme emergency. 
(Code 1987, § 2-4) 
Secs. 2-5-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Mayor and council, G.S. 160A-66 et seq. 

Sec. 2-31. - Regular meetings. 
    Except for the organizational meeting of the city council as provided for in section 2-32, the city council shall meet in regular session on the first Tuesday after the 15th day of each month, provided that when any such first Tuesday falls upon a holiday, the council may fix another day in such month for its regular meeting. Meetings shall begin at an hour specified by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 2-21(a)) 
State Law reference- Requiring city council to fix suitable times for its regular meetings, G.S. 160A-71. 
Sec. 2-32. - Organizational meetings. 
    After each municipal election at which the mayor and city council members are elected, the city council will conduct its organizational meeting on the date of the first regular meeting in December after the results of the municipal election have been certified by the election board. Such meetings will be held at 12:00 noon in the council room of the municipal building. 
(Code 1987, § 2-21(b); Ord. No. O-2012-27, § 1, 7-17-2012) 
Sec. 2-33. - Notice of special meetings. 
    Each councilmember shall be notified in writing of a special meeting in accordance with G.S. 160A-71. 
(Code 1987, § 2-22) 
State Law reference- Special meetings of city council, G.S. 160A-71. 
Sec. 2-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2014-18, § 1, adopted Nov. 18, 2014, repealed § 2-34, which pertained to rules of procedure and derived from Code 1987, § 2-24. 
Sec. 2-35. - Questions of parliamentary law; application of Robert's Rules of Order. 
    The presiding officer at a city council meeting shall decide all questions of parliamentary law and, except where otherwise provided, his deliberation shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Code 1987, § 2-25) 
State Law reference- Council to adopt its own rules of procedure, G.S. 160A-71(c). 
Sec. 2-36. - City clerk or deputy clerk to attend meetings and keep record. 
    The city clerk or deputy clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council and shall keep a true and accurate record of all business transacted by the council. All such records shall be recorded in the minute book and shall be known as the official minutes of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-37. - Resignation of mayor or councilmember. 
    The resignation of the mayor or any councilmember shall be tendered in writing at a regular meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-38. - Official copies of ordinances. 
    A true copy of an ordinance which has been duly enacted by the city council, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk shall be known as the official copy of an ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-39. - Ordinances to be enacted as amendments or additions to Code. 
    All ordinances of a general and permanent nature, and amendments to such ordinances, enacted or presented to the city council for enactment, shall be drafted, as far as possible, as specific amendments of, or additions to, this Code. Amendments to this Code shall be made by reference to the chapter and section of the Code which is to be amended, and additions shall bear an appropriate designation of chapter and section. 
(Code 1987, § 2-29) 
State Law reference- Supplementing Code, G.S. 160A-77(a). 
Sec. 2-40. - Record of ordinances and resolutions. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of all ordinances and resolutions separate and apart from the regular minutes. 
(Code 1987, § 2-30) 
State Law reference- Ordinance book, G.S. 160A-78. 
Sec. 2-41. - Posting of ordinances following enactment. 
    Within ten days after final passage of each ordinance, the city clerk shall post a notice on the City Hall bulletin board, briefly setting forth the substance of such ordinance and a statement that the ordinance is on file in the office of the city clerk and is available to the public for inspection and use at such office during all regular business hours. 
(Code 1987, § 2-31) 
Secs. 2-42-2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance relating to the salaries of the city officers or employees saved from repeal, § 1-6(6); building inspector, § 6-31; chief of fire department, § 18-82; vehicle for hire inspector, § 44-32. 
State Law reference- Personnel, G.S. 160A-162 et seq. 

Sec. 2-71. - Mayor. 
    The mayor shall be the official head of the city, having the powers and performing the duties prescribed for his office by state law, the City Charter, this Code and other ordinances and resolutions of the city council, and he shall countersign all vouchers for the disbursement of any money belonging to the city. 
(Code 1987, § 2-46) 
State Law reference- General powers of mayor and council, G.S. 160A-67; mayor to preside over council, G.S. 160A-69; mayor pro tempore, G.S. 160A-70; calling special meetings, G.S. 160A-71. 
Sec. 2-72. - City manager; budget officer. 
(a)  The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the city, having the powers and performing the duties prescribed for his office by state law, the City Charter, this Code and other ordinances, resolutions and orders of the city council. The city manager shall receive such compensation as may be specified in his contract or agreement of employment, which shall be included in each annual budget. 
(b)  The city manager shall be the ex officio budget officer. The budget officer shall have the powers and perform the duties provided by state law for municipal budget officers. 
(Code 1987, § 2-47) 
State Law reference- Administration of council-manager cities, G.S. 160A-147 et seq.; local government budget and fiscal control act, G.S. 159-7 et seq. 
Sec. 2-73. - City clerk. 
(a)  The city clerk shall be the custodian of all city records, books, documents and other papers for which no other person is designated as custodian. He shall be responsible for the preparation and filing of the journal or minutes of the city council and its committees and the filing of ordinances and resolutions of the city council. He shall be the corresponding secretary of the city council and its committees. He shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as may be specified for his office by state law, the City Charter, this Code and other ordinances, resolutions and orders of the city council. 
(b)  The office of the city clerk is hereby designated as the principal point of contact between the city government and the public, and it shall be the duty of the city clerk and his office personnel to keep themselves informed as to the general powers, duties and activities of several departments and offices of the city government so as to be able to answer pertinent questions of callers and render appropriate courtesies to such callers. Pursuant to policies established by the city council and the city manager, the office of the city clerk shall render clerical assistance not otherwise available to other city departments and officers, when to do so would not impose an undue burden on the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 2-48) 
State Law reference- City clerk, G.S. 160A-171. 
Sec. 2-74. - Deputy clerk. 
    When there is an incumbent deputy city clerk, he shall have such powers and perform such duties as may be delegated to him by the city council or the city clerk. When the city clerk is absent or disabled, or when the office of city clerk is vacant, the deputy city clerk shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 2-49) 
State Law reference- Deputy clerk, G.S. 160A-172. 
Sec. 2-75. - City treasurer; finance officer. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to receive from the city tax collector and all other persons all money, negotiable instruments and securities belonging to the city and to keep full and accurate accounts thereof, including, but not be limited to, the: 
(1)  Name of the person from whom such money, negotiable instruments and securities were received and, where applicable, the name of the person on whose behalf payment was made; 
(2)  Date of payment; 
(3)  Amount of payment and, where applicable, an itemization as to the amount paid on principal, interest, penalty, etc.; 
(4)  Purpose of the payment; and 
(5)  Account to which the payment was credited; 
and the city treasurer shall give his receipt for each payment received by him. All city funds so received shall be deposited by the city treasurer in a depository designated by special ordinance of the city council pursuant to law, except for such amount as may be authorized by the city council to be kept in a secure place in the city treasurer's office as a petty cash fund. 
(b)  The city treasurer shall disburse city funds only upon appropriation by the city council, upon checks signed by him and countersigned by the mayor, except that no check is required for a disbursement from the petty cash fund; and the city council may, by resolution, designate alternate officers for such purposes to act during the absence or disability of either or both such officers or during a vacancy in either or both such offices. The city treasurer shall keep full and accurate accounts of all disbursements, including, but not limited to, the: 
(1)  Name of the person to whom paid and, where applicable, the name of the person on whose behalf such disbursement was made; 
(2)  Date of disbursement; 
(3)  Amount of disbursement and, where applicable, an itemization as to the amount of principal, interest, etc.; 
(4)  Purpose of the disbursement; and 
(5)  Fund from which the disbursement was made; 
and, the city treasurer shall take a receipt for each disbursement made by him. 
(c)  The city treasurer, under the direct supervision and subject to the orders of the city manager, shall be ex officio finance officer of the city and, as such, he shall have the powers and perform the duties prescribed for municipal finance officers in G.S. 159-24 et seq. 
(d)  The city treasurer shall perform such other duties of a fiscal nature as may from time to time be imposed upon him by the city council or the city manager, not inconsistent with state law, the City Charter, this Code, or other ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 2-50) 
State Law reference- Selection of municipal depositories, G.S. 159-31. 
Sec. 2-76. - City tax collector. 
    The city tax collector shall collect all real and personal property taxes and all assessments due the city and, where no other officer is designated for such purpose, he shall collect all license taxes and permit fees and issue all licenses and permits. The city tax collector shall pay over to the city treasurer all money so collected not less frequently than once each week, and more often if required by the city treasurer or city manager. The city tax collector shall give his receipt to each person from whom he makes collection, and shall keep complete and accurate records of all collections in accordance with directives of the city treasurer or the city manager. The city tax collector shall perform such other related duties as may be imposed upon him from time to time by the city council or the city manager, not inconsistent with state law, the City Charter, this Code, or other ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 2-51) 
State Law reference- Tax collectors, collection and foreclosure of taxes, G.S. 105-349 et seq. 
Sec. 2-77. - Blanket bonding of officers, agents and employees; exceptions. 
(a)  The city council shall adopt a system of blanket faithful performance or honesty bonding of all officers, agents and employees of the city, except the city manager, city clerk and city tax collector. Such blanket bond coverage shall be in the amount of not less than $30,000.00 for each officer, agent and employee covered by such bond. 
(b)  Employees who are required by the General Statutes to have separate or additional bonding shall, before assuming their respective duties, enter into bond with good sureties, payable to the city, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of their respective duties and a true accounting for all funds of the city which may, respectively, come into their hands, custody or control. 
(c)  The premium for all bonds set forth in this section shall be paid by the city, and all bonds shall be approved by the city attorney as to form and legality. 
(Code 1987, § 2-52) 
State Law reference- Fidelity bonds for each officer, employee or agent who handles or has in his custody more than $100.00 of the city's at any time or who handles or has access to the city's inventories, G.S. 159-29. 
Sec. 2-78. - Public official's and employee's code of conduct. 
(a)  It is the obligation of every public official and employee to support the Constitution of the United States and the constitution of the state. 
(b)  The laws of the nation, state and city shall be impartially administered. No public official or employee shall grant any special consideration, treatment or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is available to every other citizen, except by due process of law. 
(c)  Every citizen shall receive a fair and impartial hearing on any matter coming before the city council, its appointed agencies or any employee of the city. No public official or employee shall make any promise or pledge to any person concerning any matter to be heard before such public official or employee, except upon fair, impartial and final hearing thereof. 
(d)  The conduct of public business shall be free of any hidden personal or financial interest of any public official or employee. No public official or employee shall advocate in any public meeting or private discussion incident thereto any matter in which he has a personal or financial interest, except upon full and timely disclosure of such interest. 
(e)  It is the obligation of every public official to faithfully discharge the duties of his office. In the conduct of public business, no public official shall be excused from voting, except on matters involving consideration of his own official conduct or where his financial interests are involved. Every public official shall make a full and timely disclosure of any personal or financial interest which he has in any matter of public business to be transacted before him. 
(f)  The conduct of public business shall be free of any influence arising from gifts, favors or special privileges. It is the obligation of every public official and employee to refuse personal gifts, favors or special privileges in every instance where such public official or employee reasonably believes such gift, favor or special privilege would not have been extended but for the position of such public official or employee, or where there exists a reasonable belief that the giver's interest is likely to be affected by the actions of such public official or employee, or where the gift is, or may, reasonably be considered to be designed to influence the actions of such public official or employee. No public official or employee shall seek personal or financial advantage by means of his public office, appointment or employment. 
(g)  The use of public trust for private gain is inimical to good government. No public official or employee shall violate the provision of G.S. 14-234. No public official or employee shall use confidential or advance information obtained by virtue of public office, appointment or employment for personal or financial advantage. 
(h)  No public official, employee, officer or agent of the city shall participate in selection, or in the award or administration, of a contract supported by federal funds if a conflict of interest, real or apparent, would be involved. No employee, officer or agent, any member of his immediate family, his partner or an organization which employs, or is about to employ, any of such persons, shall have a financial or other interest in the firm selected for such award. 
(i)  The city's officers, employees or agents shall neither solicit, nor accept gratuities, favors or anything of monetary value from contractors, potential contractors or parties to subagreements. 
(j)  It is the obligation of every public official and employee to carry out the lawful orders and policies of the city council. No public official or employee shall knowingly take any action inconsistent with the lawful orders or policies established by the city council. No public official or employee shall knowingly take any action which would be detrimental to the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 2-53) 
Secs. 2-79-2-110. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-111-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AIRPORT COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal airports, G.S. 63-1 et seq.; public airports and related facilities, G.S. 63-49 et seq. 

Sec. 2-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means the Laurinburg-Maxton Airport. 
    Airport commission means the Laurinburg-Maxton Airport Commission as created in section 2-132. 
(Code 1987, § 2-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-132. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an airport commission, to be known as the "Laurinburg-Maxton Airport Commission." 
(Code 1987, § 2-87) 
Sec. 2-133. - Composition. 
    The airport commission shall be composed of six members. 
(Code 1987, § 2-88) 
Sec. 2-134. - Election of members. 
    The governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg shall each elect three members to the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-89) 
Sec. 2-135. - Qualification of members. 
    Members of the airport commission shall be residents, respectively, of the Town of Maxton and the city. 
(Code 1987, § 2-90) 
Sec. 2-136. - Term of members. 
    The initial members of the airport commission shall serve staggered terms. Thereafter, each member appointed by the city council of the City of Laurinburg shall serve a three-year term. 
(Code 1987, § 2-91) 
Sec. 2-137. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Any vacancy that shall occur in the membership of the airport commission, caused by death, resignation or inability to serve, shall be filled by the governing body of the Town of Maxton or the city council of the City of Laurinburg, depending on where the vacating airport commission member was a resident at the time the vacancy occurred. 
(Code 1987, § 2-92) 
Sec. 2-138. - Compensation of members. 
    Each member of the airport commission, including the secretary-treasurer and the chairperson, shall receive such compensation as the governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg shall designate, commensurate with the duties and requirements of their offices. 
(Code 1987, § 2-93) 
Sec. 2-139. - Chairperson. 
    The chairperson of the airport commission shall alternate between members appointed by the city and the members appointed by the Town of Maxton. If the chairperson, as previously elected by the airport commission, is not eligible for reelection to the chairmanship, either by reason of having served two successive one-year terms, or by reason of not having been reappointed to the airport commission, the chairmanship shall automatically rotate, so that the chairperson shall be elected from the members appointed by the municipality from which the retiring chairperson was not appointed. Such chairperson shall have no voting privilege, except in case of a tie. 
(Code 1987, § 2-95) 
Sec. 2-140. - Attorney and auditor. 
    At the regularly scheduled meeting of the airport commission in June of each year, the airport commission shall elect an attorney to advise and represent the airport commission, and an auditor to advise and assist the airport commission for the next ensuing fiscal year, extending from July 1 of the then current year to the next following June 30. 
(Code 1987, § 2-96) 
Sec. 2-141. - Action by majority vote; quorum. 
    The actions of the airport commission shall be determined by a majority vote of the members of the airport commission, and a majority of such members shall constitute a quorum for any meeting of the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-97) 
Sec. 2-142. - Duties generally. 
    The airport commission shall establish, improve, maintain, equip, operate and regulate all airports, navigation facilities and all other real and personal property owned or acquired by the city and the Town of Maxton for the use and benefit of the airport. 
(Code 1987, § 2-98) 
Sec. 2-143. - Exercise of powers generally. 
    On behalf of the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg, the airport commission may exercise all powers of each municipality granted by G.S. ch. 63, except as provided in such chapter or as otherwise limited by the agreement between the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg entered into for the purpose of operating the airport property. 
(Code 1987, § 2-99) 
Sec. 2-144. - Responsibility; special duties and special reports. 
    The airport commission shall, at all times, be responsible to the governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg, and shall perform any special duties or make any special reports requested of the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-100) 
Sec. 2-145. - Sale and lease of real property. 
    No real property, nor airport or other navigation facility, owned jointly by the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg shall be disposed of by the airport commission by sale or otherwise, except by authority of the governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg. The airport commission may lease personal property, space, area, land or improvements and grant concessions at the airport for aeronautical purposes, or purposes incidental thereto, or for other purposes wherein the revenue is to be used for airport purposes, except that no such agreements shall be contrary to the existing joint agreement between the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg for the operation of such facilities, or any conditions or restrictions placed upon such property as a condition upon which it was obtained from the United States or the state relating thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-146. - Control of revenues and expenditures. 
    The airport commission shall have full control of all revenues received by reason of the airport or other aeronautical facilities, and shall have power to expend all sums for such aeronautical purposes as the airport commission deems proper, and to pay over any surplus to the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg in proportion to their respective interests; except, however, that such right may be limited by any restrictions or agreements whereby any of the property owned or controlled by the airport commission was obtained. 
(Code 1987, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-147. - Fund established. 
    For the purpose of providing funds for the necessary expenditures in carrying out the provisions of this division, the airport commission shall establish an airport commission fund into which the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg shall deposit its proportionate share as provided by the joint agreement adopted by the two municipalities for the operation of the airport facilities and into which shall be paid all revenues obtained from the ownership, control and operation of the airport and other air navigation facilities jointly owned by the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg and controlled by the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-148. - Disbursements of funds. 
(a)  All disbursements from the airport commission fund established in section 2-147 shall be made by order of the airport commission; subject, however, to such limitations as shall be contained in the agreement adopted by the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg for the operation of the airport facilities. 
(b)  All funds under the control of the airport commission shall be disbursed only upon the signature of the chairperson and one airport commission member or the chairperson or vice-chairperson and the duly appointed fiscal agent of the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-105) 
Sec. 2-149. - Determination and approval of total annual expenditures. 
    The total amount of expenditures to be made by the airport commission for any purpose in any calendar year shall be determined and approved by both the governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg. 
(Code 1987, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-150. - Annual report and budget. 
    At least annually, the airport commission shall make a report to the governing body of the Town of Maxton and the city council of the City of Laurinburg, giving information regarding the condition of the airport facilities and other property owned by the two municipalities. Included in this report shall be a budget adopted by the airport commission, setting forth the anticipated revenue and expenditures of the airport commission in the administration of its duties for the forthcoming year. Such report shall be made not later than the date fixed by the laws of the state for the adoption of annual budgets by municipalities, as provided in the General Statutes. 
(Code 1987, § 2-107) 
Sec. 2-151. - Annual inventory. 
    The airport commission shall annually take and keep an inventory of all property jointly owned by the Town of Maxton and the City of Laurinburg, which has been under the control and supervision of the airport commission. 
(Code 1987, § 2-108) 
Secs. 2-152-2-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2006-15, §§ 1-5, adopted Oct. 24, 2006, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as §§ 2-156-2-164. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 

Sec. 2-156. - Creation and appointment. 
    The city council hereby establishes, by authority of Chapter 160A-400 of the North Carolina General Statutes, a historic preservation commission. The commission shall consist of at least five members appointed by the city council. A majority of its members must reside within the City of Laurinburg. At its discretion, the council may appoint members who reside within the city's extraterritorial planning jurisdiction. 
    A majority of the members of the commission shall have demonstrated special interest, experience, or education in history, architecture, archaeology, or related fields. 
    Members of the commission shall serve terms of four years and shall be appointed or re-appointed according to the policies of the city council. Terms of the initial appointments shall be set in such a way as to have staggered terms on the commission. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 1.1, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-157. - Rules of procedure. 
    The commission shall adopt rules of procedure necessary to the conduct of its affairs and in keeping with the provisions of this division. The rules of procedure adopted by the commission shall at least provide for the following: 
(1)  The selection of officers; 
(2)  The time and place of regular meetings and the calling of special meetings; 
(3)  The procedures for the conduct of public hearings; 
(4)  The conduct of voting; and 
(5)  The forms to be used in applying for or denying certificates of appropriateness for changes to historic landmarks designated by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 1.2, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-158. - Powers and duties of the commission. 
    The powers and duties of the commission are as follows: 
(1)  Undertake inventories of properties of historical, pre-historical, architectural and/or cultural significance; 
(2)  Recommend to the city council structures, buildings, sites, areas, or objects to be designated by ordinance as "historic landmarks"; 
(3)  Recommend to the city council that designation of any historic landmark be revoked for cause; 
(4)  Review and act upon proposals for the alteration or demolition of any historic landmark; 
(5)  Enter, solely in the performance of its official duties and only at reasonable times, upon private lands for the examination or survey thereof; however, no member, employee, or agent of the commission may enter any private building or structure without express consent of the owner or occupant thereof. 
(6)  Restore, preserve, and operate historic properties; 
(7)  Acquire by lawful means the fee or lesser included interest, including options to purchase, to properties designated as historic landmarks, to hold, manage, preserve, restore, and improve the same, and to exchange or dispose of the property by public or private sale, lease or otherwise, subject covenants or other legally binding restrictions which will secure appropriate rights of public access and promote the preservation of the property; 
(8)  Conduct education programs with respect to historic districts and landmarks within the city; 
(9)  Cooperate with state, federal, and local government in furthering the purposes of this division; to request and offer, assistance, aid, guidance, or advice concerning matters under its purview or of mutual interest; 
(10)  Negotiate at any time with the owner of a building, structure, site, area or object for its acquisition or its preservation, when such action is deemed reasonably necessary or appropriate. 
(11)  Prepare and recommend the official adoption of a preservation element as part of the municipality's comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 1.3, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-159. - Adoption of an ordinance of designation. 
    Upon complying with the required landmark designation procedures set forth in this division, the city council may adopt and from time to time amend or repeal an ordinance designating one or more historic landmarks. No property shall be recommended by the commission for designation as a landmark unless it is deemed to be f special significance in terms of its historical, pre-historical, architectural or cultural importance, and to possess integrity of design, setting, workmanship, materials, feeling and/or association. 
    The ordinance shall include the following information: 
(1)  Description of each property designated in the ordinance; 
(2)  List of the names of the owner or owners; 
(3)  Description of the elements of the property that are integral to its historical, architectural or historical value; and 
(4)  Provision for an appropriate sign to be placed on the property indicating that the property is designated as a historic landmark. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 2.1, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-160. - Guidelines for historic landmarks. 
    The commission shall use the inventory or inventories of historic properties in the City of Laurinburg, the historic districts listed on the National Register of Historic Places, individual nominations for listing on the National Register, and other local resources as a guides for recommending designation of historic landmarks. Within the resources available to it, the commission may update the city's inventories. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 2.2, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-161. - Required procedures for designation. 
(a)  Designation report. The commission shall prepare or review an investigation and report describing the significance of the buildings, structures, features, sites, or surroundings proposed for designation or other action by the commission. For purposes of this division, a property should meet one of the following criteria in order to have special significance: 
(1)  It is associated with events that have contributed significantly to the history of Laurinburg or a wider region. 
(2)  It is associated with the life of a person who is significant in Laurinburg's past or the past of the region, state, or nation. 
(3)  It embodies the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, or method of construction. 
(4)  It represents the work of a master or possesses high artistic values. 
(5)  It has yielded or is likely to yield important historical or pre-historical information. 
The designation report shall be submitted to the North Carolina Department of Cultural Resources. The department, acting through the state historic preservation officer, shall be given an opportunity to review and comment upon the substance of the report and the effect of designation of the property as a landmark. If the department does not respond within 30 days of receipt of the report, the commission is relieved of any responsibility to consider such comments. 
The commission, at its discretion, may refer the report to other local groups for comment before it is finalized. 
(b)  Public hearing. After the report is finalized and the designation ordinance is prepared, the commission and the city council shall hold public hearing(s) prior to adoption of the ordinance. A joint public hearing may be held. 
The public hearing(s) may only be held after public notice is given in the same manner as for adoption or amendment of the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Adoption, Following the public hearing and receiving a recommendation from the commission, the city council may adopt the designation ordinance along with any amendments it deems appropriate, or reject the ordinance. 
Amendments to any designation ordinance shall follow the same steps as required for adopting the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 2.3, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-162. - Certificate of appropriateness. 
(a)  Requirement. From and after designation of a historic landmark, no exterior portion of any building or other structure (including masonry walls, fences, light fixtures, steps and pavement, or other appurtenant features), nor above-ground utility structure nor any type of outdoor advertising sign shall be erected, altered, restored, moved, or demolished on such landmark until after an application for a certificate of appropriateness as to exterior features has been submitted to and approved by the commission. No permit for such work shall be issued until the commission approves the certificate of appropriateness. The certificate of appropriateness for such work is required whether or not a building permit or other permit is required. 
As specified in G.S. 160A-400.9(f) the requirement for a certificate of appropriateness is applicable to construction, alteration, moving and demolition by the State of North Carolina, its political subdivisions, agencies and instrumentalities, provided however they shall not apply to interiors of buildings or structures owned by the State of North Carolina. The state and its agencies shall have a right of appeal to the North Carolina Historical Commission or any successor agency assuming its responsibilities under G.S. 121-12(a) from any decision of the commission. The decision of the commission shall be final and binding upon both the state and the commission. 
This requirement for a certificate of appropriateness shall be a part of any ordinance designating a historic landmark. 
(b)  Review guidelines. Prior to the designation of any local historic landmarks, the commission shall prepare and adopt guidelines, not inconsistent with Part 3 Article 19 of Chapter 160A of the North Carolina General Statutes, for altering, restoring, moving, or demolishing property designated as landmarks. These guidelines shall ensure, insofar as possible, that changes in designated landmarks are in harmony with the special character of the landmark. 
(c)  Certain changes not prohibited. Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent the ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature of a designated landmark that does not involve a change in design, materials, or outer appearance thereof; the ordinary maintenance or repair of streets, sidewalks, pavement markings, street signs, or traffic signs; the construction, reconstruction, alteration, restoration or demolition of any such feature that the building inspector shall certify is required by the public safety because of an unsafe or dangerous condition. Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent the maintenance, or in the event of an emergency, the immediate restoration of any existing aboveground utility structure without approval of the commission. 
(d)  Minor works. After adoption of detailed standards by the preservation commission of detailed standards, the building inspector may review and approve applications for a certificate of appropriateness or of minor works as defined specified in the standards. 
(e)  Appeals. An appeal may be taken to the board of adjustment from the commission's action in granting or denying any certificate, which appeals (1) may be taken by any aggrieved party, (2) shall be taken within times prescribed by the historic preservation commission by general rule, and (3) shall be in the nature of certiorari. Any appeal from the board of adjustment's decision in any such case shall be heard by the superior court of the county in which the municipality is located. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 3, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-163. - Enforcement and remedies. 
    The city building inspector shall enforce compliance with the terms of the certificate of appropriateness. Failure to comply with the certificate shall be a violation that is punishable in the same manner as a violation of the Unified Development Ordinance. 
    In case any landmark is about to be demolished, whether as a result of deliberate neglect or otherwise, materially altered, remodeled, removed or destroyed except in compliance with this division, the commission, the city council, or any other aggrieved party may institute any action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful action. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 4, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 2-164. - Demolition delay. 
(a)  An application for a certificate of appropriateness authorizing demolition, removal, or destruction of a landmark may not be denied except as provided in subsection 2-164(c). However, the effective date of such a certificate may be delayed up to 365 days from the date of approval. The period of delay may be reduced if the commission finds that the owner would suffer extreme hardship or be permanently deprived of all beneficial use or return from such property by virtue of the delay. 
If the commission has voted to recommend designation of a property as a landmark, and final designation has not been made by the city council, the demolition or destruction of any building, site, or structure located on the property of the proposed landmark or in the proposed district may be delayed by the commission for a period of up to 180 days or until the city council takes final action on the designation, whichever occurs first. 
(b)  The city council may enact an ordinance to prevent the demolition by neglect of any designated landmark. Such ordinance shall provide appropriate safeguards to protect property owners from undue hardship. 
(c)  An application for a certificate of appropriateness authorizing the demolition of a designated landmark determined by the state historic preservation officer as having statewide significance as defined in the criteria of the National Register of Historic Places may be denied except where the commission finds that the owner would suffer extreme hardship or be permanently deprived of all beneficial use or return from such property by virtue of the denial. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-15, § 5, 10-24-2006) 
Secs. 2-165-2-180. - Reserved.

Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16; pushcarts, bicycles and animals, § 38-5. 
State Law reference- Dogs generally, G.S. ch. 67; rabies control, G.S. 130A-184 et seq.; regulation of domestic animals, G.S. 160A-186; regulation of dangerous animals, G.S. 160A-187. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means every living creature, domestic or nondomestic, but not including humans. 
    Animal shelter means any premises provided and operated for the restraint, care and disposition of animals, whether such shelter is public or private in nature. 
    At large means an animal off the property of its owner or keeper and not under physical restraint; however, such term shall not be construed to include any cat. 
    Cat means both male and female cats of any age. 
    Commercial animal establishment means any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, riding school or stable, zoological park, circus, animal exhibition or kennel. 
    Dangerous dog means a dog that: 
(1)  Has killed or inflicted severe injury on a person without provocation; 
(2)  Is determined by the person designated by the city manager to be potentially dangerous because the dog has engaged in one or more of the behaviors listed in the definition in this section of the term "potentially dangerous dog"; and 
(3)  Is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting. 
    Dog means both male and female dogs of any age. 
    Domestic means any animal kept, cared for, sheltered, fed or harbored as a pet, for work purposes or as a source of food, raw materials or income. 
    Head of household means the person who maintains the household. 
    Impounded means having been taken or received into the custody of the animal control officer or any authorized representative thereof. 
    Keeper means a person having custody of an animal, or who keeps or harbors an animal, or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied or controlled by such person. 
    Nondomestic means any animal that is wild or dangerous by natural existence. 
    Nuisance means an animal, or group of animals, if it:
