(1)  Damages, soils or defiles private or public property; 
(2)  Interferes with, molests or attacks persons or other animals; 
(3)  Causes unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions, including fouling of the air by odors; 
(4)  By virtue of number or type, is offensive or dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare; 
(5)  Is diseased or dangerous to the public health; 
(6)  Habitually or repeatedly makes noises or other sounds that tend to annoy, disturb or frighten citizens. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping or harboring any dog or cat. For the purpose of this chapter, the head of the household shall be deemed to be the owner in respect to any dog or cat owned, kept or harbored by any person residing in such household and kept on the premises. 
    Owner's real property means any real property owned or leased by the owners of any dog or cat, but does not include any public right-of-way or a common area of a condominium, apartment complex or townhouse development. 
    Potentially dangerous dog means a dog that the person designated by the city manager determines to have: 
(1)  Inflicted a bite on a person that resulted in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations or required cosmetic surgery or hospitalization; 
(2)  Killed or inflicted severe injury upon a domestic animal when not on the owner's real property; or 
(3)  Approached a person in a vicious or terrorizing manner in an apparent attitude of attack when not on the owner's real property. 
    Restraint means any animal if it is within the real property limits of its owner, or secured by a leash or lead, or confined. 
    Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations or requires cosmetic surgery or hospitalization. 
    Stray means any domestic animal not under restraint and found off the property of its owner or keeper. 
    Vicious animal means an animal that constitutes a physical threat to humans or other domestic animals. 
(Code 1987, § 4-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Authority to appoint animal control officers. 
    Authority is hereby given to the city manager, in his discretion, to appoint one or more animal control officers. 
(Code 1987, § 4-2) 
Sec. 4-3. - Animal control officers' responsibilities; right of investigation and inspection. 
(a)  The employees of the animal control program shall: 
(1)  Enforce and carry out all laws of the state and all ordinances of the city pertaining to animals; 
(2)  Be empowered to issue notices of violations of this chapter in such form as the city council may prescribe. 
(b)  Whenever it is necessary to make an investigation or inspection to enforce any of the provisions of, or perform any duty imposed by, this chapter or other applicable law, or whenever the animal control officer or his designated agent has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any violation of the provisions of this chapter or other applicable law, the animal control officer or his designated agent is hereby empowered to enter such property at any reasonable time and to inspect the property and perform any duty imposed upon such animal control officer or his agent by this chapter or other applicable law. 
(Code 1987, §§ 4-3, 4-4) 
Sec. 4-4. - Interference with enforcement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder or molest the animal control officer or persons duly authorized by this chapter, or to seek to release any animal in the custody of such person, except as otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1987, § 4-5) 
Sec. 4-5. - Animals at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession, charge, custody or control of any animal to suffer, permit or allow the animal to stray or in any manner to run at large in or upon any public street, sidewalk or park or upon the property of another, if such animal is not under sufficient physical restraint to allow the animal to be controlled. 
(Code 1987, § 4-7) 
State Law reference- Authority of city by ordinance to regulate, restrict or prohibit the keeping or running at large of domestic animals, G.S. 160A-186. 
Sec. 4-6. - Creating and maintaining nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful for an owner or keeper to permit an animal to create a nuisance, or to maintain a nuisance created by an animal. 
(Code 1987, § 4-8) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 16-31 et seq. 
Sec. 4-7. - Collecting dogs and cats for resale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to collect any dog or cat for the purpose of resale within the corporate limits of the city by soliciting from house to house, setting traps or other means on any land within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-9) 
Sec. 4-8. - Keeping livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, harbor, pasture or stable cows, horses, mules and other livestock within the corporate limits of the city within 150 feet of any residence, school, church or commercial or public eating place, but such prohibition shall not apply to the keeping of swine or goats. 
(Code 1987, § 4-10) 
Sec. 4-9. - Keeping swine, goats, chickens or domesticated ducks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any pigs, hogs, goats, chickens, or domesticated ducks within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-11; Ord. No. O-2006-16, § 1, 10-24-2006) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. O-2006-16 states that this section shall be in full force on and after Nov. 1, 2006. 
Sec. 4-10. - Keeping fowl. 
    All yards, premises, sheds, coops, etc., occupied by chickens or other fowl shall be deemed a nuisance if not cleaned regularly and kept in a sanitary condition at all times. 
(Code 1987, § 4-12) 
Sec. 4-11. - Keeping nondomestic animals. 
    No person shall possess or harbor any nondomestic animal which is dangerous to persons or property or which has the potential of being dangerous to persons or property. This section shall not apply to bona fide circuses, petting zoos and other traveling commercial animal exhibitions of limited duration. 
(Code 1987, § 4-13) 
Sec. 4-12. - Bird sanctuary established. 
    All of the territory within the territorial limits of the city shall be a bird sanctuary. 
(Code 1987, § 4-14) 
State Law reference- Declaring wild animal or bird a pest, G.S. 113-300.2; authorizing government body of municipality to create and establish a bird sanctuary within territorial limit of municipality, G.S. 160A-188. 
Sec. 4-13. - Hunting, killing and trapping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, kill or trap any animal within the territorial limits of the city. This section shall not apply to the animal control officer or duly authorized agent when enforcing the provisions provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 4-15) 
Sec. 4-14. - Slaughterhouses and butchering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, any slaughterhouse or to do any butchering within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-16) 
Sec. 4-15. - Compliance with state dangerous dog laws required; article supplemental to dangerous dog laws; additional regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any animal owner or other person to fail to comply with the state laws relating to dangerous dogs. 
(b)  It is the purpose of this chapter to supplement the state laws by providing a procedure for the enforcement of state laws relating to dangerous dogs in addition to the criminal penalties provided by state law. 
(c)  The city manager shall designate a person to be responsible for determining when a dog is a dangerous dog and shall designate a separate board to hear any appeals. 
(d)  In addition to complying with the state laws, owners of animals determined to be dangerous shall observe the following: 
(1)  The owner shall meet all requirements for licensing and rabies inoculations; 
(2)  A dangerous dog shall wear an identifying collar as provided by the city at the owner's expense; 
(3)  A dangerous dog shall be sterilized or neutered. Such altering may be performed by any veterinarian licensed to practice in the State of North Carolina and shall be performed within 20 days after the date the dog meets the definition of a dangerous dog. All fees shall be paid in full by the owner to the satisfaction of the veterinarian prior to release. 
(4)  While on the owner's property, a dangerous dog must be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel suitable to prevent entry or reaching through by young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. The pen or kennel may not share common fencing with an area or perimeter fence. The kennel or pen must have secure sides at least six feet in height; a secure top attached to all sides; the sides must be either buried two feet into the ground, sunken into a concrete pad or securely attached to a wire bottom. The gate to the kennel must be locked. The enclosure must also provide protection from the elements for the animal and have a ground area of at least five feet by 20 feet. The owner or keeper shall display a sign on his premises warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. The sign shall be visible and capable of being read from the public highway. 
(5)  The owner or keeper must allow officers of the animal control department to make whatever inquiries are deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this subsection (d), including inspection of the owner's or keeper's premises where the dangerous dog is confined. If an inspection reveals that the owner or keeper has not complied with the requirements for confining a dangerous dog, animal control shall issue a $100.00 civil penalty and may impound the dog at the animal shelter. 
If the dog shall be impounded and shall not be redeemed within five working days and the owner shall not request an appeal within the time limit provided, the dog shall be deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of in accordance with this chapter. 
(6)  If a dangerous dog escapes its confinement or frees itself from its owner or keeper, an animal control officer or other law enforcement officer is authorized to destroy the dog on the spot, if, in his judgment, the dog cannot be safely captured without causing harm to the officer or the public. The officer shall not be held liable for the loss of the dog. 
(7)  If the owner or keeper of the dog that has been designated dangerous is unwilling or unable to comply with the regulations of this subsection (d) for keeping such dog, then he must have the animal humanely euthanized by the animal control department or a licensed veterinarian after a holding period of ten days. All costs shall be borne by the owner. 
(Code 1987, § 4-17; Ord. No. O-2008-04, § 1, 3-18-2008, eff. 4-1-2008) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, restrict or prohibit the possession of dangerous animals, G.S. 160A-187. 
Sec. 4-16. - Notification of injury to animal required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person injuring an animal to fail to immediately notify the owner or keeper of the animal, or an animal control officer, humane society or the police department of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-18) 
Sec. 4-17. - Cruelty to animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to molest, torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance, cruelly beat, needlessly mutilate or kill, wound, injure, poison, abandon or subject any animal to conditions detrimental to its health or general welfare, or to cause or procure such action. The terms "torture" and "torment" shall be held to include every act, omission or neglect whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death is caused or permitted. Such terms shall not be construed to prohibit lawful taking of animals under the jurisdiction and regulation of the wildlife resources commission; nor to prohibit the animal control officer or persons duly authorized from destroying dangerous, unwanted or injured animals in a humane manner. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to fail to provide his animal with proper shelter and protection from the weather, sufficient and wholesome food and water to keep his animal in good health and comfort, the opportunity for vigorous daily exercise, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, and humane care and treatment. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, barter or give away within the city baby chickens, baby ducklings, other fowl or rabbits under eight weeks of age as pets, toys, premiums or novelties. This subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the sale or display of baby chickens, ducklings, other fowl or rabbits in proper facilities by breeders or stores engaged in the business of selling such fowl or rabbits for purposes other than for pets or novelties. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to color, dye, stain or otherwise change the natural color of baby chickens, other fowl or rabbits. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tether any fowl. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to incite, procure or cause any animal fight within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-19) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, G.S. 14-360; power of city to define and prohibit abuse of animals, G.S. 160A-182; protection of animals, G.S. ch. 19A. 
Sec. 4-18. - Luring, enticing, seizing, molesting or teasing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to entice or lure any animal out of an enclosure or off the property of its owner or keeper, or to seize, molest or tease any animal while the animal is held or controlled by its owner or keeper or while the animal is on the property of its owner or keeper. 
(Code 1987, § 4-20) 
Sec. 4-19. - Restraint of dogs. 
(a)  When a dog is on the property of its owner or keeper and is not within a secure enclosure, it shall be under the direct control of, and obedient to, the owner or keeper. At all other times when a dog is on the property of its owner or keeper, it shall be kept within a secure enclosure, including a fenced in area or electronic fence, house or other building, of sufficient strength and height to prevent the dog from escaping from such enclosure, provided, the owner or keeper may, for a period not to exceed one hour every 24 hours, allow the dog to be tethered or chained to a stationary object or pole as long as the dog is provided with sufficient water and nourishment. All dogs off of the property of its owner or keeper shall be controlled by means of a leash and under the direct control of, and obedient to, the owner's or keeper's command. 
(b)  Noncompliance with any of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section may result in the impoundment of the animal at any time, or may result in a fine of $100.00, or both. With respect to any dog found in violation of subsection (a) for a second time, animal control shall have the authority to require that the owner thereof have the dog spayed or neutered by a licensed veterinarian within twenty (20) days. All costs of such spaying or neutering shall be the responsibility of the owner. Failure to comply with any directive to have the dog spayed or neutered shall result in and additional civil penalty of $100.00. 
(c)  Dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the course of law enforcement activities are exempt from this section. 
(Code 1987, § 4-21; Ord. No. O-2008-04, § 2, 3-18-2008, eff. 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 4-20. - Confinement of female cats and dogs in heat. 
    When any female cat or dog is in heat, the owner of such animal shall confine the cat or dog in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that the animal will not be in contact with another cat or dog or create a nuisance by attracting males. With respect to any female cat or dog is found in violation of this section animal control shall have the authority to require that the owner, thereof have the cat or dog spayed within 20 days by a licensed veterinarian. All costs shall be borne by the owner. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the intentional breeding of animals within an enclosed area on the premises of the owner of the animal being bred. 
(Code 1987, § 4-22; Ord. No. O-2008-04, § 3, 3-18-2008, eff. 4-1-2008) 
State Law reference- Permitting bitch at large, G.S. 67-2. 
Sec. 4-21. - Licensing and registering cats and dogs. 
(a)  All cats or dogs kept, harbored or maintained by their owners or keepers in the city shall be licensed and registered. Licenses may be issued by the consumer billing department, veterinary offices or Humane Society upon payment of a license fee as stipulated in subsection (c) of this section. At the time application is made for such license, the owner shall state whether the license is for a cat or dog, the breed, color and sex of the animal, and shall submit proof that the animal has been immunized. 
(b)  Upon payment of the license fee, the owner shall be issued a tag for each cat or dog licensed. The owner shall provide each cat or dog with a collar to which the current license tag must be affixed, and shall ensure that the tag and collar are constantly worn by each cat or dog at all times, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(c)  The annual license fee shall be set from time to time by the city council and on file in the city clerk's office, and shall be payable between January 1 and February 15 of each year. 
(d)  In addition to all other penalties prescribed by law, a cat or dog is subject to impoundment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter if the cat or dog is found not to be wearing a currently valid license tag. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any dog being kept in any governmental facility, veterinary hospital, licensed commercial animal establishment or Seeing eye or service dogs properly trained to assist blind and other disabled persons or law enforcement animals. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to obtain a license tag for his cat or dog within 30 days of moving into the city or acquiring the animal. 
(f)  If ownership of a currently licensed cat or dog is transferred, the new owner may have the current license transferred to his name upon payment to the consumer billing department of a fee as established by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office. 
(g)  Replacement license tags may be obtained from the consumer billing department upon payment of a fee as established by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office. 
(h)  After written warning has been given to the owner or keeper of an unimmunized or unlicensed animal notifying such owner or keeper of their failure to license and/or vaccinate their animal, the animal control officer may issue a citation to the pet owner. The penalty associated with the issuance of a citation shall be set from time to time by the city council and a schedule of such penalties is on file and available in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 4-23) 
State Law reference- Animal taxes, G.S. 160A-212. 
Sec. 4-22. - Strays. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to knowingly and intentionally harbor, feed, keep in possession by confinement or otherwise allow to remain on his property any animal which does not belong to him, unless, within 72 hours from the time such animal came into his possession, he has notified the animal control officer or duly authorized person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to surrender any such stray animal to the animal control officer or duly authorized person upon demand. 
(Code 1987, § 4-24) 
Sec. 4-23. - Nondomestic animal nuisance. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, if any nondomestic animal, or group of nondomestic animals, become a nuisance, the animal control officer may take whatever measures are necessary to abate the nuisance, including, but not limited to, requiring the citizen to take preventive measures, trap and remove, trap to destroy, or destroy such animals. The animal control officer may authorize, in writing, other persons to carry out the provisions of this section, and such persons shall work under the control and supervision of the animal control officer. Any citizen of the city may petition the animal control officer for relief from any nuisance created by a nondomestic animal or group of nondomestic animals, and the animal control officer shall forthwith investigate the situation and take whatever action is appropriate to abate the nuisance. If the animal control officer fails to act within ten days after receipt of the petition, or if the action taken by the animal control officer is ineffective, the petitioner may then file the petition with the city manager, and the city manager is authorized to take whatever action is appropriate to abate the nuisance, and he is authorized to assume all the powers and duties conferred upon the animal control officer in this section. No actions taken under this section shall be in violation of any state or federal wildlife laws or regulations. 
(Code 1987, § 4-25) 
Sec. 4-24. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor, and any person convicted of such violation shall be punished as provided in section 1-10. Each day's violation of this chapter is a separate offense. Payment of a fine imposed in criminal proceedings pursuant to this subsection does not relieve a person of his liability for fees imposed under this chapter. 
(b)  In addition, enforcement of this chapter may be by appropriate equitable remedial injunction or order of abatement issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to G.S. 160A-175. 
(c)  In addition to, or in lieu of, impounding a currently licensed dog found running at large, the animal control officer or his agent may issue a notice of violation of this chapter to the known owner of such dog. Such notice shall impose upon the owner of the dog a penalty as established by the city council, which penalty shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. The notice of violation referred to in this subsection may be delivered in person or mailed to the person violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 4-6) 
Sec. 4-25. - Domesticated animals at vacant residences or structures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession, charge, custody or control of any domesticated animal to allow the animal to be confined at a vacant residence or structure for a period of more than 14 days. For the purposes of this section, a residence or structure shall be deemed "vacant" if there is either no electrical or water service to the same or the same is determined to be uninhabitable by the building inspector. At any time during this 14-day period, if the animal is not adequately and properly cared for or is otherwise subjected to conditions detrimental to its health and general welfare, it shall be deemed abandoned according to state law and shall be seized, impounded and confined in an animal shelter in a humane manner, subject to the terms and conditions of article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-15, § 1, 7-17-2007) 
Secs. 4-26-4-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 4-61. - Generally. 
(a)  Any animal which appears to be lost, stray or unwanted, or not wearing a currently valid license tag or rabies vaccination tag, as required by state law or this chapter, or not under restraint in violation of this chapter, may be seized, impounded and confined in an animal shelter in a humane manner. 
(b)  Impoundment of such an animal shall not relieve the owner or keeper of such animal from any penalty which may be imposed for a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 4-36) 
Sec. 4-62. - Notice to owner or keeper. 
(a)  Upon impounding an animal, notice of impoundment shall be posted for a minimum of 72 hours, beginning with the time the animal enters the animal shelter, or until the animal is disposed of. Reasonable effort shall be made to identify the owner or keeper and inform the owner or keeper of the conditions whereby the animal may be redeemed. 
(b)  Such notice shall be prominently displayed on a bulletin board at the animal shelter, and the time and place of the taking of the animal, together with the time and date of posting the notice, shall be stated in such notice. 
(c)  In the case of impoundment of a duly licensed dog, not later than three days after impounding the dog, the animal control officer or his agent shall attempt to notify the registered owner of the dog by telephone or personal contact. Should such notification be unsuccessful, the animal control officer or his agent shall mail a certified letter to the address indicated on the license tag application. If the certified letter is returned to the city as undeliverable to the address stated on the license application, the city may be relieved of all responsibility of contacting the owner of the dog. 
(Code 1987, § 4-37) 
Sec. 4-63. - Redemption by owner or keeper; fees. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of an animal impounded under this article may redeem the animal and regain possession thereof within 72 hours after notice of impoundment is posted as required by this article by complying with all applicable provisions of this article and paying any applicable fees. 
(b)  The consumer billing department shall charge and collect fees from owners who redeem their animals for the apprehension, notice, feeding and care of such animals. Such fees shall be established by the city council from time to time and are on file at the animal shelter and in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  The fees referred to in subsection (b) of this section do not include any penalty for a violation of any provision of this chapter, nor do they include any charges for licenses or inoculations that may be required of the owner. 
(Code 1987, § 4-38) 
Sec. 4-64. - Redemption of unvaccinated dogs and cats. 
(a)  Unless proof of a current rabies vaccination can be furnished, every person who redeems a dog or cat at the animal shelter will be given a proof of rabies vaccination notice at the time of such redemption. The notice will be marked with a date and state the maximum time limit allowed to take the dog or cat to the veterinarian of such person's choice for rabies vaccination. The time limit for dogs and cats four months of age and older will be 72 hours, excluding Sundays and holidays. The time limit for puppies and kittens under four months of age will vary according to their age. 
(b)  The proof of rabies vaccination notice will be completed by the veterinarian and returned to the animal control officer by the animal owner or keeper. 
(c)  Payment of the rabies vaccination required by this section will be the responsibility of the person redeeming or adopting the animal. 
(Code 1987, § 4-39) 
Sec. 4-65. - Disposition of unredeemed animals. 
(a)  If an impounded animal is not redeemed by the owner or keeper within the period prescribed in section 4-62, it may be destroyed in a humane manner or shall become the property of the animal shelter and offered for adoption to a responsible adult who is willing to comply with this article. 
(b)  Immediately prior to the euthanization of any duly licensed dog, it shall be the responsibility of the animal control officer or his agent to certify to the city manager that the notice to the owner required by this article has been made pursuant to the provisions of section 4-62(c). 
(Code 1987, § 4-40) 
Sec. 4-66. - Adoption or destruction of animals surrendered by their owners. 
    Any animal surrendered by its owner to the animal control officer may be immediately turned over to the animal shelter for adoption or humanely destroyed by the animal control officer. The waiting periods provided in section 4-62 shall not apply to immediate adoption or destruction in this section. 
(Code 1987, § 4-41) 
Sec. 4-67. - Destruction of animals which cannot be seized by reasonable means. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, an animal which cannot be seized by reasonable means may be humanely destroyed by, or upon order of, the animal control officer. 
(Code 1987, § 4-42) 
Secs. 4-68-4-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Rabies control, G.S. 130A-184 et seq.; dogs generally, G.S. ch. 67. 

Sec. 4-101. - Compliance with state rabies laws required; article supplemental to state rabies laws. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any animal owner or other person to fail to comply with the state laws relating to the control of rabies. 
(b)  It is the purpose of this article to supplement such state laws by providing a procedure for the enforcement of state laws relating to rabies control, in addition to the criminal penalties provided by state law. 
(Code 1987, § 4-56) 
Sec. 4-102. - Vaccination of dogs and cats required; tag. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner or keeper of any dog or cat four months of age or older to fail to provide such animal with a current vaccination against rabies (hydrophobia) by a licensed veterinarian with antirabies vaccine as required by the General Statutes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any dog or cat owner or keeper to fail to provide the dog or cat with a collar or harness to which a current rabies tag issued under this section is securely attached. The collar or harness, with the attached tag, must be worn at all times. 
(c)  In addition to all other penalties prescribed by law, a dog or cat is subject to impoundment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter if the dog or cat is found not to be wearing a currently valid rabies tag. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a rabies vaccination tag for an animal other than the animal for which the tag was issued. 
(e)  All dogs and cats shipped or otherwise brought into the city, except for exhibition purposes where dogs and cats are confined and not permitted to run at large, shall be securely confined and vaccinated within one week after such entry, and shall remain confined for two additional weeks after vaccination unless accompanied by a certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog or cat is apparently free from rabies and has not been exposed to rabies, and that the dog or cat has received a proper dose of rabies vaccine not more than six months prior to the date of issuance of the certificate. 
(Code 1987, § 4-57) 
Sec. 4-103. - Areawide emergency quarantine. 
    When reports indicate a positive diagnosis of rabies to the extent that lives of persons are endangered, the mayor shall issue a proclamation declaring an areawide quarantine for such period of time as he deems necessary. Upon invoking such emergency quarantine, no dog or cat may be taken or shipped from the city without written permission of the animal control officer or duly authorized agent. During such quarantine, the animal control officer, law enforcement officers or person duly authorized may seize and impound any dog or cat found running at large in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 4-58) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16; fire prevention and protection, ch. 18; solid waste management, ch. 30; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; storage of lumber, building materials and other merchandise, § 32-44; property numbering, § 32-151 et seq.; utilities, ch. 40; building sewers, § 40-221 et seq.; vegetation, ch. 42; unified land development ordinance, app. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate the construction of buildings, G.S. 160A-412. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Codes adopted; applicability; copies. 
(a)  The North Carolina State Building Code, together with its various articles applying to plumbing, electrical, mechanical, etc., systems, and the North Carolina Uniform Residential Building Code are hereby adopted by reference, as fully as though set forth in this chapter, as the building code of the city. The provisions of this chapter and the regulatory codes adopted in this section shall apply to the location, design, materials, equipment, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, maintenance, moving, demolition, removal, use and occupancy of every building or structure, or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings or structures. 
(b)  An official copy of each regulatory code adopted in this section, and official copies of all amendments to such codes, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and such copies shall be the official copies of the codes and the amendments. 
(Code 1987, § 5-1) 
State Law reference- Building code applicable statewide, G.S. 143-138(e). 
Sec. 6-2. - Moving buildings over streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is engaged in the moving of any house or building to move the house or building over the public streets of the city without first procuring written permission from the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is engaged in the moving of any house or building to permit such house or building to remain standing in the street for more than six continuous hours. Each hour such house or building shall be allowed to stand in violation of the provisions of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1987, § 5-3) 
State Law reference- Professional house moving, G.S. 20-356 et seq. 
Sec. 6-3. - Maintenance of plumbing and sewer systems. 
    The plumbing and sewer system of any premises under the jurisdiction of the city shall be maintained in a sanitary and safe operating condition by the owner of the premises or his agent. 
(Code 1987, § 5-4) 
Secs. 6-4-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Building inspection, stop work orders, condemnation, G.S. 160A-411 et seq. 

Sec. 6-31. - Building inspector. 
(a)  The same person who has been designated as the building inspector by the board of commissioners of the county shall perform the duties of the city building inspector, city electrical inspector, city plumbing inspector and city gas inspector within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The person designated by the board of commissioners of the county as the county building inspector shall, within the corporate limits of the city, administer and carry out the city building code and any building code which may have been, or may be, adopted by reference by the city, the city electrical code and any electrical codes which may be adopted by reference by the city, the city plumbing code and any uniform plumbing codes which may be adopted by reference by the city. 
(c)  For the purpose of carrying out the various city codes listed in subsection (b) of this section, the person employed by the county board of commissioners as the county building inspector shall, if required by ordinance, be given the titles of city building inspector, city plumbing inspector, city electrical inspector and city gas inspector, as the case may be. 
(Code 1987, § 5-21) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority for city to designate county inspector as city inspector, G.S. 160A-413. 
Sec. 6-32. - Building permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to begin or proceed with the construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair or demolition of any building or structure within the city until a permit has been issued by the building inspector. Such permits may be referred to as "building permits." 
(Code 1987, § 5-22) 
State Law reference- Permits, G.S. 160A-417. 
Secs. 6-33-6-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE LIMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Requirement that city establish fire limits, G.S. 160A-435. 

Sec. 6-71. - Established; description. 
    There are hereby established two fire zones for the city, to be designated and described as follows: 
(1)  Primary fire limits. The primary fire limits of the city shall include the territory within the following described boundaries: 
Beginning at the southwest intersection of the Laurinburg and Southern Railroad tracks and Biggs Street; and running thence with the western line of Biggs Street to the northwestern intersection of Biggs Street and Church Street; thence, at the north line of Church Street to the northwestern intersection of Church Street and Oak Alley; thence, at the western edge of Oak Alley 212.9 feet to a concrete monument, at the corner of a lot owned by Hamlet Savings and Loan Association; thence, at and with the line of the Hamlet Savings and Loan Association lot, if extended, to the eastern line of Atkinson Street; thence, at the eastern line of Atkinson Street and continuing on the line with Atkinson Street to the Laurinburg and Southern Railroad tracks; thence, at the Laurinburg and Southern Railroad tracks in a southeastern direction to the beginning. 
(2)  Secondary fire limits. The secondary fire limits of the city shall include as much of the territory described in this subsection as lies outside the primary fire limits, as described in subsection (1) of this section. The outer boundaries of the secondary fire limits shall be as follows: 
Beginning at the northwest intersection of McRae Street and James Street and running at the northern line of McRae Street and continuing in a line therewith to the northeastern intersection of McLean Street and Everett Street; thence, at the eastern line of Everett Street to the northeast intersection of Everett Street and Church Street; thence, at the northern line of Church Street to the northeast intersection of Church Street and McLaurin Avenue; thence, along the western line of McLaurin Avenue extended to the Laurinburg and Southern Railroad tracks; thence, on a line with the southern line of Dickson Street and continuing at the southern line on Dickson Street to a point in the southern line of Dickson Street at the intersection with the western line of James Street, if extended; thence, on a line with the western line of James Street to the beginning. 
(Code 1987, § 5-41) 
Sec. 6-72. - Building within fire limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any building or structure within the fire limits established and described in section 6-71, unless such building or structure complies with the requirements of the state building code or the state uniform residential building code as adopted in this chapter, whichever may be applicable. 
(Code 1987, § 5-42) 
State Law reference- Restrictions within primary fire limits, G.S. 160A-436; restrictions within secondary fire limits, G.S. 160A-437. 
Sec. 6-73. - Wooden buildings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move any wooden building into the fire limits established and described in section 6-71, and it shall be unlawful for any person to move any wooden building from one place within such fire limits to any other place within such fire limits. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to repair, add to or in any way change any wooden building within such fire limits without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the building inspector. The required permit shall only be granted upon written application, setting forth, in detail, the repairs or alterations which the applicant proposes to make, and upon approval of the city council. In addition to such permit, the building inspector shall provide a printed notice which the owner must display in a prominent place on the lot so that it can be easily seen from the street. 
(Code 1987, § 5-43) 
Secs. 6-74-6-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED STRUCTURES AND DWELLINGS UNFIT FOR HUMAN HABITATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Minimum housing standards, G.S. 160A-441 et seq. 

Sec. 6-101. - Findings; intent. 
    It is hereby found that the following exists within the city: 
(1)  Abandoned structures which the city council finds to be hazardous to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city due to the attraction of insects or rodents, conditions creating a fire hazard, dangerous conditions constituting a threat to children or frequent use by vagrants as living quarters in the absence of sanitary facilities; 
(2)  Dwellings that are unfit for human habitation due to dilapidation, defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities, lack of ventilation, light or sanitary facilities or due to other conditions rendering the dwellings unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, morals or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city. 
Therefore, pursuant to the authority granted by G.S. 160A-441, it is the intent of this article to provide for the repair, closing, demolition or removal of such dwellings or structures. 
(Code 1987, § 5-81) 
Sec. 6-102. - Supplemental nature. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to abdicate or impair the powers of the courts or any department of the city to enforce any provisions of its Charter, ordinances or regulations, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof. The powers conferred by this article shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law. 
(Code 1987, § 5-82) 
State Law reference- Supplemental nature of part, G.S. 160A-450. 
Sec. 6-103. - Planner/code enforcer officer designated as building inspector. 
    The city planner/code enforcer officer is designated as the building inspector for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 5-83) 
Sec. 6-104. - Duties of building inspector. 
    The building inspector is designated as the city officer who shall enforce the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the building inspector to: 
(1)  Locate abandoned structures and substandard dwellings within the city and determine which of such structures are in violation of this article; 
(2)  Take such action pursuant to this article as may be necessary to provide for the repair, closing or demolition of such structures; 
(3)  Keep an accurate record of all enforcement proceedings begun pursuant to the provisions of this article; and 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed in this article or assigned to the building inspector by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 5-84) 
Sec. 6-105. - Powers of building inspector. 
    The building inspector is authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary to carry out the intent and provisions of this article, including, in addition to other powers granted in this article, the power to: 
(1)  Investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings are unfit for human habitation; 
(2)  Investigate the conditions of buildings within the city in order to determine which structures are abandoned and in violation of this article; 
(3)  Enter upon premises for the purpose of making examination in a manner that will create the least possible inconvenience for the persons in possession of such premises; 
(4)  Administer oaths, affirmations, examine witnesses and receive evidence; 
(5)  Designate such other officers, agents and employees of the city as he deems necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 5-85) 
State Law reference- Additional powers of public officer, G.S. 160A-448. 
Sec. 6-106. - Standards for enforcement. 
(a)  Dwellings unfit for human habitation. 
(1)  The building inspector may determine that a dwelling is unfit for human habitation if he finds that conditions exist in the dwelling that render it dangerous or injurious to the health, safety or morals of the occupants of the dwelling, the occupants of neighboring dwellings or other residents of the city. 
(2)  Notwithstanding subsection (a)(1) of this section, defective conditions may include the following: 
a.  Defects increasing the hazard of fire, accident or other calamities; 
b.  Lack of adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; 
c.  Dilapidation; 
d.  Disrepair; 
e.  Structural defects; 
f.  Uncleanliness; and 
g.  Violations of other city ordinances, the state building code, standard housing code, state electrical code or fire prevention code which constitute a fire hazard in such structure or which might result in danger to the occupants. 
(b)  Abandoned structures. 
(1)  Every abandoned structure within the city shall be deemed in violation of this article whenever such structure constitutes a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the city's citizens as a result of: 
a.  The attraction of insects or rodents; 
b.  Conditions creating a fire hazard; 
c.  Dangerous conditions constituting a threat to children; or 
d.  Frequent use by vagrants as living quarters in the absence of sanitary facilities. 
(2)  In making the preliminary determination as to whether or not an abandoned structure is in violation of this article, the building inspector may, by way of illustration and not limitation, consider the presence or absence of the following conditions: 
a.  Holes or cracks in the structure's floors, walls, ceilings or roof which might attract or admit rodents and insects or become breeding places for rodents and insects; 
b.  The collection of garbage or rubbish in or near the structure which might attract rodents and insects or become breeding places for rodents and insects; 
c.  Violations of the state building code, standard housing code, state electrical code or fire prevention code which constitute a fire hazard in such structure; 
d.  The collection of garbage, rubbish or combustible material which constitutes a fire hazard in such structure; 
e.  The use of such structure or nearby grounds or facilities by children as a play area; 
f.  Violation of the state building code which might result in danger to children using the structure or nearby grounds or facilities as a play area; and 
g.  Repeated use of such structure by transients and vagrants, in the absence of sanitary facilities, for living, sleeping, cooking, drinking or eating. 
(Code 1987, § 5-86) 
State Law reference- Exercise of police power authorized, finding of health or safety hazard, G.S. 160A-441; standards, G.S. 160A-444. 
Sec. 6-107. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  Preliminary investigations; notices; hearings . Whenever a petition is filed with the building inspector by at least five residents of the city charging that any dwelling or structure exists in violation of this article, or whenever it appears to the building inspector, upon inspection, that any dwelling or structure exists in violation of this article, the building inspector shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of, and parties in interest in, such dwelling or structure, a complaint stating the charges in such respect and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the building inspector at a place fixed in such complaint, which shall be not less than ten days, nor more than 30 days after the serving of the complaint. The owner and parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or otherwise and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint. Notice of such hearing shall also be given to at least one of the persons signing a petition relating to such structure. Any person who desires may attend such hearing and give evidence relevant to the matter being heard. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the building inspector. 
(b)  Issuance of order to correct violations . If, after notice of the hearing, the building inspector determines that the dwelling or structure is in violation of this article, he shall state, in writing, his findings of fact supporting such determination, and shall issue, and cause to be served upon the owner of the dwelling or structure, an order to correct the violation. 
(1)  In the case of an abandoned building, such order shall direct and require the owner to either repair, close and secure such structure or demolish and remove the structure within a specified period of time, not to exceed 90 days. 
(2)  In the case of a dwelling which is determined to be unfit for human habitation: 
a.  If the repair, alteration or improvement of the dwelling can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, which reasonable cost shall be less than 50 percent of the value of the building, the order shall require the owner, within the time specified, to repair, alter or improve the dwelling in order to render the dwelling fit for human habitation or to vacate and close the dwelling as a human habitation; or 
b.  If the repair, alteration or improvement of the dwelling cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, which reasonable cost shall not to be in excess of 50 percent, the order shall require the owner to remove or demolish such dwelling within the time specified in the order. 
(c)  Failure to comply with order. 
(1)  In personam remedy. If the owner of any structure shall fail to comply with the order of the building inspector within the time specified in such order, the building inspector may submit a resolution to the city council at its next regular meeting, directing the city attorney to petition the superior court for an order directing such owner to comply with the order of the building inspector as authorized by G.S. 160A-446(g). 
(2)  In rem remedy. After failure of an owner of a structure to comply with an order of the building inspector within the time specified in such order, if injunctive relief has not been sought or has not been granted as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the building inspector may submit an ordinance to the city council ordering the building inspector to cause such structure to be repaired, closed or demolished as provided in the original order of the building inspector, and pending such repair, closing or demolition, to placard such structure as provided by G.S. 160A-443(4). 
(d)  Petition of superior court by owner . Any person aggrieved by an order issued by the building inspector shall have the right, within 30 days after issuance of such order, to petition the superior court for a temporary injunction restraining the building inspector pending a final disposition of the cause as provided by G.S. 160A-446(f). 
(e)  Notice of lis pendens. Upon the issuance of a complaint and notice of hearing pursuant to this section, the building inspector may cause the filing of a notice of lis pendens, with a copy of the complaint and notice of hearing attached thereto, in the Office of the Clerk of Superior Court of Scotland County, to be indexed and cross-indexed in accordance with the indexing procedures of the North Carolina General Statutes. The building inspector shall cause a copy of the notice of lis pendens to be served upon the owners and parties in interest in the building or dwelling at the time of filing in accordance with G.S. 160A-445, as applicable. Upon compliance with the requirements of any order issued based upon such complaint and hearing, the inspector shall direct the Clerk of Superior Court to cancel the notice of lis pendens. 
(Code 1987, § 5-88; Ord. No. O-2012-19, § 2, 6-19-2012, eff. 7-1-2012) 
State Law reference- Ordinance authorized as to repair, closing and demolition, order of public officer, G.S. 160A-443. 
Sec. 6-108. - Service of complaints and orders. 
    Complaints or orders issued by the building inspector pursuant to this article shall be served upon the persons either personally or by registered or certified mail. If the identity of any owners or the whereabouts of the persons are unknown and cannot be ascertained by the building inspector in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the building inspector makes an affidavit to such effect, the serving of the complaint or order upon the unknown owners or other persons may be made by publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the city at least once, no later than the time at which personal service would be required under the terms of this article. When service is made by publication, a notice of the pending proceedings shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises thereby affected. 
(Code 1987, § 5-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-445. 
Sec. 6-109. - In rem action. 
    After failure of an owner of a structure to comply with an order of the building inspector issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, and upon adoption by the city council of an ordinance authorizing and directing him to do so, as provided by G.S. 160A-443(4), (5) and 5-88(c), the building inspector shall proceed to cause such structure to either be repaired, closed or demolished as directed by the ordinance of the city council, and shall cause a placard to be posted on the main entrance of such structure, prohibiting the use or occupation of the structure. Use or occupation of a posted building shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each such ordinance shall be recorded in the office of the register of deeds of the county, and shall be indexed in the name of the property owner in the grantor index, as provided by G.S. 160A-443(5). 
(Code 1987, § 5-90) 
Sec. 6-110. - Lien on premises. 
    As provided by G.S. 160A-443(6), the amount of the cost of the repair, alteration or improvement, or of the vacating, closing, removal or demolition by the building inspector shall be a lien against the real property upon which the cost was incurred, which lien shall be filed, have the same priority and be collected as a lien for special assessments provided in G.S. ch. 160A, art. 10. If the dwelling is removed or demolished by the building inspector, he shall sell the materials of the dwelling and any personal property, fixtures or appurtenances found in or attached to the dwelling or structure, and shall credit the proceeds of the sale against the cost of the removal or demolition. Any balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the building inspector, secured in a manner directed by the court, and disbursed by the court to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of the court. Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the powers of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(Code 1987, § 5-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-443(6). 
Sec. 6-111. - Appeals. 
(a)  The zoning board of adjustment (referred to in this article as the "board") shall hear appeals from the building inspector. 
(b)  An appeal of any decision or order of the building inspector may be made by any person aggrieved thereby or by any officer, board or commission of the city. Any appeal from a decision or order of the building inspector shall be made within ten days from the rendering of the decision or service of the order by filing a notice of appeal with the building inspector and the board, which notice shall specify the grounds upon which the appeal is based. Upon the filing of any notice of appeal, the building inspector shall forthwith transmit to the board all of the papers constituting the record upon which the appealed decision or order was made. Where an appeal is made of a decision or order of the building inspector refusing to allow the person aggrieved thereby to do any act, the building inspector's decision or order shall remain in force until modified or reversed. When any appeal is made of the decision of the building inspector requiring the person aggrieved to do any act, the appeal shall have the effect of suspending the requirement until the hearing by the board unless the building inspector certifies to the board, after the notice of appeal is filed with him, that, because of facts stated in the certificate, a copy of which shall be furnished to the appellant, a suspension of the building inspector's requirement would cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, the requirement shall not be suspended, except by a restraining order which may be granted for due cause shown upon not less than one day's written notice to the building inspector by the board or a court of record upon petition made pursuant to subsection (e) of this section. 
(c)  The appeals board shall fix a reasonable time for hearing appeals and shall give due notice to the parties and shall render its decision within a reasonable time. Any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. The board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the decision or order appealed. The board may make any decision or order that, in its opinion, should be made in the matter. To such end, the board shall have all the powers of the building inspector, but the concurring vote of four members of the board shall be necessary to reverse or modify any decision or order of the building inspector. The board shall also have power in passing appeals, when practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships would result from carrying out the strict letter of this article, to adapt the application of this article to the necessities of the case so that the spirit of this article shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. 
(d)  Every decision of the board shall be subject to review by proceedings in the nature of certiorari instituted within 15 days of the decision of the board. The decision of the board shall not otherwise be subject to review. 
(e)  Any person aggrieved by a decision or order issued by the building inspector or a decision rendered by the board may petition the superior court for an injunction restraining the building inspector from carrying out his decision or order or the decision of the board. Upon such petition, the court may issue a temporary injunction restraining the building inspector, pending a final disposition of the cause. The petition shall be filed within 30 days after issuance of the building inspector's decision or order or rendering of the decision of the board. Hearings shall be held by the court on a petition within 20 days and shall be given preference over other matters on the court's calendar. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require. It shall not be necessary to file a bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this subsection. 
(Code 1987, § 5-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-446(c)-(f). 
Sec. 6-112. - Compensation of property owners. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as preventing the owner of any property from receiving just compensation for the taking of property by the power of eminent domain under the laws of the state, nor as permitting any property to be condemned or destroyed, except in accordance with the police power of the state. 
(Code 1987, § 5-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-447. 
Sec. 6-113. - Violations; actions and proceedings. 
    If any dwelling or structure is erected, constructed, altered, repaired, converted, maintained or used in violation of this article or any valid order or decision of the building inspector or board made pursuant to this article, the building inspector or board may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to: 
(1)  Prevent the unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration or use; 
(2)  Restrain, correct or abate the violation; 
(3)  Prevent the occupancy of the dwelling; or 
(4)  Prevent any illegal act, conduct or use in and about the premises of the building. 
(Code 1987, § 5-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-446(g). 
Secs. 6-114-6-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16. 

Sec. 6-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inspector means the city planner/code enforcer officer. 
    Unsafe building means a structure judged to be especially dangerous to life because of its liability to fire, the bad condition of the walls, overloaded floors, defective construction, decay, unsafe wiring or heating systems, inadequate means of egress or other causes. 
(Code 1987, § 5-106) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-142. - Findings; purpose. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.S. 160A-426, it is found and declared that buildings exist in the city which are unsafe because of age, structural defects or a general state of disrepair. 
(b)  In order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city as authorized by G.S. 160A-411 et seq., it is the purpose of this article to establish the procedure for condemning unsafe buildings. This article shall be used in conjunction with the city's minimum housing code to promote maintenance standards that will ensure safe buildings in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 5-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-426. 
Sec. 6-143. - Records. 
    The inspector shall keep complete and accurate records, in a convenient form, of all proceedings pertaining to this article. Such records shall be kept in the manner and for the period prescribed by the state department of cultural resources. 
(Code 1987, § 5-109) 
State Law reference- Records and reports, G.S. 160A-433. 
Sec. 6-144. - Condemnation procedure. 
(a)  Upon the thorough inspection of a building and the determination that it is indeed unsafe because it has one or more of the characteristics stated in the definition of the term "unsafe building" in section 6-141, the inspector shall affix a notice of the dangerous character of the structure upon a conspicuous place on the exterior wall of the building. 
(b)  Upon posting the unsafe notice on a building, the inspector shall give the owner written notice, by certified or registered mail to his last known address or by personal service, that: 
(1)  The building or structure is in a condition that appears to constitute a fire or safety hazard or to be dangerous to life, health or other property; 
(2)  A hearing will be held before the inspector at a designated place and time not less than ten days, nor more than 30 days after the serving of the notice, at which time the owner shall be entitled to be heard in person or by counsel and to present arguments and evidence pertaining to the matter; and 
(3)  Following the hearing, the inspector may issue an order to repair, close, vacate or demolish the building or structure, as appears appropriate. 
(c)  If the name or whereabouts of the owner cannot be discovered after due diligence, the notice shall be considered properly and adequately served if a copy thereof is posted on the outside of the building or structure in question at least ten days prior to the hearing and a notice of the hearing is published at least one time in a newspaper having general circulation in the city not later than one week prior to the hearing. 
(d)  Upon the issuance of a notice of hearing pursuant to this section, the inspector may cause the filing of a notice of lis pendens, with a copy of the notice of hearing attached thereto, in the Office of the Clerk of Superior Court of Scotland County, to be indexed and cross-indexed in accordance with the indexing procedures of the North Carolina General Statutes. The inspector shall cause a copy of the notice of lis pendens to be served upon the owners and parties in interest in the building or dwelling at the time of filing in accordance with G.S. 160A-428, as applicable. Upon compliance with the requirements of any order issued following such hearing, the inspector shall direct the Clerk of Superior Court to cancel the notice of lis pendens. 
(Code 1987, § 5-110; Ord. No. O-2012-19, § 1, 6-19-2012, eff. 7-1-2012) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-426, 160A-428. 
Sec. 6-145. - Issuance of order. 
    If, upon a hearing held in accordance with the procedure set out in section 6-144, the inspector shall find that the building or structure is in a condition that constitutes a fire or safety hazard or renders it dangerous to life, health or other property, he shall make an order, in writing, directed to the owner of the building or structure requiring the owner to remedy the defective condition by repairing, closing, vacating or demolishing the building or structure or taking other necessary steps within 60 days. 
(Code 1987, § 5-111) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-429. 
Sec. 6-146. - Appeals. 
    An owner who has received an order as described in section 6-145 may appeal the order to the city council by giving notice of appeal, in writing, to the inspector and the city clerk within ten days following issuance of the order. In the absence of an appeal, the order of the inspector shall be final. The city council shall hear the appeal within a reasonable time and may modify, affirm or revoke the order. If the city council affirms the inspector's action, the 60-day abatement period may be judged to have been initiated with the date of the inspector's written order to the owner. The inspector shall inform owners of such appeal procedure. 
(Code 1987, § 5-112) 
State Law reference- Appeal; finality of order if not appealed, G.S. 160A-430. 
Sec. 6-147. - Failure to comply. 
    If the owner of a building or structure fails to comply with an order issued pursuant to section 6-145 from which no appeal has been made or fails to comply with an order of the city council following an appeal, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished at the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1987, § 5-113) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-431. 
Sec. 6-148. - Violations. 
    Whenever any violation is determined to be a misdemeanor under the provisions of this article, the city, either in addition to or in lieu of other remedies, may initiate any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent, restrain, correct or abate the violation or to prevent the occupancy of the building or structure involved. 
(Code 1987, § 5-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-432. 
Secs. 6-149-6-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 6-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private means not open to the public, not publicly owned or not otherwise regulated by the state either by statute, or rules or regulations of one of the state's administrative agencies. 
    Swimming pool means any artificially constructed, nonportable pool, capable of being used for swimming or bathing, and having a depth of two feet or more at any point. 
(Code 1987, § 5-131) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-182. - Permit required; application; fee. 
(a)  A permit shall be obtained from the zoning enforcement officer before construction shall begin on any swimming pool. The application for the permit shall be accompanied by a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the swimming pool, and such plans and specifications shall be approved by the zoning enforcement officer before any permit shall be issued. 
(b)  All applications for a permit shall be accompanied by a permit fee, the amount of which shall be set by the city council and kept on file in the offices of the city clerk and zoning enforcement officer. 
(Code 1987, § 5-132) 
Sec. 6-183. - General requirements. 
(a)  Pool construction shall conform to the state building and plumbing codes which are enforced by the county inspection office in the city. Any accessory building which houses pumping and filtering equipment must conform to the provisions of appendix A of this Code. All swimming pools, inclusive of paved decks and all accessory buildings, shall be located no closer than eight feet to any property line. 
(b)  No swimming pool shall be located in the front yard of any residence. 
(c)  Fiberglass and plastic pools may be permitted, provided they meet accepted safety and construction standards. 
(d)  The water department may regulate the hours for filling pools, and no pool shall be drained during periods of rainfall. 
(e)  Owners of pools shall regulate their use in a manner so as not to create any undue noise or disturbance. 
(Code 1987, § 5-133) 
Sec. 6-184. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  There shall be no cross connection of the city water supply with any other source of water supply for the pool. The line from the city water supply to the pool shall be protected against backflow of water by means of an air gap and shall discharge at least six inches above the maximum high water level of the makeup tank or the pool. 
(b)  The drain line for the pool may be connected to the city sewer system, if the following revisions are complied with: 
(1)  The pool drain shall be connected to the storm sewer, if available. 
(2)  Where a storm sewer is not available, the pool drain may be connected to a sanitary sewer or a combined sewer, subject to the approval of the engineering department, provided, an air gap discharge connection is installed. 
(Code 1987, § 5-134) 
Sec. 6-185. - Fences. 
    All swimming pools to be constructed or which are already constructed shall be enclosed by a fence which shall be at least four feet in height and shall be of a type not readily climbed by children. The gates shall be of a self-closing and latching type, with the latch on the inside of the gate, and not readily available for children to open; provided, however, that if the entire premises of the residence is enclosed, then this provision may be waived by the zoning enforcement officer upon inspection and approval of the residence enclosure. 
(Code 1987, § 5-135) 
Sec. 6-186. - Inspection. 
    The zoning enforcement officer and county building inspector shall have the right, at any reasonable hour, to inspect any swimming pool for the purpose of determining that all provisions of this article are fulfilled and complied with. 
(Code 1987, § 5-136) 
Secs. 6-187-6-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SIGNS 

Sec. 6-221. - Consent and approval required for posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, tack or otherwise fasten to, or lean against, any building, wall, fence, tree, pole, post or any other property, any advertising sign, card or placard, without the consent or approval of the owner of such property. 
(Code 1987, § 21-1) 
State Law reference- Unlawful posting of advertisements, G.S. 14-145; tax on advertisers, G.S. 105-86. 
Sec. 6-222. - Posting on trees, parks and utility poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tack or paste signs of any description on any shade tree upon any street or in any park, or on any telephone, telegraph or electric light pole. 
(Code 1987, § 21-3) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 40; vegetation, ch. 42. 
Sec. 6-223. - Posting across streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, hang or suspend any sign or banner across any street, unless such person shall first have obtained a permit from the city manager, and shall post such sign or banner under the direction and supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 21-4) 
Sec. 6-224. - Posting on building fronts and across sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, hang or suspend any sign or banner in front of any building or across any sidewalk without a written permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 21-5) 
Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Sales, ch. 28; taxation, ch. 34; telecommunications, ch. 36; utilities, ch. 40; vehicles for hire, ch. 44. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and license businesses, trades and professions, G.S. 160A-194; authority to levy privilege license taxes, G.S. 160A-211. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Nonpayment at places of amusement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the knowledge or consent of any person in charge of any amusement or any show where an admission fee is charged, to see such event without paying for such privilege. 
(Code 1987, § 3-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate places of amusement, G.S. 160A-181. 
Sec. 8-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2019-07, § 1, adopted March 19, 2019, repealed § 8-2, which pertained to billiard or pool tables where alcoholic beverages are sold for on-premises consumption and derived from Code 1987, § 3-2. 
Sec. 8-3. - Distance requirement for circuses, shows and amusements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, display, run or operate any itinerant circus, show or any similar amusement within a distance of one block of any church or school without the written consent of the officials of the church or school affected. 
(Code 1987, § 3-3) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate circuses, G.S. 160A-181. 
Sec. 8-4. - Shooting galleries prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install or operate any shooting gallery within the corporate limits of the city except for military and law enforcement operations. 
(Code 1987, § 3-4) 
Secs. 8-5-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVILEGE LICENSE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- License taxes, G.S. 105-33 et seq.; authority to regulate and license occupations, businesses, etc., G.S. 160A-194, G.S. 160A-211. 

Sec. 8-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means the person having the agency for the manufacturer, producer or distributor. 
    Business means any business, trade, occupation, profession, vocation or calling of any kind subject to a license tax by the provisions of this article. 
    Engaged in business means engaged in the business as owner or operator. 
    Fiscal year means the period beginning July 1 and ending the next following June 30. 
    Quarter means any three consecutive months. 
(Code 1987, § 23-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-32. - Construction. 
    No provision contained in this article shall be construed to prevent the city council imposing from time to time as it may see fit, such license taxes as are not specifically defined in the license schedule referred to in section 8-34, or from increasing or decreasing the amount of any special license tax, or from prohibiting or regulating the business or acts licensed. 
(Code 1987, § 23-17) 
Sec. 8-33. - Levy and collection. 
    Under the power and authority conferred by the laws of the state, there shall be levied and collected annually, or more often where provided for, a privilege license tax on trades, professions, business operations, exhibitions, circuses and all subjects authorized to be licensed as provided in this article and in accordance with the current schedule of license taxes. 
(Code 1987, § 23-18) 
Sec. 8-34. - Schedule adopted. 
    The North Carolina Privilege License Taxation Schedule, as published by the Institute of Government, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, 2000 edition, by Mr. William A. Campbell, is hereby adopted by reference, and a copy is on file in the city clerk's office. All privilege license taxes for the city shall be as set forth in such publication, and administrative and enforcement procedures stipulated in the publication shall be followed in the billing and collection of the city's privilege license taxes. 
(Code 1987, § 23-19) 
Sec. 8-35. - Abatement; refund. 
    No license tax, the payment of which is required under this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34, shall be abated, nor shall any refund of any part thereof be made in any case where the licensee discontinues his business before the end of the period for which such license was issued. 
(Code 1987, § 23-20) 
Sec. 8-36. - Terms. 
    All licenses and license taxes provided for and fixed in this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34 shall be for 12 months, unless otherwise specified, and shall so remain for 12 months beginning July 1 and ending with the expiration of the next following June 30, provided that, where the license is issued after January 1, then the licensee shall be required to pay only one-half the tax prescribed, except where otherwise specifically provided for. 
(Code 1987, § 23-21) 
Sec. 8-37. - Prerequisite to engaging in business. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or his agent or servant to engage in or carry on a business in the city for which a license is required under this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34 without first having paid to the city tax collector the requisite license tax and obtained the requisite license from the city tax collector. For the purpose of this section, the opening of a place of business or offering to sell, followed by a single sale or the doing of any act or thing in furtherance of the business, shall be construed to be engaging in or carrying on such business. 
(Code 1987, § 23-22) 
Sec. 8-38. - License granted subject to Code and valid ordinances. 
    All licenses shall be granted subject to the provisions of this Code and all other valid ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 23-23) 
Sec. 8-39. - Limitation on validity of license. 
    A license issued under this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34 for the privilege of conducting a business shall be valid only for the business conducted at the place and by the licensee named in such license. 
(Code 1987, § 23-24) 
Sec. 8-40. - Display of license. 
    Every license issued under this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34 shall be kept prominently displayed at the place of business of the licensee named in the license or, if the licensee has no fixed place of business, such licensee shall keep the license wherever such business is being operated and where it can be inspected at any time by the proper municipal official. 
(Code 1987, § 8-40) 
Sec. 8-41. - Separate businesses or locations. 
(a)  The payment of any particular license tax imposed by this article and by the schedule referred to in section 8-34 shall not relieve the person paying the tax from the payment of any other tax imposed by this article and such schedule for any other business he may carry on, unless so provided by the section imposing such tax. It is the intent of this article and such schedule that license taxes prescribed by various sections of this article and the schedule applicable to any business shall be cumulative, except where otherwise specifically provided.
