(b)  Every person doing business in more than one factory, mill, warehouse, store, stall, stand or other place of business shall secure a separate license for each such place of business, unless such places of business are contiguous to each other, communicate directly with an opening into each other and are operated as a unit. 
(Code 1987, § 23-26) 
Sec. 8-42. - Change of location or sale of business. 
    If a business licensed under this article and the schedule referred to in section 8-34 is moved, or if a licensee under this article and such schedule sells to another person, a new license shall be necessary, unless a special permit to continue business under the original license is obtained from the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 23-27) 
Sec. 8-43. - Limitation of coin-operated music machines. 
    The licensing of more than one coin-operated musical machine shall not be permitted in one location, store or other place of business within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 23-28) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate places of amusement, G.S. 160A-181. 
Secs. 8-44-8-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS, PEDDLERS OR VENDORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate solicitation campaigns, flea markets and itinerant merchants, G.S. 160A-178. 

Sec. 8-71. - Definitions; compliance required; applicability. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether or not a resident of the city, who engages in the business of carrying any goods, wares or merchandise from place to place and offering to sell or barter, or actually selling or bartering, such goods or merchandise. 
    Transient merchant, itinerant merchant and itinerant vendor (all such terms referred to in this article as "itinerant merchant") mean any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether or not a resident of the city, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, trailer, railroad box car, truck or boat, public room in hotels, motels, lodginghouses, apartments or shops, or any street, alley or other place within the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction, provided that such definition shall not be construed to include: 
(1)  Any person selling at a flea market taxed under G.S. 105-53(d). 
(2)  Any person selling at a "yard sale," as such term is defined in section 28-31 of this Code. 
(3)  Any person, firm or corporation that otherwise meets the requirements of this definition, but who is part of a group of ten or more merchants selling at a shopping area or trade show, and is selling at the invitation of the shopping area or trade show, and where such sales activities do not last for a period of time longer than seven days. 
(4)  A traveling salesman. 
(b)  Relief from compliance by association. For the purpose of this article, a person, firm or corporation engaged in a transient business shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of temporarily associating with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(c)  Applicability. The provisions of this section dealing with transient merchants, itinerant merchants, itinerant vendors and peddlers shall not apply to any person, firm or corporation who sells, or offers for sale, books, periodicals, printed music, ice, wood for fuel, fish, beef, mutton, pork, bread, cakes, pies, dairy products, poultry, eggs, vegetables, fruits, livestock or articles produced by the individual vendor offering such articles for sale, but shall apply to medicines, drugs or assembled articles. 
(Code 1987, § 23-52) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-72. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor or peddler to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a privilege license in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 23-51) 
State Law reference- Peddlers, itinerant merchants and specialty market operators, G.S. 105-53. 
Sec. 8-73. - License applications. 
    Applicants for the privilege license as required in section 8-72 shall file a written application to the zoning officer of the city. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A description of the goods, wares or merchandise for sale. 
(2)  The names of the persons, and any employees or agents, having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that such business will be carried on in the city; the local addresses of such persons while engaged in such business; the permanent addresses of such persons; the capacity in which such persons will act, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise; the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any and, if a corporation, under the law of what state the corporation is incorporated. 
(3)  Proof of state sales tax reporting number issued by the state department of revenue. 
(4)  Places within the city where the applicant proposes to conduct business and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business shall be conducted, and the provisions the applicant has for access and parking. 
(5)  Proof of the property owner's permission to conduct such business. 
(Code 1987, § 23-53) 
Sec. 8-74. - Bond. 
    Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this article for engaging in a transient or itinerant business, an applicant shall file a bond with the city clerk in the currently required amount, executed by the applicant, a principal or surety, upon which service of process may be made within the state. Such bond shall be conditioned that the applicant shall fully comply with all provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against the applicant by any person for damage arising out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with the applicant, whether such misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the applicant or its servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold, or any part thereof. Any aggrieved person may bring action against the licensee in the general court of justice of the county. The bond required by this section shall be posted and shall remain in effect at all times the license is in effect. Such bond shall be approved by the office of the city attorney, both as to form and the responsibility of the surety. 
(Code 1987, § 23-54) 
Sec. 8-75. - License fee. 
    Before issuing a license under this article, the zoning officer shall collect a license fee in an amount which shall be set from time to time and is on file in the city clerk's office, which shall be for a term of one year from the date of issuance and shall not be pro rated due to the license being issued later than July 1. The license fee shall not relieve the applicant of paying any other state or local taxes required by law. 
(Code 1987, § 23-55) 
Sec. 8-76. - Investigation of application; issuance of license; term of validity; change of location; transferability. 
(a)  The zoning officer shall investigate all applications within five days from receipt of the application. 
(b)  If the applicant satisfies all requirements of this article, the consumer billing department of the city shall issue a license. The zoning officer shall maintain a copy of all license applications and all licenses issued. 
(c)  The license shall be issued for a period of one year. Itinerant merchant licenses will be valid for the location indicated on the license. If the location changes, the itinerant merchant shall apply for a new license. 
(d)  The license is not transferable to other persons or locations. 
(Code 1987, § 23-56) 
Sec. 8-77. - Posting of license. 
    The license issued under this article shall be conspicuously posted in the place of business named on such license. 
(Code 1987, § 23-57) 
Sec. 8-78. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to civic clubs located within the county, nor to any bona fide charitable, educational, religious, cultural or governmental institution or organization when the proceeds of the sales are used directly for the institution's or organization's charitable purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 23-58) 
Sec. 8-79. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the city inspections division, during normal business hours, and the city police department, during all other times, to enforce this article. 
(Code 1987, § 23-59) 
Sec. 8-80. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  Licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the zoning officer of the city, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or a false statement contained in the application for the license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or a false statement made in the course of carrying on the business as peddler or itinerant merchant; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Convictions of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  Conducting the business of peddler or itinerant merchant in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a detriment to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, specifically setting forth the grounds of complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1987, § 23-60) 
Sec. 8-81. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the zoning officer in the denial of an application for a license as provided in section 8-73, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in section 8-80, shall have the right to appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the council, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement, fully setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided in section 8-80 for notice of a hearing on revocation of a license. The decision and order of the council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1987, § 23-61) 
Sec. 8-82. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor, and every person convicted of a violation of this article may be punished in accordance with section 1-10 of this Code. 
(b)  Each day's violation of this article shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the provisions of this article may be enforced by an appropriate equitable remedy issued from a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  The violation of this article shall subject the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of $250.00, provided, the offender does not pay the fine within ten days after he has been convicted of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 23-62) 
Secs. 8-83-8-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TAX ON GROSS RECEIPTS FROM RETAIL SHORTTERM LEASE OR RENTAL OF VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy a tax on gross receipts from retail shortterm leases of vehicles, G.S. 160A-215.1. 

Sec. 8-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Customer means any person that leases or rents a vehicle on a shortterm lease or rental basis. 
    Gross receipts means the amount that is, or would be, reported as gross receipts on a business's state income tax return, or on the federal income tax return filed with the state income tax return if the state return does not separately state gross receipts for the most recently completed tax year. Taxes collected under this article are not subject to the tax imposed in this article and are not included in gross receipts. 
    Lease and rental mean a transfer, for consideration, of the use, but not the ownership, of property to another for a period of time. 
    Longterm lease or rental means a lease or rental made under a written agreement to lease or rent property to the same person for a period of at least 365 continuous days. 
    Shortterm lease or rental means any lease or rental of a vehicle that is not a longterm lease or rental. 
    Tax collector means the individual appointed by the city council pursuant to G.S. 105-187.1(4) and G.S. 160A-215.1(e)(2). 
    Taxpayer means any person liable for the taxes imposed by this article. 
    Vehicle means any of the following: 
(1)  A motor vehicle of the private passenger type, including a passenger van, minivan or sport utility vehicle. 
(2)  A motor vehicle of the cargo type, including a cargo van, pickup truck or truck with a gross vehicle weight of 26,000 pounds or less, used predominantly in the transportation of property for other than commercial freight, and that does not require the operator to possess a commercial driver's license. 
(3)  A trailer or semitrailer with a gross vehicle weight of 6,000 pounds or less. 
(Code 1987, § 23-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-112. - Levied. 
    A tax is hereby imposed and levied in an amount equal to 1.5 percent of the gross receipts derived from the shortterm lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public. The tax on gross receipts is in addition to the privilege taxes authorized by G.S. 160A-211. 
(Code 1987, § 23-92) 
Sec. 8-113. - Collection. 
    Every person engaged in the business of the shortterm lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public shall collect, at the time of the lease or rental, the tax levied in this article, place the tax collected in a segregated account, and thereafter remit such tax to the tax collector in accordance with the provisions of this article. The taxpayer shall include a provision in each retail shortterm lease or rental agreement stating that the percentage amount enacted by this article of the total lease or rental price, excluding sales tax, is being charged as a tax on gross receipts. The amount of the tax shall be stated separately from the lease or rental and shown separately on the taxpayer's records. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the taxpayer as trustee for, and on account of, the city. The taxpayer shall be liable for the collection of the tax and for the payment thereof to the tax collector, and the taxpayer's failure to charge or collect such tax from the customer shall not affect such liability. 
(Code 1987, § 23-93) 
Sec. 8-114. - Report and payment. 
    Taxes levied under this article are due and payable when a return is required to be filed. Every taxpayer shall, within the time specified, submit a return to the tax collector on the form prescribed by the tax collector. A return must be signed by the taxpayer or the taxpayer's agent. Returns of taxpayers are due to the tax collector each month on or before the 15th day of the month following the month in which the tax accrues. As provided in G.S. 160A-208.1, a return shall not be considered a public record and information contained in a return may be disclosed only in accordance therewith. 
(Code 1987, § 23-94) 
Sec. 8-115. - Records, books and accounts. 
    The taxpayer shall keep and preserve suitable records of the gross receipts received by such taxpayer in the conduct of business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of the tax for which such taxpayer is liable under the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the taxpayer to keep and preserve all such records of gross receipts and other books and accounts for a period of three years. All records, books and accounts described in this section shall be open for examination at all reasonable hours during the day by the tax collector or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1987, § 23-95) 
Sec. 8-116. - Provision of forms. 
    To ensure a full collection of and an accounting for taxes due, the tax collector shall design, prepare, print and make available to all taxpayers operating within the municipal boundaries of the city, forms and instructions for filing returns. The failure of any taxpayer to obtain or receive forms shall not relieve such taxpayer from the payment of the tax at the time and in the manner provided. 
(Code 1987, § 23-96) 
Sec. 8-117. - Situs. 
    The transaction giving rise to the tax levied in this article shall be deemed to have occurred at the location of the entity from which the customer takes delivery of the vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 23-97) 
Sec. 8-118. - Administration. 
    In addition to the provisions in this article, the levy and collection of the taxes imposed in this article shall be otherwise administered in the same manner as the sales and use tax provided in G.S. 105-164.1 et seq. 
(Code 1987, § 23-99) 
Sec. 8-119. - Penalties and remedies. 
    The provisions with respect to remedies and penalties applicable to G.S. 105-463 et seq., as contained in G.S. 105-164.1 et seq. and G.S. 105-228.90 et seq., shall be applicable in like manner to the tax authorized to be levied and collected under this article, to the extent that such provisions are not inconsistent with the provisions of this article. The city council may exercise any power the secretary of revenue may exercise in collecting sales and use taxes. 
(Code 1987, § 23-98) 
Chapter 10 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Cemeteries generally, G.S. ch. 65; municipal cemeteries, G.S. 65-37-65-40; authority of city as to cemeteries, G.S. 160A-341-160A-348; regulation of city cemeteries, G.S. 160A-348. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult plot means space of sufficient size to accommodate one adult interment, approximately three feet by nine feet. 
    Baby plot means a space of sufficient size to accommodate one baby interment, approximately three feet by four feet. 
    Certificate of ownership means the original conveyance given by the city to the original purchaser. 
    City cemetery means any cemetery owned, operated or controlled by the city. 
    Interment means the permanent disposition of the remains of a deceased person by cremation, entombment or burial. 
    Lot means the numbered divisions, as shown on the recorded plats, each of which consists of two or more plots. 
    Lot marker means concrete or other suitable material used by the city to locate corners of the lot. 
    Monument includes a tombstone or memorial of granite or other material which shall extend above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1987, § 6-1; Ord. No. O-2010-22, §§ 1, 2, 10-19-2010) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-2. - Burials in authorized cemeteries required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bury any human body within the city, except in the cemeteries authorized under this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-2) 
Sec. 10-3. - Use for burial of humans. 
    The cemeteries shall be used only for the burial of human bodies. 
(Code 1987, § 6-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Cemeteries located and maintained as of July 19, 1954. 
    The cemeteries or places of burial, located and maintained as of July 19, 1954, within the limits of the city, by any corporation or association for the purpose of affording burial places for the dead, and for maintaining the graves therein, are hereby expressly authorized to be used and maintained for such purpose. No expansion thereof shall be authorized or permitted and no body shall be buried therein after July 19, 1954, without the consent of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 6-4) 
Sec. 10-5. - New cemeteries. 
    No new cemetery shall be established and maintained within the limits of the city without the consent of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 6-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - General management and control. 
(a)  The city manager shall have the general management and control of the city cemeteries and of the cemetery supervisor and other persons employed therein. 
(b)  The city manager shall have charge of the grounds and buildings of the city cemeteries, as well as the conduct of funerals, traffic, employees, plot owners and visitors and, at all times, shall have supervision and control of all persons in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1987, § 6-6) 
Sec. 10-7. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may make rules and regulations, not inconsistent with state law, the Charter and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city, relative to the proper maintenance of city cemeteries and the guidance and direction of the cemetery supervisor and other persons employed therein as he may deem necessary. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations following their approval by resolution of the city council and filing thereof in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 6-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - Protection of lot owners from loss or damage; exceptions. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect lot owners and the burial rights of lot owners within the city cemeteries from loss or damage. The city disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage from causes beyond its reasonable control and especially from damage caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions, insurrections, riots or order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral, other than as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-8) 
Sec. 10-9. - Plat and plat book of lots sold and for sale. 
    The city shall keep a plat and plat book of the city cemeteries on which all lots which have been sold and which are for sale shall be shown. 
(Code 1987, § 6-9) 
Sec. 10-10. - Accounts and financial records. 
    The city manager shall cause to be kept such accounts and financial records in relation to the maintenance and operation of city cemeteries as, in his judgment, may be necessary to facilitate the efficient maintenance and operation thereof, consistent with a uniform system of accounting. 
(Code 1987, § 6-10) 
Sec. 10-11. - Collection and deposit of funds received. 
    The city shall collect all money in payment for lots and all services rendered by employees of the city cemeteries in the performance of their duties as regulated by the city council and shall deposit such funds, when collected, in the official depository of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-11) 
Sec. 10-12. - Receipt of fees by city employees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while employed by the city in connection with city cemeteries, to receive any fee, gratuity or commission, except from the city, either directly or indirectly. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be immediately dismissed from the employment of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-12) 
Sec. 10-13. - Change in address of lot owner; effect of notice sent to address on file. 
    The owners of lots in city cemeteries shall notify the management of any change in their post office address. Notice sent to a lot owner at his last address on file in the office of the cemetery shall be considered sufficient and proper legal notification, except where publication is required. 
(Code 1987, § 6-13) 
Sec. 10-14. - Memorial installation. 
(a)  Prior to any memorial installation, the cemetery supervisor shall be notified of the following information: 
(1)  Installation company and address. 
(2)  Name on marker. 
(3)  Lot and section number. 
(4)  Date and time of installation. 
(5)  Name and address of person requesting the installation. 
(b)  The following procedure shall be followed when installing any monument/marker in any city cemetery: 
(1)  Installer must obtain a monument/marker installation permit. 
(2)  When leaving the job, all grass and excess dirt must be removed and the area left clean. 
(3)  All other codes must be followed pertaining to the installation of markers. 
(4)  The cemetery supervisor, at his discretion, will notify any business installing monuments or markers, in writing, of what was not performed to city standards. The company will then have a period of five working days to correct the situation. 
(c)  An administrative fee, as set from time to time by the city council and on file in the city clerk's office, shall be paid prior to the installation of any monument or marker in a city cemetery. 
(d)  Failure to install monuments/markers to meet city requirements will result in a noncompliance fine. The fine schedule shall be kept in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 6-15) 
Sec. 10-15. - Grave liners. 
(a)  All burials on or after July 1, 1990, will be in a commercially procured grave liner or vault that has been approved by the cemetery supervisor. The minimum requirements for concrete liners shall be as follows: 
(1)  Sidewall thickness, 11/2 inches. 
(2)  Top thickness, two inches. 
(3)  Bottom thickness, two inches. 
(4)  Pounds per square inch (psi), 3,000. 
(b)  The minimum requirement for a steel vault shall be 12-gauge thickness on the top, sides and bottom. 
(c)  Wooden or other shortterm liners are not allowed. 
(d)  No liner is required for cremations. 
(Code 1987, § 6-16) 
Sec. 10-16. - Notification prior to burial; authorization and burial fee; noncompliance fine. 
(a)  Prior to any burial, the cemetery supervisor shall be notified of the following: 
(1)  Name of the deceased. 
(2)  Age, death date and burial date of the deceased. 
(3)  Name and address of the lot owner. 
(b)  An authorization for burial fee, as set by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office, shall be paid prior to the interment. 
(c)  Failure to open and close graves to meet city requirements will result in a noncompliance fine. The fine schedule and work specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 6-17) 
Sec. 10-17. - Opening and closing graves. 
    Any funeral home granted a burial permit shall be responsible for opening and closing graves in compliance with the following regulations. Failure to comply with such regulations will result in the funeral home paying a fine before any further burials are made in any city cemetery: 
(1)  Any cutting of sod shall be done in sections that are removed and placed in such a manner that they can be replaced in the same order as removed. 
(2)  Any soil removed from a grave must be put into trailers that are provided by the city. The cemetery department will remove the trailers from the grave during business hours. 
(3)  All existing markers in the vicinity of the grave must be covered, to protect them from damage, during the opening and closing of graves. 
(4)  When filling graves, the soil must be packed in six-inch layers as the grave is being filled to help keep the grave from settling. 
(5)  Grass must be replaced level with the surrounding turf. 
(6)  The area must be left in its original state with precautions taken to prevent damage. 
(7)  Funeral homes are responsible for removing grass, filling and repacking graves and replacing the grass level with surrounding turf for a period of one year from the date of the burial. 
(8)  The cemetery supervisor, at his discretion, will notify any funeral home, in writing, of work that was not performed to city standards. The funeral home will have a period of five working days to correct the situation. If such correction is not done, then a noncompliance fine will be charged. 
(Code 1987, § 6-18) 
Sec. 10-18. - Perpetual care fund. 
    A perpetual care fee, as set by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office, shall be charged and deposited into a perpetual care fund which shall be used for maintenance of city cemeteries. The fee for noncity residents shall be twice that charged city residents. 
(Code 1987, § 6-19) 
Sec. 10-19. - Violations and noncompliance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate, or fail, refuse or neglect to comply with, the provisions or requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  Failure to abide by any provision of this chapter by any funeral home or memorial company may, with written notification by the cemetery supervisor, under direction of the city manager, result in the temporary revocation of the privilege of interment or installation of memorials in any city cemetery. The city manager may permanently revoke the privilege of interment or installation of memorials for repeated failure to abide by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-14) 
Secs. 10-20-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CEMETERY SUPERVISOR 

Sec. 10-51. - Office created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of cemetery supervisor. The cemetery supervisor shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 6-31) 
Sec. 10-52. - Duplicate plat and plat book; record of funerals or burials. 
    Subject to the control and supervision of the city manager, the cemetery supervisor shall keep a duplicate plat and plat book of the city cemeteries, on which shall be shown: 
(1)  All lots which have been sold and which are for sale; 
(2)  The date of any funeral or burial; 
(3)  The name of any person interred; and 
(4)  The name and address of any funeral director who may be in charge of the funeral or burial. 
(Code 1987, § 6-32) 
Sec. 10-53. - Disposition of money received. 
    The cemetery supervisor shall pay to the city all money received by him. 
(Code 1987, § 6-33) 
Sec. 10-54. - Improvement and maintenance of walks and grounds. 
    Under the direction of the city manager, the cemetery supervisor shall plant trees and other plants in and through the grounds of city cemeteries, except on privately owned lots, and shall improve and keep the walks and grounds of city cemeteries in order. 
(Code 1987, § 6-34) 
Sec. 10-55. - Removal of floral designs, flowers, weeds and trees. 
(a)  The cemetery supervisor may remove all floral or funeral designs or decorations, flowers, weeds, plants or herbage of any kind from city cemeteries as soon as, in the judgment of the cemetery supervisor, they become unsightly, dangerous, detrimental or diseased or when they do not conform to the standard maintained. 
(b)  If any trees or shrubs situated on any lot in the city cemeteries shall, by means of their roots, branches or otherwise, become detrimental to the adjacent lots, or avenues or paths, or dangerous or inconvenient to pedestrians, such trees or shrubs may be removed by order of the cemetery supervisor. The cemetery supervisor may enter the lot and remove any trees or shrubs, or parts thereof, which are detrimental or inconvenient. 
(Code 1987, § 6-35) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 42. 
Sec. 10-56. - Removal of offensive or improper monuments, effigies, structures and inscriptions. 
    If any monument, effigy, structure or inscription is placed in or upon any lot in any city cemetery, which monument, effigy, structure or inscription shall be deemed by the cemetery supervisor to be offensive or improper, the cemetery supervisor shall notify the owner to remove the monument, effigy, structure or inscription, and if the owner fails to do so within 48 hours, the cemetery supervisor shall enter upon such lot and remove such offensive or improper monument, effigy, structure or inscription. 
(Code 1987, § 6-36) 
Sec. 10-57. - Additional duties. 
    The cemetery supervisor shall perform such duties as may be required of him by the city manager, in addition to the duties that may be imposed upon him by this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-39) 
Secs. 10-58-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVATION OF CERTAIN RIGHTS 

Sec. 10-91. - Boundaries, roads, drives and walks. 
    The city may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right to, enlarge, reduce, replat or change the boundaries or grading of the city cemeteries, or of a section thereof, not already developed from time to time, including the modification or change of the locations, or removing or regarding, of roads, drives or walks, or any parts thereof, in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-56) 
Sec. 10-92. - Pipelines and gutters. 
    The city may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right to, lay, maintain and operate, or alter or change, pipelines and gutters for sprinkling systems, drainage, etc., in the city cemeteries. 
(Code 1987, § 6-57) 
Sec. 10-93. - Passage to and from plots. 
    The city reserves to itself, and those lawfully entitled thereto, a perpetual right of ingress and egress over plots in the city cemeteries for the purpose of passage to and from other plots. 
(Code 1987, § 6-58) 
Sec. 10-94. - Right to adopt, amend and repeal rules and regulations. 
    The city council may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right at any time to, adopt new rules and regulations relative to the city cemeteries or to amend or repeal any provision of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-59) 
Sec. 10-95. - Correction of errors. 
    The city may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right to, correct any error which may be made by it, either in making any interment, disinterment or removal, or in the description, transfer or conveyance of any interment property, either by canceling such conveyance and conveying in lieu thereof other interment property of equal value and similar location insofar as may be possible, or by refunding the amount of money paid on account of the purchase of the property. 
(Code 1987, § 6-60) 
State Law reference- Procedures for disinterment and reinterment, G.S. 130A-113. 
Sec. 10-96. - Exceptions, suspensions and modifications. 
    In connection with the city cemeteries, the city council may, and it hereby expressly reserves the right to, make exceptions to, suspensions of, or modifications, without notice, in any of the provisions of this chapter when, in the judgment of the city council, such action appears advisable; however, such special exceptions, suspensions or modifications shall not be construed as affecting the general application of such rule. 
(Code 1987, § 6-61) 
Secs. 10-97-10-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INTERMENTS, DISINTERMENTS AND REMOVALS 

Sec. 10-131. - Application of general laws of the state. 
    In any city cemetery, all interments, disinterments and removals shall be subject to the general laws of the state governing such interments, disinterments and removals, in addition to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-76) 
State Law reference- Removal of graves, G.S. 65-13; notification of death, G.S. 130A-112; permits for burial transit, authorization for cremation and disinterment-reinterment, G.S. 130A-113. 
Sec. 10-132. - Determination of time, manner and charges. 
    All interments, disinterments and removals in any city cemetery shall be made at the time, in the manner and upon payment of such charges as may be determined by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 6-77) 
Sec. 10-133. - Opening of interment space under certain circumstances. 
    In any cemetery, when instructions regarding the location of an interment space in a lot cannot be obtained, or when such instructions are indefinite or, for any reason, the interment space cannot be opened where specified, the management may, in its discretion, open such interment space in such part of the lot as the cemetery supervisor may deem best under the circumstances, so as to avoid delaying the funeral. In such case, neither the city, nor any of its employees, shall be liable for any error in failing to open the interment space in the proper location. 
(Code 1987, § 6-78) 
Sec. 10-134. - City's responsibility for verbal or unclear orders. 
(a)  In any city cemetery, the city shall not be held responsible for any order given verbally, either in person or by telephone, with reference to interment space or for any mistake resulting from want of precise and proper instructions as to the particular space, size and location of an interment space in a lot where interment is desired. 
(b)  If such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in a different location, the management shall have the right to remove or transfer such interred remains to such other property of equal value and similar location as may be conveyed in lieu thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 6-79) 
Sec. 10-135. - City's liability for delayed interment. 
    Neither the city, nor any of its employees, shall be liable for any delay in the interment of a body where a protest against the interment has been made or where there has been a failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 6-80) 
Sec. 10-136. - Protests. 
    The city shall be under no duty to recognize any protests proposed of interments in any city cemetery unless such protests shall be in writing and shall have been filed in the office of the city manager or cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-81) 
Sec. 10-137. - City's liability for interment permit or identity of body. 
    In connection with any city cemetery, the city shall not be liable for the interment permit, nor the identity of any body sought to be interred or cremated. 
(Code 1987, § 6-82) 
Sec. 10-138. - City's liability for embalming. 
    In connection with any cemetery, the city shall not be liable in any way for the embalming of any body. 
(Code 1987, § 6-83) 
Sec. 10-139. - Payment of purchase price required prior to interment or placement of monument. 
    No interment shall be permitted in any lot or plot in any city cemetery, nor shall any memorial or monument be placed on such lot or plot until the purchase price of the lot or plot shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1987, § 6-84) 
Secs. 10-140-10-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONDUCT OF PERSONS 

Sec. 10-171. - Signs, notices and advertisements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, post or maintain any sign, notice or advertisement of any kind in any city cemetery; however, such requirement shall not be construed to apply to the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-102) 
Sec. 10-172. - Peddling and soliciting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle flowers or plants, or solicit the sale of any commodity in any city cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-103) 
Sec. 10-173. - Certain motor vehicles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a motorcycle, motorbike or motor scooter in any city cemetery or to bring such motorcycle, motorbike or motor scooter into any city cemetery, except when such person is in attendance at a funeral or is on business. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any other type of motor vehicle, except a passenger vehicle, hearse or flower truck, into the city cemeteries, except upon the permission of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-104) 
Sec. 10-174. - Restriction of motor vehicles and other vehicles; responsibility for damage. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle through the grounds of any city cemetery at a speed greater than 15 miles per hour, or to fail, neglect or refuse to keep such vehicle on the right-hand side of the cemetery roadway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or propel any vehicle, bicycle or baby carriage upon the lots or the lawns of any city cemetery. 
(c)  Persons driving in any city cemetery shall be responsible for any damage done by them, and the cemetery supervisor may make and collect for any such damage. 
(Code 1987, § 6-105) 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 38. 
Sec. 10-175. - Discharge of firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a law enforcement officer acting in the line of duty, to discharge any firearm on the grounds of any city cemetery, except at military funerals, upon permit from the cemetery supervisor or in the lawful defense of any person or property. 
(Code 1987, § 6-107) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit discharge of firearms, G.S. 160A-189. 
Sec. 10-176. - Shooting, hunting and ranging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot in, hunt in or range over the grounds of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-108) 
Sec. 10-177. - Children under 15 years of age. 
    It shall be unlawful for children under 15 years of age to enter or remain in any city cemetery, unless accompanied by responsible persons to take care of them. 
(Code 1987, § 6-109) 
Sec. 10-178. - Animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring, allow or permit to be brought any dog or other animal into any city cemetery, except Seeing Eye or service dogs properly trained to assist blind and other disabled persons or law enforcement animals. 
(Code 1987, § 6-110) 
Sec. 10-179. - Expulsion of certain persons. 
    Any person disturbing the quiet and good order of any city cemetery by noise, improper conduct, violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules and regulations prescribed in this chapter shall be compelled to instantly leave the cemetery grounds. 
(Code 1987, § 6-112) 
Sec. 10-180. - Entering or remaining between sunset and sunrise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain within any city cemetery during the hours between sunset and sunrise, without first securing the permission of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-113) 
Sec. 10-181. - Placing certain articles upon plots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any plot in any city cemetery any trinket, toy, shell, flower (except in approved receptacles), vase, glass jar, tin can, sand, artificial material, temporary marker after one year, cross, flag, flag pole or any other article which, in the opinion of the city manager or his designee, is unsightly or hazardous to lawn maintenance. Notwithstanding the foregoing, American flags which do not extend upward more than 24 inches and do not touch the ground may be placed on a plot for a period of two weeks (beginning one week before and ending one week after) the following holidays: Memorial Day, Independence Day (July 4), and Veterans' Day. If any article shall be placed upon any plot in violation of this section or shall remain thereon in violation of this section, the city shall have the authority to remove the article, without notice, and the city shall not be responsible for any loss or destruction thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 6-114; Ord. No. O-2008-05, § 1, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. O-2008-13, § 1, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 10-182. - Disposition of rubbish. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw rubbish on the drives and paths or on any part of the grounds of the city cemeteries. 
(Code 1987, § 6-115) 
Cross reference- Solid waste management, ch. 30. 
Secs. 10-183-10-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HILLSIDE CEMETERY AND CEDAR GROVE CEMETERY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-211. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to Hillside Cemetery and Cedar Grove Cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-126) 
Sec. 10-212. - Purchase of plot. 
    Any person may select any plot in the cemeteries, provided that no other person has obtained a certificate of ownership to the plot, and shall obtain from the city, upon payment of the cost thereof, a certificate of ownership setting forth the space purchased, location and other information. 
(Code 1987, § 6-127) 
Sec. 10-213. - Transfer of plot ownership. 
    When the owner of a plot in a cemetery desires to assign or transfer to another person the space owned by him, he shall provide to the city adequate documentation of such transfer within 30 days. The city clerk shall then issue a new certificate of ownership, executed as provided in section 10-212, to the new owner and cancel the old surrendered certificate of ownership upon payment of the currently required fee for each separate instrument. 
(Code 1987, § 6-129) 
Sec. 10-214. - Rights of purchaser. 
    A person to whom the city clerk issues a certificate of ownership to a lot in a cemetery shall be entitled to the lot, or part thereof, so paid for as a burying place for himself, any person who is a member of his family or one of his descendants or friends. 
(Code 1987, § 6-130) 
Sec. 10-215. - Ownership of lot upon purchaser's death. 
    In case of the death of a purchaser of a cemetery lot, the surviving spouse of the decedent shall be recognized as the owner of the lot, and in case of the death of the surviving spouse, the heirs at law of the purchaser shall be recognized as the owner of the lot. 
(Code 1987, § 6-131) 
Sec. 10-216. - Reversion of lot to city. 
(a)  When a lot in a cemetery shall have remained without any interment for a period of 50 years, and the purchaser or his assignee has died or has been removed from the city, and none of their relatives is known to the city council to reside in the city, the lot shall revert to the city when the conditions set forth in subsection (b) of this section have been complied with. 
(b)  The city council, intending to cause the reversion to the city of an unused lot as provided in subsection (a) of this section, shall give notice of such proposed reversion once a week for four weeks in a newspaper published in the city. If no relative of the purchaser or his assignee appears within 30 days from the last day of such publication, then such plot shall revert to the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-132) 
Sec. 10-217. - Interments for remuneration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any lot holder to allow any interment to be made in his lot for any remuneration. 
(Code 1987, § 6-133) 
Sec. 10-218. - Planting of shrubs and plants by proprietor of lot. 
    The proprietor of a lot in a cemetery may be permitted to plant and cultivate shrubs and plants on the lot under the supervision, and with the consent, of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-134) 
Sec. 10-219. - Cut flower receptacles. 
    Permanent receptacles for cut flowers in the cemeteries shall be of metal or stone and shall be sunk below the surface of the ground in such a manner as not to interfere with the mower. Receptacles placed so as to interfere with the mower shall be removed at once. Receptacles shall not be unsightly when not filled. 
(Code 1987, § 6-135) 
Sec. 10-220. - Keeping on walks and roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person visiting any cemetery to fail, neglect or refuse to keep on the walks or roadways in such cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-136) 
Sec. 10-221. - Boundary markers. 
    All cemetery boundary markers set by the city shall be permanent land markers. It shall be unlawful for any person to move such boundary markers without proper authority. 
(Code 1987, § 6-137) 
Secs. 10-222-10-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION, BUILDING AND REPAIR 

Sec. 10-241. - Work by masons and stone cutters. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply to the work of masons and stone cutters in the cemeteries: 
(1)  Materials shall not be brought onto the grounds in large quantities in advance of their immediate use or in an unprepared condition. 
(2)  Blocks of stone or marble must be dressed to the design and dimensions ready for setting. 
(3)  Lime must be slacked and mortar prepared and brought to the grounds in moderate supply. 
(Code 1987, § 6-151) 
Sec. 10-242. - Supervision of masons and stone cutters. 
    Masons and stone cutters working in the cemeteries shall at all times be under the supervision of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-152) 
Sec. 10-243. - Erection of stonework. 
    In the cemeteries, the erection of stonework shall be subject to the rules and regulations covering the particular cemetery section. Lot holders and contractors shall be furnished full information, upon request. 
(Code 1987, § 6-153) 
Sec. 10-244. - Placing of enclosures and curbing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any enclosure or curbing around any lot, or part thereof, in any section in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1987, § 6-154) 
Sec. 10-245. - Erection and construction of steps. 
    Each step erected upon any lot in the cemeteries shall be made of a single stone, and shall be constructed on a solid foundation of masonry. 
(Code 1987, § 6-155) 
Sec. 10-246. - Laying of cradle tombs and slabs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lay cradle tombs or slabs in the cemeteries unless such cradle tombs or slabs are laid horizontally. 
(Code 1987, § 6-156) 
Sec. 10-247. - Bringing in stone and other material. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring stone or any other material into the cemeteries when the grounds thereof are not in suitable condition. 
(Code 1987, § 6-157) 
Sec. 10-248. - Loads over eight tons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring a load of more than eight tons into the grounds of the cemeteries without having first obtained permission from the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-158) 
Sec. 10-249. - Fastening of guy ropes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fasten guy ropes to any tree, monument or tomb in the cemeteries. 
(Code 1987, § 6-159) 
Sec. 10-250. - Moving of material. 
    In the cemeteries, all material shall be moved in the paths, over planks laid for such purpose, and not over the adjoining lots. 
(Code 1987, § 6-160) 
Sec. 10-251. - Dilapidated enclosures. 
(a)  When any enclosure in the cemeteries is found to be in a dilapidated condition, either from decay or want of paint, so that it becomes unsightly or a nuisance, the owner of any such enclosure shall be notified by the cemetery supervisor that if the enclosure is not put in good condition within ten days after such notice, it shall be removed by the cemetery supervisor. Such a removed enclosure shall not be replaced by any other enclosure. 
(b)  When the owner of the dilapidated enclosure is unknown or is not a resident of the city, the city council, intending to cause the removal or repair of a dilapidated enclosure as provided in subsection (a) of this section, shall give notice of such proposed removal or repair once a week for four weeks in a newspaper published in the city. If the owner does not appear within 30 days from the last day of such publication, the enclosure shall be removed by the cemetery supervisor. Such a removed enclosure shall not be replaced by any other enclosure. 
(Code 1987, § 6-161) 
Sec. 10-252. - Vaults. 
    The city manager may allow a vault to be built by the purchaser of a lot in the cemeteries. The city manager shall establish specifications which shall be observed by the owner in the construction of such vault. 
(Code 1987, § 6-162) 
Sec. 10-253. - Failure to comply with rules and regulations. 
    The cemetery supervisor may immediately suspend work whenever there is a failure to conform to the applicable rules and regulations. 
(Code 1987, § 6-163) 
Sec. 10-254. - Repair of damage; responsibility for failure to comply with rules and regulations. 
(a)  If any damage is done by any person working in the cemeteries, such damage will be repaired under the direction of the cemetery supervisor and shall be paid for by the person responsible for such damage. 
(b)  Any workman failing to conform to the applicable rules and regulations shall be excluded from the cemeteries and the person employing him shall be responsible for the injuries sustained through such workman's neglect. 
(Code 1987, § 6-164) 
Sec. 10-255. - Removal of rubbish and excavated earth. 
    Persons employed by lot owners to work on lots in the cemeteries shall remove all rubbish and excavated earth produced in the course of their work to dumps designated by the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-165) 
Sec. 10-256. - Unauthorized work on Sundays. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to work in the cemeteries on Sundays. 
(Code 1987, § 6-166) 
Secs. 10-257-10-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - HILLSIDE MEMORIAL PARK 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-291. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Memorial means a monument, marker, tablet, headstone, private mausoleum or tomb for family or individual use, tombstone, coping, lot enclosure, surface burial vault, urn and crypt, and niche plates. 
    Owner's declaration of reservation means the document executed by the owner in the presence of the management, designating and specifying the person entitled to burial in the lot or plot for which a certificate of ownership is held. 
(Code 1987, § 6-181) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-292. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to Hillside Memorial Park. Such cemetery shall be operated under the provisions of this article, subject to the General Statutes. 
(Code 1987, § 6-182) 
Sec. 10-293. - Establishment and name. 
    That certain tract of land containing 22.7 acres, more or less, located on the east side of the 401 Bypass and on the west side of the Laurinburg and Southern Railroad, which was purchased by the city from Giles Leach and his sister, Cora M. Leach, by a deed dated January 10, 1956, which is registered in the county registry in deed book 2-0, page 680, shall be used exclusively as a municipal cemetery to be operated by the city under the name of Hillside Memorial Park. 
(Code 1987, § 6-183) 
Sec. 10-294. - Plat and record. 
    The city shall keep a plat and record of the cemetery, showing sections, lots and subdivisions, together with the location and date of all burials and the name of each person interred therein. 
(Code 1987, § 6-184) 
Sec. 10-295. - Lot prices and other charges. 
    The prices of all lots in the cemetery and the charges for opening graves and for other work carried on in the cemetery, not specified in this article, shall be as fixed by the city council from time to time and maintained on file in the office of the city clerk. A true copy of such charges shall also be maintained on file in the office of the cemetery supervisor. 
(Code 1987, § 6-185) 
Sec. 10-296. - Reservation of city's right to use property not conveyed. 
    The city reserves the right to use, for cemetery purposes, the cemetery property which has been plotted and recorded in the office of the register of deeds of the county, not sold to individual lots owners, including the interring and preparing for interment of human bodies or for anything necessary, incidental or convenient thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 6-186) 
Sec. 10-297. - Composition of agreement between city and lot or plot owner. 
    The certificate of ownership, declaration of reservation, option agreement, if any, and provisions of this article and any amendment thereto constitute the entire agreement between the city and the owner of any lot or plot in the cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-187) 
Sec. 10-298. - Work to be done by city. 
    In the cemetery, the city shall undertake and perform the following work: 
(1)  All grading, landscaping and improvements of any kind. 
(2)  All care of plots. 
(3)  All planting, trimming, cutting and removal of trees, shrubs and herbage. 
(Code 1987, § 6-188) 
Sec. 10-299. - Authority of city manager for improvements and alterations. 
    All improvements or alterations of lots or plots in the cemetery shall be under the direction, and subject to the consent, satisfaction and approval, of the city manager. Should such improvements or alterations be made without the written consent of the city manager, he may remove, alter or change such improvements or alterations at the expense of the plot owner or if, at any time when, in his judgment, such improvements or alterations become unsightly. 
(Code 1987, § 6-189) 
Sec. 10-300. - Motor vehicles required to stop at entrance. 
    The city reserves the right to compel all persons driving motor vehicles into the cemetery to bring such vehicles to a full stop at the entrance to such cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-190) 
Sec. 10-301. - Use of avenues, walks, alleys and roads; liability for injuries. 
    Persons within the cemetery shall use only the avenues, walks, alleys and roads. Any person injured in the cemetery while walking on the grass or any portion of the cemetery, other than the avenues, walks, alley or roads, shall in no way hold the city liable for any injuries sustained. 
(Code 1987, § 6-191) 
Sec. 10-302. - Trespassers on plots. 
    Only the plot owner and his relatives shall be permitted on any plot in the cemetery. Any other person on such plot shall be considered a trespasser. The city shall owe no duty to any such trespasser to keep the property or memorial on such plot in a reasonably safe condition. 
(Code 1987, § 6-192) 
Secs. 10-303-10-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INTERMENTS, DISINTERMENTS AND REMOVALS 

Sec. 10-321. - Application for interment or opening of burial space. 
    In the absence of the owner's declaration of reservation, the cemetery supervisor may refuse interment in any plot and refuse to allow the opening of any burial space for any purpose, except upon written application by the plot owner of record, made out on forms provided by the management and duly filed in the office of the management. 
(Code 1987, § 6-206) 
Sec. 10-322. - Interment of more than one body in single grave or vault. 
    Not more than one body or the remains of more than one body shall be interred in a single grave or vault, except in the case of a mother and her newborn baby, unless such grave or vault has been purchased in the written agreement that more than one body or the remains of more than one body may be interred therein, or unless the cemetery supervisor shall have given its written consent thereto. Interment shall not be permitted unless proper identification shall be made of such interment on one regulation memorial or marker. 
(Code 1987, § 6-207) 
Sec. 10-323. - Interment in lot owned by church, lodge or other society. 
    Where a lot is owned by a church, lodge or other society, interment shall be limited to the actual members of the organization and their husbands, wives and immediate family members, unless otherwise provided in the certificate of ownership. 
(Code 1987, § 6-208) 
Sec. 10-324. - Removal of body for sale of plot or lot for profit. 
    It shall be unlawful for the heirs of the original owner of the lot or plot to remove a body from such plot or lot so that such lot or plot may be sold for profit. 
(Code 1987, § 6-209) 
Sec. 10-325. - Removal of body to different lot or plot. 
    A body, or the remains thereof, may be removed from the original lot or plot in which it was originally buried to a different lot or plot in the cemetery when there has been an exchange or purchase for such purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 6-210) 
Secs. 10-326-10-350. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SALE OF LOTS 

Sec. 10-351. - Price of lots. 
(a)  All lots in Hillside Memorial Park are to be offered for sale at prices set by the city council from time to time which fees shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  The sales price per lot in Hillside Memorial Park to nonresidents of the city shall be twice the sales price that is in effect for the residents of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-227) 
Sec. 10-352. - Installment payments. 
    The purchase price of any of the lots in the cemetery may be paid in installments. In such case, the purchaser shall execute a signed contract, in a form to be approved by the city manager, which shall provide the following: 
(1)  Payment shall be made in weekly, semimonthly or monthly installments. 
(2)  The maximum length of the time allowed for the payment of the total purchase price shall not exceed 24 months. 
(3)  A cash payment upon each lot shall be made by the purchaser at the time of the execution of the contract. The payment shall, in no event, be less than the minimum cash payment for a lot of that classification, to be determined by the city manager. 
(4)  Each installment shall be paid on or before the date provided for such payment in the written contract to purchase. If any payment shall not be made on or before the date when the payment shall be due, a service charge, the amount of which shall be set by the city council from time to time and kept on file in the city clerk's office, shall be added to such payment for each and every month, or fraction thereof, that the payment may be delinquent. If any payment shall be past due and unpaid for as long as 90 days, the city manager may, at his option, declare the contract to have been breached by the purchaser, and may apply all payments previously made as liquidated damages for the breach of such contract, provided that: 
a.  If the contract covered a four-grave lot, and 30 percent of the base price thereof shall have been paid, a certificate of ownership shall then be issued for a one-grave lot, but the location thereof may be changed to another location of the same classification in the sole discretion of the city manager; 
b.  If the contract covered a four-grave lot, and 60 percent of the base price shall have been paid, a certificate of ownership shall then be issued for a two-grave lot, but the location thereof may be changed to another location of the same classification in the sole discretion of the city manager; and 
c.  If the contract covered a two-grave lot, and 60 percent of the base price shall have been paid, a certificate of ownership shall then be issued for a one-grave lot, but the location thereof may be changed to another location of the same classification in the sole discretion of the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 6-228) 
Secs. 10-353-10-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BURIAL RIGHTS OF LOT AND PLOT OWNERS 

Sec. 10-371. - Certificate of ownership. 
    Upon receipt of payment in full for any lot, the city clerk shall execute and deliver a certificate of ownership to the purchaser, granting to such purchaser and his heirs and assigns the exclusive right of interment in such lot, subject to the rules and regulations contained in this article and any amendments thereto which may be made by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 6-241) 
Sec. 10-372. - Right of interment when owner files declaration of reservation. 
    At the time of the purchase of a lot or plot, or at any time after such purchase during the lifetime of the purchaser or transferee, and in accordance with the provisions of this article, the owner of any such lot or plot may present his certificate of ownership, and may file with city offices a declaration of reservation, specifically designating the persons entitled to be buried in any or all of the plots in the lot, or vesting the right of designation for unreserved plots in a named person. No other person may be buried in any plot designated by the owner in the declaration of reservation, except by an amended declaration of reservation executed by the owner and filed with city offices. The owner of any lot may, in the declaration of reservation, limit the persons entitled to be buried in such lot to the persons designated in the declaration of reservation. If the owner fails to designate burial rights for each plot in such lot, or shall fail to limit burials in such plot to the persons designated in the declaration of reservation, then, as to the plots not designated, the right of burial shall be as provided in section 10-373. Upon application by any person for interment of a body in a given plot, the burden of proof as to the identity of the person to be interred rests upon the applicant and no liability shall be incurred by the city as the result of a false statement in the application, but the cemetery supervisor will make reasonable effort to see that only persons entitled to be buried in a given plot are so interred. 
(Code 1987, § 6-242) 
Sec. 10-373. - Rights of interment in absence of declaration of reservation. 
    In the absence of a declaration of reservation by the registered owner of a lot, the right of interment shall be in the following order: 
(1)  One plot shall be reserved for the owner and one for the owner's surviving spouse, if any. 
(2)  The remaining plots in such lot shall be held in trust by the city for burial of the following persons in the order of their death and if a request is made for burial: 
a.  The children of the owner and their respective spouses; 
b.  Lineal descendants of the owner and their respective spouses; 
c.  Parents of the owner. 
(Code 1987, § 6-243) 
Sec. 10-374. - Vested rights of lot owners and their spouses. 
    The burial rights in all lots and plots conveyed shall be presumed to be the sole and separate property of the person named as grantee in the certificate of ownership, in accordance with the provisions of this division, provided that the spouse shall have a vested right of interment of his body in any burial plot conveyed to the plot owner which shall continue as long as he shall remain the spouse of the plot owner or shall be his spouse at the time of such plot owner's demise. No conveyance or transfer shall divest the spouse of an owner of his vested right of interment with the joinder in such conveyance or transfers executed by the spouse and filed with city offices. 
(Code 1987, § 6-244) 
Sec. 10-375. - Indivisibility of lots; alienation of lot in which certain interments have been made. 
    All lots, the use of which has been conveyed in a certificate of ownership, are indivisible. Whenever an interment of the remains of a member, a relative of a member of the family of the record owner or the record owner is made in a lot, the lot thereby becomes inalienable, and shall be held as the family plot of the owner, except as otherwise provided by the owner's declaration of reservation. 
(Code 1987, § 6-245) 
Secs. 10-376-10-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TRANSFERS OR ASSIGNMENTS 

Sec. 10-401. - Restricted. 
(a)  The ownership of any lot, plot, section or burial space in Hillside Memorial Park shall neither be assigned, nor transferred to any person, except the city. Upon such transfer, the city shall refund to the owner of the certificate of ownership the amount of the purchase price originally paid for the property, less the sum paid for any burial space which has already been used for the burial of the dead. 
(b)  The substance of this section shall be placed in every certificate of ownership issued by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-261) 
Sec. 10-402. - Options to purchase. 
    The city will refuse to consent to a transfer of any option to purchase a lot or plot when a balance of the purchase price is still owed to the city. 
(Code 1987, § 6-262) 
Sec. 10-403. - Transfer charge. 
    All transfers of ownership in lots or plots in the cemetery shall be subject to a charge which shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such charges is on file and available in the city clerk's office. The charge shall be paid to the city when the transfer is recorded. 
(Code 1987, § 6-263) 
Sec. 10-404. - Passage of lot or plot by will or laws of descent. 
    No lot or plot in the cemetery may be bequeathed or devised by will like other property or real estate, nor shall any such lot or plot descend according to the laws of descent and distribution. 
(Code 1987, § 6-264) 
Secs. 10-405-10-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DECORATION OF PLOTS 

Sec. 10-421. - Right to regulate. 
    The city council reserves the right to regulate the method of decorating plots so that a uniform beauty may be maintained. 
(Code 1987, § 6-276) 
Sec. 10-422. - Flower receptacles. 
(a)  Fountain, Myrtle and Rose sections. Only one approved flower receptacle may be placed on any plot. Receptacles shall be placed so as to not interfere with mowing equipment. Unapproved or misplaced receptacles may be removed by the city, without notice, and the city shall not be responsible for any loss or destruction thereof. 
(b)  Estate section. Only vases that are attached on the base of the headstone, or arrangements that are made to attach to the top of the headstones shall be permitted in the Estate section. 
(Code 1987, § 6-277; Ord. No. O-2008-05, § 2, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 10-423. - Responsibility for floral pieces and containers. 
    The city shall not be responsible for floral pieces, baskets or frames in or to which such floral pieces are attached, beyond the acceptance of such floral pieces for funeral services held in the cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-278) 
Sec. 10-424. - Responsibility for plants. 
    The city shall not be responsible for frozen plants or herbage of any kind or for plantings damaged by the elements, thieves, vandals or other causes beyond the control of the management. 
(Code 1987, § 6-279) 
Sec. 10-425. - Removal of flowers, floral designs and plants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove flowers, floral designs, trees, shrubs, plants or herbage of any kind unless the cemetery supervisor gives his consent for such removal. 
(Code 1987, § 6-280) 
Secs. 10-426-10-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - MEMORIAL WORK 

Sec. 10-451. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all memorial work in the cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-296) 
Sec. 10-452. - Erection of monuments and stones. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any monument or stone of any kind in the cemetery, except in the Estate section. 
(Code 1987, § 6-297) 
Sec. 10-453. - Erection of enclosures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any enclosure in the cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-298) 
Sec. 10-454. - Use and placement of markers. 
(a)  Fountain, Myrtle and Rose sections. Only first-class bronze, granite or marble markers shall be allowed. Such markers shall be set level with the ground at the head of each plot, except in the case of a family marker, which shall be set at the head and center of the plot. 
(b)  Estate section. 
(1)  Only first quality granite or natural cut stone monuments will be permitted in the Estate section. 
(2)  All monuments shall be set on uniform lines, as prescribed by the cemetery supervisor, to conform to the general plan of the Estate section. 
(Code 1987, § 6-299; Ord. No. O-2008-05, § 3, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 10-455. - Monument specifications. 
(a)  The length of a monument base shall not exceed 60 percent of the width of the lot. 
(b)  Foundation requirements are as follows: 
(1)  All foundations shall extend five inches from the monument base and shall be dug to the proper depth. 
(2)  After the foundation is dug, the soil must be thoroughly compacted. 
(3)  Concrete mixture for the foundation shall be one part cement, two parts sand and two parts stone. 
(4)  Monuments weighing 300-3,500 pounds shall have a minimum foundation depth of six inches or manufacturer's specifications, whichever is greater. Wet concrete must cure for a period of three days prior to installation of the monument. 
(5)  Monuments weighing less than 300 pounds and footstones shall have a minimum foundation depth of four inches of wet concrete or six inches of dry concrete. 
(6)  Monuments exceeding 3,500 pounds shall be installed by the manufacturer's recommendation. Prior to installation, the installer shall submit an installation proposal for approval. 
(7)  For a period of two years from the date of installation, it shall be the responsibility of the installer to correct any settlement, leaning or other problems resulting from installation of monuments. 
(Code 1987, § 6-300) 
Sec. 10-456. - Bronze marker specifications. 
    Bronze markers intended for placement in the cemetery shall comply with the following specifications: 
(1)  Sizes and dimensions . Sizes and dimensions shall be as follows: 
a.  Outside dimensions, including flange: 
1.  Family memorials. 
i.  Width: Not less than 13 inches, nor more than 24 inches. 
ii.  Length: Not less than 42 inches, nor more than 60 inches. 
2.  Individual markers. 
i.  Width: Not less than 12 inches, nor more than 18 inches. 
ii.  Length: 24 inches. 
3.  Baby memorials. 
i.  Width: Not less than six inches, nor more than ten inches. 
ii.  Length: Not less than 12 inches, nor more than 20 inches. 
b.  Sloping flange: 
1.  Width: Two inches for both large and small markers. 
2.  Height of flange edges: Not less than three-eighths inch. 
3.  Thickness of metal: Not less than three-sixteenths inch. 
(2)  Attachment bolts. Attachment bolt requirements shall be as follows: 
a.  Six bronze attachment bolts shall be provided on the back face of each marker. 
b.  A diameter of not less than five-sixteenths inch. 
c.  Exposed length of not less than three inches. 
d.  Deformation for concrete setting shall be required. 
e.  Bolts may be cast integrally or attached by a screw, with threading of not less than three-eighths inch, in case lugs are on the back face of the casting. 
(3)  Materials. Material requirements shall be as follows: 
a.  The standard of quality shall be in accordance with Bulletin No. 172-A of the U.S. Bureau of Standards for statuary bronze. 
b.  The proportion of materials shall be 88 percent copper, ten percent tin and two percent zinc. A variation, not exceeding three percent, is permissible on each of such materials, provided, a minimum of two percent zinc must be used. 
c.  All virgin metals must be used and mixed to a uniform alloy at proper temperature. 
d.  No other alloys of metals or combinations of materials shall be acceptable. 
(4)  Craftsmanship. Craftsmanship requirements shall be as follows: 
a.  Markers shall be free from sand holes, pits or other imperfections which mar the appearance, or impair the usefulness and stability, of the finished markers. 
b.  All ornaments shall be clean and sharp, and all edges true and accurate to the standard dimensions set out in this section. 
(5)  Lettering. Lettering requirements shall be as follows: 
a.  Careful spacing and accurate setting in line, both vertically and horizontally, shall be required. 
b.  Names, dates, inscriptions and emblems shall be arranged so as to result in an artistic and neat appearing plate. 
c.  Style of lettering shall be preferably round-faced classic, V-shaped classic or flat-faced classic, but other styles of lettering may be used, subject to approval by the cemetery supervisor. 
(6)  Finish. Finish requirements shall be as follows: 
a.  Castings shall be free from scale, sand, pinholes and pits. 
b.  All ornamentation, face of letters and background shall be hand-chased, hand-tooled and burnished appropriately for a memorial tablet. 
c.  Matching of the approved color and texture, as per the sample marker, shall be done by an approved oxidizing process. 
d.  No colored lacquer or lacquer-carrying pigment shall be used. 
(Code 1987, § 6-301) 
Sec. 10-457. - Removal of noncompliant markers and monuments. 
    Any marker or monument not complying with the provisions of this division shall be removed. 
(Code 1987, § 6-302) 
Sec. 10-458. - Bronze memorial vases. 
    Approved bronze memorial vases may be substituted for any individual or baby bronze marker. 
(Code 1987, § 6-304) 
Sec. 10-459. - Use of metal other than standard bronze. 
    No metal other than standard bronze as prescribed by this division will be permitted in any lot in the cemetery. 
(Code 1987, § 6-305) 
Sec. 10-460. - Granite and marble marker specifications. 
    Granite and marble markers intended for placement in the cemetery shall comply with the following specifications: 
    Sizes and dimensions. Sizes and dimensions shall be as follows: 
(1)  Family memorials. 
a.  Width: Not less than 16 inches, nor more than 18 inches. 
b.  Length: Not less than 48 inches, nor more than 60 inches. 
c.  Thickness: Four inches or greater. 
(2)  Individual markers. 
a.  Width: Not less than 16 inches, nor more than 18 inches. 
b.  Length: Not less than 24 inches nor more than 26 inches. 
c.  Thickness: Four inches or greater. (This does not apply to military markers.) 
(3)  Baby memorials. 
a.  Width: Not less than 12 inches, nor more than 18 inches. 
b.  Length: Not less than 20 inches, nor more than 26 inches. 
c.  Thickness: Four inches or greater. 
(Ord. No. O-2008-05, § 4, 4-1-2008) 
Chapter 12 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 18; law enforcement, ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Power of municipality to enact ordinances dealing with states of emergency, G.S. 14-288.12; riots and civil disorders, G.S. 14-288.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STATE OF EMERGENCY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, adopted Feb. 19, 2019, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 12-31-12-37, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1987, §§ 9-1-9-7. 

Sec. 12-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    State of emergency means whenever, during times of great public crisis, disaster, riot, catastrophe of similar public emergency, for any reason, municipal public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety or property.
