    Emergency means an occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or man-made accidental, military, paramilitary, terrorism, weather-related, public health, explosion-related, riot-related cause, or technological failure or accident, including, but not limited to, a cyber incident, an explosion, a transportation accident, a radiological accident, or a chemical or other hazardous material incident. 
    State of emergency means a finding and declaration by any of the following authorities that an emergency exists: 
a.  The governor, acting under the authority of G.S. 166A-19.20. 
b.  The general assembly, acting under the authority of G.S. 166A-19.20. 
c.  The governing body of a municipality or the mayor of a municipality, acting under the authority of G.S. 166A-19.22. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-32. - Authority of mayor to declare a state of emergency. 
(a)  In the event of an emergency, the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of a state of emergency. 
(b)  In the event the mayor is absent or for any reason unable to perform his duties, then the mayor pro tem may declare a state of emergency and exercise all powers given to the mayor by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 12-33. - Restrictions authorized. 
    During a state of emergency, the mayor may impose any or all of the following restrictions: 
(1)  A curfew in order to more effective protect the lives, safety and property of the people within the jurisdiction of the city. The mayor can limit the curfew to areas specifically designated and described within the corporate limits of the city and to specific hours of the day or night, and to exempt from the curfew police officers, firefighters, doctors, nurses and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to the safety, health and welfare needs of the people within the city. 
(2)  Prohibit or regulate the possession, transportation, sale, purchase, storage and use of gasoline and dangerous weapons and substances, except that this subsection does not authorize prohibitions or restrictions on lawfully possessed firearms or ammunition. As used in this subsection, the term "dangerous weapons and substances" has the same meaning as it does under G.S. 14-288.1. As used in this subsection, the term "firearm" has the same meaning as it does under G.S. 14-409.39(2). 
(3)  Prohibit or regulate the buying or selling of beer, wine or intoxicating beverages of any kind and their possession or consumption off one's own premises. 
(4)  Prohibit or regulate travel upon any public street or roadway or upon any other public property, except by persons in search of medical assistance, food or other commodity or service necessary to sustain the well-being of themselves or their families, or some member thereof. 
(5)  Prohibit or restrict movements of people in public places. 
(6)  Prohibit or regulate the participation in or carrying on of any business activity and prohibit or regulate the keeping open of places of business, entertainment and public assembly. 
(7)  Prohibit or restrict the operation of offices, business establishments and other places to or from which people may travel or at which they may congregate. 
(8)  Prohibit or restrict other activities or conditions specifically mentioned in the state of emergency declaration, the control of which may be reasonably necessary to maintain order and protect the lives or property during the state of emergency. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 12-34. - Authority of mayor to request state policy and military forces and proclamation of martial law. 
    If, in the sound discretion of the mayor, it shall appear that the emergency is, or that the threatened emergency is likely to be, of such proportions that the means available to the city to maintain law and order are insufficient for such purpose, then the mayor shall promptly, and by the most expeditious means of communication, inform the governor of the situation and request that such necessary police or military forces of the state be provided promptly. If during an actual state of emergency, the mayor shall find that the civil courts having jurisdiction within the city are unable to perform their lawful duties and that, by reason of widespread lawlessness, writs and other processes cannot be served or executed in the city, then the mayor shall inform the governor of his findings and may recommend to the governor that a state of martial law be proclaimed to exist within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 12-35. - Termination. 
    A state of emergency declared pursuant to this article shall remain in effect until terminated by the mayor or other authorized official. Restrictions or prohibitions imposed under a state of emergency declaration may be modified or rescinded by amendment to the state of emergency declaration. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 12-36. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article, and any person who violates any provision of a state of emergency by the mayor or mayor pro tem under the authority of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-05, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Chapter 14 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Municipal elections, G.S. 163-279 et seq. 

Sec. 14-1. - General elections laws; conflicts of law. 
    All matters not specifically covered with reference to elections and registration of voters within the city by the terms of this chapter shall be subject to the general election laws contained in G.S. ch. 163, and all sections of this chapter which may be in conflict with any portion of the enacted general laws shall be deemed amended to conform to the general election laws of the state. 
(Code 1987, § 7-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - County board of elections to conduct city elections; reimbursement of costs. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.S. 163-285, beginning with city elections to be held in 1999, the city will contract with the county board of elections to conduct its elections. 
(b)  The city will reimburse the county board of elections for all costs incurred in connection with the city's elections. 
(Code 1987, § 7-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Election and terms of mayor and councilmembers. 
    The election and terms of the mayor and councilmembers shall be in accordance with article III of the Charter. 
(Code 1987, § 7-3) 
State Law reference- Results of elections determined by plurality, G.S. 163-292. 
Sec. 14-4. - Special elections. 
    In addition to the regular elections for the election of city officials, the city council shall have the authority to call such special elections as may be permitted by law. 
(Code 1987, § 7-6) 
State law reference- Special elections; procedure for calling, G.S. 163-287. 
Sec. 14-5. - Qualification for candidacy. 
    Only persons who are registered to vote in the city shall be permitted to file notice of candidacy for election to municipal office. A candidate for the office of councilmember must reside and be registered to vote in the district which he desires to represent in order to file as a candidate for that district. Candidates for the at-large council seat and candidates for mayor may reside in either district. 
(Code 1987, § 7-7) 
Sec. 14-6. - Filing of notice of candidacy. 
    Beginning with city elections conducted in the year 1999, each person offering themselves as a candidate for election to any city office shall do so by filing a notice of candidacy with the county board of elections. 
(Code 1987, § 7-8) 
State Law reference- Notice of candidacy, G.S. 163-294.2(a). 
Sec. 14-7. - Signing of notice of candidacy. 
    The notice of candidacy shall be either signed in the presence of the chairperson or secretary of the board of elections, or signed and acknowledged before an officer authorized to take acknowledgments, who shall certify the notice under seal. An acknowledged and certified notice may be mailed to the board of elections. The candidate shall sign the notice of candidacy with his legal name and, in his discretion, any nickname by which he is commonly known, in the form that he wishes it to appear upon the ballot. 
(Code 1987, § 7-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 163-294(a). 
Sec. 14-8. - Period for filing notices of candidacy. 
    All candidates for mayor and city council shall file notice of candidacy in accordance with the provisions of Article 24 of Chapter 163 of the General Statutes of North Carolina entitled "Conduct of Municipal Elections". 
(Code 1987, § 7-10; Ord. No. O-2007-09, § 1, 5-22-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 163-294.2(c). 
Sec. 14-9. - Filing fees. 
    Pursuant to G.S. 163-295.2(e), the filing fee for the primary or election shall be fixed by the city council not later than the day before candidates are permitted to begin filing notices of candidacy. There shall be a minimum filing fee of $5.00. The city council shall have the authority to set the filing fee at not less than $5.00, nor more than one percent of the annual salary of the office sought unless one percent of the annual salary of the office sought is less than $5.00, in which case, the minimum filing fee of $5.00 will be charged. The fee shall be paid to the county board of elections at the time notice of candidacy is filed. 
(Code 1987, § 7-11) 
State Law reference- Basis for filing fee, G.S. § 163-294.2(e). 
Sec. 14-10. - Withdrawal of candidacy. 
    Any person may withdraw his notice of candidacy at any time prior to the filing deadline prescribed in this chapter, and shall be entitled to a refund of his filing fee if he does withdraw. 
(Code 1987, § 7-12) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, G.S. 163-294.2(d). 
Chapter 16 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 4; rabies control, § 4-101 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; unsafe buildings, § 6-141 et seq.; solid waste management, ch. 30; disposal of hazardous materials, § 30-8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; utilities, ch. 40; vegetation, ch. 42; unified land development ordinances, app. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Animals creating and maintaining nuisances, § 4-6. 
State Law reference- Authority to abate public health nuisances within city limits and one mile beyond, G.S. 160A-193. 

Sec. 16-31. - Enumerated. 
    The existence of any of the following conditions on any lot or parcel of land, whether improved or unimproved, occupied or unoccupied, within the city limits or within a distance of one mile beyond the city limits, is hereby declared to be dangerous and prejudicial to the public health or safety and to constitute a public nuisance: 
(1)  The uncontrolled growth of noxious weeds or grass, not grown for agricultural purposes, to a height in excess of 12 inches on the average, causing, or threatening to cause, a hazard detrimental to the public health or safety. It shall also be the duty of the owner to cut and remove all weeds and other rank vegetation as often as necessary so as to comply with this subsection. This subsection does not apply to lots exceeding one acre in size or to lots which are covered with trees. However, lots exceeding one acre or lots covered with trees shall be maintained in accordance with this subsection to a depth of ten feet from the property lines, if and only if the adjacent property is occupied by a dwelling or other structure located within 50 feet of the property; 
(2)  Any accumulation, including burial, of animal or vegetable matter that is offensive by virtue of odors or vapors or by the inhabitance therein of rats, mice, snakes or vermin of any kind which is or may be dangerous or prejudicial to the public health; 
(3)  Any accumulation of rubbish, trash or junk causing, or threatening to cause, a fire hazard, the accumulation of stagnant water or the inhabitation therein of rats, mice, snakes or vermin of any kind which is or may be dangerous or prejudicial to the public health; 
(4)  Any ditches, drains or culverts which are not kept properly clean from June 1 until November 1 of each year; 
(5)  Any sinkhole whereby unclean or stagnant water may stand or be conveyed into the streets or alleys, or keeping, or permitting to be kept, any bucket, can, barrel or any other receptacle whereby unclean or stagnant water may accumulate or stand; 
(6)  Operating a junkyard, or dismantling secondhand automobiles for the purpose of salvaging and selling the parts thereof, or storing unserviceable automobiles, or parts thereof, in areas on the outside of buildings or on open lots; 
(7)  Any condition detrimental to the public health, which violates the rules and regulations of the county health department. 
(8)  Any condition which results from the failure by any owner, occupant or other person in control of any building or land in the city, including vacant property, to keep such building or land in a clean and orderly condition. 
(9)  The use of carports, open porches, decks, open garages or other outdoor areas that are visible to streets or other public areas as a storage or collection place for boxes, appliances, discarded wood, furniture (including upholstered sofas, couches, chairs or other indoor type furniture, seats removed from motor vehicles or other furniture not intended for outdoor use by the manufacturer but not including typical outdoor or yard furniture that is wood, metal or plastic or that contains weather resistant cushions), tools, equipment, junk, garbage, broken or discarded machinery and equipment, cans, containers, cardboard, household goods or any similar condition that increases the likelihood of fire, may conceal dangerous conditions, may be a breeding place or habitat for mice, rats or other pests or create an unattractive condition or visually blighted property. 
(10)  In the city's Central Business District only (as defined in section 32-11), all commercial buildings that contain broken, cracked, missing or boarded up windows, doors, or storefronts. 
(11)  In the city's Central Business District only (as defined in section 32-11), all commercial buildings that are unsecured such as to permit public entry into the building during non-business hours. 
(12)  In the city's Central Business District only (as defined in section 32-11), all commercial buildings that show "evidence of vacancy" which is defined as any aesthetic condition that on its own or combined with other conditions present would lead a reasonable person to conclude that the building is vacant. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, overgrown or dead vegetation, exterior walls in poor condition, the absence of window coverings such as curtains, blinds or shutters at street level and the absence of furnishings or personal items consistent with commercial habitation visible from the street. 
(Code 1987, § 14-1; Ord. No. O-2007-10, § 1, 5-22-2007; Ord. No. O-2010-14, § 1, 7-20-2010; Ord. No. O-2019-04, § 1, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 16-32. - Enforcement. 
    The enforcement of this chapter shall be under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 14-2) 
Sec. 16-33. - Investigation. 
    Upon notice from any person of the existence of any of the conditions described in section 16-31, the city manager shall cause to be made by the appropriate city official such investigation as may be necessary to determine whether, in fact, such conditions constitute a public nuisance as declared in section 16-31. 
(Code 1987, § 14-3) 
Sec. 16-34. - Violations; penalties; abatement by city. 
(a)  Upon investigation and finding by the city manager that any premises is being maintained in violation of section 16-31, the city manager is hereby vested with authority to give written notice, which may be served personally, by registered mail or in any other manner authorized by law to the owner, occupant or person in charge of such premises or to any two or all of such persons believed to be responsible for such violation. The notice shall specify the condition which constitutes the violation and shall direct the addressee to abate such violation in a lawful manner within ten days from the date of the notice. The notice shall also warn the addressee that failure to comply with such notice shall subject him to prosecution for his violation and, in addition, shall render him liable to the city for any costs and expenses which may be incurred by the city in the abatement of such violation under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, and that such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien upon the property involved. 
(b)  If, upon the expiration of the time specified in any such notice, the condition which constitutes the violation has not been abated in a lawful manner, the city manager shall provide for the abatement of such condition by the most expedient means, and the costs and expenses thereby incurred, including any cost incurred in service of the notice, shall be collected by the city tax collector from any one or more of the addressees served with notice and, if such costs and expenses are not paid within 30 days, the city tax collector shall make collection thereof in the manner provided by law for delinquent taxes, or in any other manner authorized by law, and the amount of such costs and expense shall constitute a lien in favor of the city upon the property upon which the violation occurred. 
(c)  In addition to the sanctions imposed in subsection (b) of this section, a violation of this article or any order issued under this article shall also be a civil offense and shall subject the offender to a civil penalty as follows: 
(1)  If the offender shall abate the nuisance within ten days from the date of the notice and shall not, within the preceding three years, have been notified of any prior violation of this article, no civil penalty shall be assessed. 
(2)  If the offender shall abate the nuisance within ten days from the date of the notice but shall, within the preceding three years, have been notified of any prior violation of this article, a civil penalty in the amount of $200.00 shall be assessed. 
(3)  If the offender shall not abate the nuisance within ten days from the date of the notice, a civil penalty in the amount of $200.00 shall be assessed for each day upon which inspection of the premises is made and the nuisance is found to either first exist or to be unabated. 
    For the purposes of this section, only notices given on or after the effective date of Ordinance No. O-2004-08 [April 20, 2004] shall be considered as notice of any prior violation of this article. 
    Furthermore, any landowner violating this article shall be issued a written citation in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1987, § 14-4; Ord. No. O-2004-08, § 1, 4-20-2004) 
Sec. 16-35. - Defects in service of notice. 
    Defects in the method of giving the notice as specified in section 16-34 or in the form thereof or the giving of such notice to an improper person shall not prevent the city, in any case where the work of abating any violation of this article is actually done by the city, from collecting the cost thereof from the owner of the premises upon which the violation occurred, nor shall it affect the validity of the lien on such premises for such cost. 
(Code 1987, § 14-5) 
Sec. 16-36. - Right of entry. 
    An agent of the city shall have the right to enter any premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of making the inspections or investigations required by this article. 
(Code 1987, § 14-6) 
Sec. 16-37. - Hindering, obstructing and delaying agents. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, obstruct or delay any agent of the city in the lawful discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1987, § 14-7) 
Sec. 16-38. - Article to be additional remedy. 
    The procedure set forth in this article shall be in addition to any other remedies that may exist under law for the abatement of public nuisances, including, but not limited to the provisions of G.S. 160A-175. This article shall not prevent the city from proceeding in a criminal action against any person violating the provisions of this article, as provided in G.S. 14-4. 
(Code 1987, § 14-8; Ord. No. O-2019-04, § 2, 2-19-2019) 
Secs. 16-39-16-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate, control, restrict and prohibit all noises tending to annoy persons, G.S. 160A-184. 

Sec. 16-71. - Unreasonably loud and disturbing noises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 14-26) 
Sec. 16-72. - Noises detrimental to life and health. 
    Noise of such character, intensity and duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1987, § 14-27) 
Sec. 16-73. - Enumeration. 
    Acts which are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this article, shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place in the city, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. Also, the use of any signaling device, except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is held up for any reason. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The use or operation of, or permitting to be played, used or operated, any radio receiver set, tape recorder, phonograph, television, musical instrument or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for the convenience of the persons who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operating and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument or device in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of the violation of this subsection. 
(3)  Pets. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort and repose of any person in the vicinity. 
(4)  Use of vehicles. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such a manner as to create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(5)  Steam whistles on stationary boilers. The blowing of any steam whistle on any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of danger. 
(6)  Exhaust discharges. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of an internal combustion engine or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(7)  Compressed air devices. The use of any mechanical device operated by compression air unless the noise created thereby is effectively muffled or reduced. 
(8)  Noise near schools, hospitals, churches, etc. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to a school, institution of learning, library, sanitarium or court while such school, institution of learning, library, sanitarium or court is in session or which unreasonably interferes with the working of such institution, provided, conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the street is a school, hospital, church, library, sanitarium or court street. 
(9)  Loading and unloading vehicles, opening bales, etc. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
(10)  Bells and gongs attached to buildings, etc. The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any building or premises, which disturbs the quiet or repose of persons in the vicinity; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed to apply to a fire alarm. 
(11)  Peddlers, hawkers and vendors. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the quiet and peace of the neighborhood. 
(12)  Drums and loudspeakers used to attract attention to performances, sales, etc. The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention, by creation of noise, to any performance, show, sale, display or advertisement of merchandise. 
(13)  Loudspeakers and amplifiers on vehicles. Except as provided in subsection (12) of this section, the use of mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers on trucks, other vehicles or airplanes for advertising or other purposes, except in specific instances and upon written permission obtained from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 14-28) 
Sec. 16-74. - Political advertisements. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to political advertisements by the use of motor vehicles, drums, loudspeakers, amplifiers or other instruments within the 30-day period immediately preceding regularly conducted primaries or elections. 
(Code 1987, § 14-29) 
Sec. 16-75. - Permits for relief from allowable noise level limits. 
    Applications for a permit for relief from the maximum allowable noise level limits designated in sections 16-71-16-73 may be made in writing to the chief of police or his designee. Any permit granted by the chief of police or his designee under this article must be in writing and shall contain all conditions upon which the permit shall be effective. The chief of police or his designee may grant the relief as applied for under the following conditions: 
(1)  General conditions and requirements. The chief of police or his designee may prescribe any reasonable conditions or requirements he deems necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the community or the surrounding neighborhood, including use of mufflers, screens, or other sound attenuating devices. 
(2)  Permits. Permits may be granted under the following conditions: 
a.  The function must be staged between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight Friday and Saturday; 
b.  The function must be open to the public; or 
c.  The function must take place on public property or public vehicular areas of shopping centers. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-08, 4-22-2003) 
Secs. 16-76-16-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED, NUISANCE AND JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- Removal and disposal of junked and abandoned motor vehicles, G.S. 160A-303. 

Sec. 16-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means, as authorized and defined in G.S. 160A-303, a motor vehicle that: 
(1)  Is left upon a public street or highway in violation of a law or ordinance prohibiting parking; 
(2)  Is left on a public street or highway for longer than seven days; 
(3)  Is left on property owned or operated by the city for a period of time longer than 24 hours; or 
(4)  Is left on private property, without the consent of the owner, occupant or lessee thereof, for a period of time longer than two hours. 
    Authorizing official means the supervisory employee of the police department or the city zoning officer, respectively, designated to authorize the removal of vehicles under the provisions of this article. 
    Junked motor vehicle means, as authorized and defined in G.S. 160A-303.2, a vehicle that does not lawfully display a current license plate upon such vehicle, and that: 
(1)  Is partially dismantled or wrecked; 
(2)  Cannot be self-propelled or moved in the manner in which it originally was intended to move; or 
(3)  Is more than five years old and appears to be worth less than $500.00. 
    Motor vehicle or vehicle means all machines designated or intended to travel over land or water by self-propulsion or while attached to any self-propelled vehicle. 
    Nuisance vehicle means a vehicle on public or private property that is determined and declared to be a health or safety hazard, a public nuisance and unlawful, including a vehicle found to be: 
(1)  A breeding ground or harbor for mosquitoes, other insects, rats or other pests; 
(2)  A point of heavy growth of weeds or other noxious vegetation over eight inches in height; 
(3)  A point of collection of pools or ponds of water; 
(4)  A point of concentration of quantities of gasoline, oil or other flammable or explosive materials, as evidenced by odor; 
(5)  One which has areas of confinement which cannot be operated from the inside, such as trunks, hoods, etc. 
(6)  So situated or located that there is a danger of the vehicle falling or turning over; 
(7)  One which is a point of collection of garbage, food waste, animal waste, or any other rotten or putrescible matter of any kind; 
(8)  One which has sharp parts, which are jagged or contain sharp edges, of metal or glass; 
(9)  So offensive to the sight as to damage the community, neighborhood or area appearance upon a finding by the enforcement officer that such aesthetic regulation is necessary and desirable for the protection of property values, promotion of tourism, indirect protection of health and safety, preservation of the character and integrity of the community or promotion of the comfort, happiness and emotional stability of area residents; or 
(10)  Any other vehicle specifically declared by the city council to be a health and safety hazard and a public nuisance. 
(Code 1987, § 25-146; Ord. No. O-2011-13, § 1, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. O-2013-02, § 1, 1-22-2013) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-303(b). 
Sec. 16-102. - Abandoned vehicles unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to cause or allow such vehicle to be abandoned. 
(b)  Upon investigation, proper authorizing officials of the city may determine that a vehicle is an abandoned vehicle and order the vehicle removed. 
(Code 1987, § 25-147) 
Sec. 16-103. - Nuisance vehicles unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located, to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after it has been declared a nuisance vehicle. 
(b)  Upon investigation, the city zoning officer may determine and declare that a vehicle is a health or safety hazard and a nuisance vehicle, and order the vehicle removed. 
(Code 1987, § 25-148) 
State Law reference- Authority to abate public health nuisances, G.S. 160A-193. 
Sec. 16-104. - Junked motor vehicles regulated; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of a junked motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which a junked motor vehicle is located, to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after the vehicle has been ordered to be removed. 
(b)  Upon investigation, the city zoning officer may order the removal of a junked motor vehicle after finding, in writing, that the aesthetic benefits of removing the vehicle outweigh the burdens imposed on the private property owner. Such finding shall be based on a balancing of the monetary loss of the apparent owner against the corresponding gain to the public by promoting or enhancing community, neighborhood or area appearance. The following, among other relevant factors, may be considered: 
(1)  Protection of property values; 
(2)  Promotion of tourism and other economic development opportunities; 
(3)  Indirect protection of public health and safety; 
(4)  Preservation of the character and integrity of the community; and 
(5)  Promotion of the comfort, happiness and emotional stability of area residents. 
(Code 1987, § 25-149) 
Sec. 16-105. - Pre-towing notice requirements. 
(a)  Except as set forth in section 16-106, an abandoned, nuisance or junked vehicle which is to be removed shall be towed only after notice to the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of the vehicle. In the case of a nuisance vehicle or junked motor vehicle, if the names and mailing addresses of the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of the vehicle, or the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located can be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the notice shall be given by first class mail. The person who mails the notice shall retain a written record to show the names and addresses to which the notice was mailed, and the date of such mailing. If such names and addresses cannot be ascertained, or if the vehicle to be removed is an abandoned motor vehicle, notice shall be given by affixing on the windshield or some other conspicuous place on the vehicle a written notice, which shall state that the vehicle will be removed by the city on a specified date, no sooner than seven days after the notice is affixed or mailed, unless the vehicle is moved by the owner or legal possessor prior to such time. 
(b)  If the registered owner or person entitled to possession of an abandoned vehicle on private property, nuisance vehicle or junked motor vehicle to which notice is required to be given does not remove the vehicle, but chooses to appeal the determination that the vehicle is abandoned, a nuisance vehicle or in the case of a junked motor vehicle that the aesthetic benefits of removing the vehicle outweigh the burdens, such appeal shall be made to the city council, in writing, heard at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council, and further proceedings to remove the vehicle shall be stayed until the appeal is heard and decided. 
(Code 1987, § 25-150) 
Sec. 16-106. - Exceptions to prior notice requirement. 
    The requirement that notice be given prior to the removal of an abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicle may, as determined by the authorizing official, be omitted in circumstances where there is a special need for prompt action to eliminate traffic obstructions or to otherwise maintain and protect the public safety and welfare. Such findings shall, in all cases, be entered in the appropriate daily records by the authorizing official. Circumstances justifying the removal of vehicles without prior notice shall include the following: 
(1)  Vehicles abandoned on streets. The city council hereby determines that immediate removal of vehicles left on the public streets and highways may be warranted when they are: 
a.  Obstructing traffic; 
b.  Parked in violation of an ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking; 
c.  Parked in a no stopping or no standing zone; 
d.  Parked in loading zones; 
e.  Parked in bus zones; or 
f.  Parked in violation of temporary parking restrictions imposed under this Code. 
(2)  Other abandoned or nuisance vehicles. Abandoned or nuisance vehicles left on city owned property, other than the streets and highways, and on private property may be removed without giving prior notice only in circumstances where the authorizing official finds a special need for prompt action to protect and maintain the public health, safety and welfare, including, but not limited to, the following circumstances: 
a.  Vehicles blocking or obstructing ingress or egress to businesses and residences; 
b.  Vehicles parked in such a location or manner as to pose a traffic hazard; and 
c.  Vehicles causing damage to public or private property. 
(Code 1987, § 25-151) 
Sec. 16-107. - Post-towing notice requirements. 
(a)  Any abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicle which has been ordered to be removed may, as directed by the city, be removed to a storage garage or area by the tow truck operator or towing business contracting to perform such services for the city. Whenever such a vehicle is removed, the authorizing city official shall immediately notify the last known registered owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle, such notice to include the following: 
(1)  Description of the removed vehicle; 
(2)  Location where the vehicle is stored; 
(3)  Violation with which the owner is charged, if any; 
(4)  Procedure the owner must follow to redeem the vehicle; and 
(5)  Procedure the owner must follow to request a probable cause hearing on the removal. 
(b)  The city shall attempt to give notice to the vehicle owner or person entitled to possession by telephone; however, whether or not these persons are reached by telephone, written notice, including the information set forth in subsections (1) through (5) above, shall also be mailed to the registered owner's last known address or the address of the person entitled to possession's address, unless this notice is waived in writing by the vehicle owner, the person entitled to possession, or his agent. 
(c)  If the vehicle is registered in the state, notice shall be given within 24 hours to its owner or person entitled to possession. If the vehicle is not registered in the state, notice shall be given to the registered owner within 72 hours from the time of removal of the vehicle. 
(d)  Whenever an abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicle is removed, the authorizing city office shall make reasonable efforts to determine the last known registered owner or the person entitled to possession of the vehicle, and to notify him of the information set forth in subsections (a)(1)-(5) of this section. 
(Code 1987, § 25-152; Ord. No. O-2006-04, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-108. - Right to probable cause hearing before sale or final disposition of vehicle. 
    After the removal of an abandoned vehicle, nuisance vehicle or junked motor vehicle, the owner or any other person entitled to possession of such vehicle is entitled to a hearing for the purpose of determining if probable cause existed for removing the vehicle. A request for hearing must be filed, in writing, with the county magistrate designated by the chief district court judge to receive such hearing requests. The magistrate will set the hearing within 72 hours of receipt of the request, and the hearing will be conducted in accordance with the provisions of G.S. 20-222. 
(Code 1987, § 25-153) 
Sec. 16-109. - Redemption of vehicle during proceedings. 
    At any stage in the proceedings, including before the probable cause hearing, the owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle may obtain possession of the removed vehicle by paying the towing fee, including any storage charges, or by posting a bond for double the amount of such fees and charges to the tow truck operator or towing business having custody of the removed vehicle. Upon regaining possession of a vehicle, the owner or person entitled to the possession of the vehicle shall not allow or engage in further violations of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 25-154; Ord. No. O-2006-04, § 2, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-110. - Sale and disposition of unclaimed vehicles. 
    Any abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicle which is not claimed by the owner or other party entitled to possession will be disposed of by the tow truck operator or towing business having custody of the vehicle. Disposition of such a vehicle shall be carried out in coordination with the city and in accordance with G.S. 44A-1 et seq. 
(Code 1987, § 25-155) 
Sec. 16-111. - Conditions for removal of vehicles from private property. 
(a)  As a general policy, the city will not remove a vehicle from private property if the owner, occupant or lessee of such property could have the vehicle removed under applicable state law procedures. 
(b)  In no case will a vehicle be removed by the city from private property without a written request of the owner, occupant or lessee, except in cases where a vehicle is a nuisance vehicle or a junked motor vehicle which has been ordered removed by the city zoning officer. 
(c)  The city may require any person requesting the removal of an abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicle from private property to indemnify the city against any loss, expense or liability incurred because of the removal, storage or sale thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 25-156) 
Sec. 16-112. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to any vehicle which is: 
(1)  Located in a bona fide "automobile graveyard" or "junkyard," as such terms are defined in G.S. 136-143, in accordance with the Junkyard Control Act, G.S. 136-141, et seq.; 
(2)  In an enclosed building; 
(3)  On the premises of a business enterprise being operated in a lawful place and manner if the vehicle is necessary to the operation of the enterprise; or 
(4)  In an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 25-157) 
Sec. 16-113. - Removal of impounded vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, or attempt to remove, from any storage facility designated by the city any vehicle which has been impounded pursuant to the provisions of this Code unless and until all towing and impoundment fees which are due, or bond in lieu of such fees, have been paid. 
(Code 1987, § 25-158) 
Sec. 16-114. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  The police department and city zoning officer shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this article. The police department shall be responsible for administering the removal and disposition of vehicles determined to be abandoned on the public streets and highways within the city, and on property owned by the city. The city zoning officer shall be responsible for administering the removal and disposition of abandoned, nuisance or junked motor vehicles located on private property. 
(b)  On an annual basis, the city may contract with private tow truck operators or towing businesses to remove, store and dispose of abandoned, nuisance and junked motor vehicles in compliance with this article and applicable state laws. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit the legal authority or powers of officers of the city police department and fire department in enforcing other laws or in otherwise carrying out their duties. 
(Code 1987, § 25-159) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; fire limits, § 6-71 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 12; burning solid waste, § 30-76. 
State Law reference- Fire protection in municipalities, G.S. 160A-291 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Fire escapes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to encumber any fire escape, balcony or ladder which is intended as a means of escape from fire. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all police officers and firefighters who shall discover such encumbered fire escapes to report such encumbrance through their departments to the chief of the bureau of fire prevention, who shall immediately notify the owner, agent or tenant to immediately vacate or remove such encumbrance. 
(Code 1987, § 10-1) 
State Law reference- Requirements for fire escapes, G.S. 69-11, 69-12. 
Sec. 18-2. - Congregating on streets near fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons to congregate on the streets or sidewalks near a fire in a manner so as to interfere with the activities of the fire department. 
(Code 1987, § 10-2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Interfering with firefighters in the performance of their duties, G.S. 69-39. 
Sec. 18-3. - Loitering at fire station; interfering with fire apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the members of the fire department, to loiter about any fire station or to change, handle or meddle in any manner with any fire engine or any other fire apparatus. 
(Code 1987, § 10-3) 
Sec. 18-4. - Unauthorized mounting or riding of fire engine and apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a bona fide member of the fire department, to mount or ride on any fire engine or apparatus before it leaves the fire station, while on its way to or from a fire or at any other time unless by permission of the driver or officer in command of such engine or other apparatus. 
(Code 1987, § 10-4) 
Sec. 18-5. - Open burning. 
(a)  It shall be illegal for any person to burn, or cause to be burned, any trash, refuse, shavings, paper, leaves, litter, tires, shingles, paint or other material of any kind outside any house or in or on any street, sidewalk, lot or yard within the city limits. 
(b)  Contractors, developers or corporations involved in the clearing of land, rights-of-way or easements for development purposes may burn only upon submitting to the fire chief a permit from the appropriate state authorities authorizing specific burnings. 
(Code 1987, § 10-5) 
Secs. 18-6-18-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city, by ordinance, to restrict, regulate or prohibit the sale, possession, use, etc., of any explosive, corrosive or flammable substance, G.S. 160A-183; fire escapes, G.S. 69-8 et seq.; safety precautions in hotels, G.S. 69-26 et seq.; gasoline and oil inspection and regulation, G.S. ch. 119; inspection and regulation of liquefied petroleum gases, G.S. 119-54 et seq. 

Sec. 18-41. - Adopted. 
    North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, (2009 International Fire Code with North Carolina Amendments), of the North Carolina State Building Code, 2017 Edition, as published by the North Carolina Building Code Council and the North Carolina Department of Insurance, as adopted by reference as the City of Laurinburg's Fire Prevention Code, is hereby amended by incorporating the 2018 International Fire Code with North Carolina Amendments. A copy of the Fire Prevention Code, along with the amendments, is on file in the office of the city clerk and the same is hereby incorporated in and made a part of this ordinance as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1987, § 10-21; Ord. No. O-2006-13, § 1, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. O-2009-10, § 1, 7-21-2009; Ord. No. O-2012-03, § 1, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. O-2019-01, § 1, 1-22-2019) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, G.S. 160A-76(b). 
Sec. 18-42. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Corporation counsel means the city attorney. 
    Municipality means the city. 
(Code 1987, § 10-22) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-43. - Administration and enforcement; bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The fire prevention code shall be administered and enforced by the bureau of fire prevention which is hereby established within the fire department and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The organization of the bureau of fire prevention shall be as prescribed from time to time by the chief of the fire department, with the approval of the city manager. 
(c)  The chief of the bureau of fire prevention or his representative shall have the right, during reasonable hours, upon proper identification and in compliance with all applicable provisions of law, to enter any building, structure or premises in the discharge of his official duties for the purpose of making any inspection, removing any fire hazard or enforcing compliance with any provision of the fire prevention code. 
(d)  The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall be deemed to be a fire prevention inspector within the meaning of G.S. 160A-411 and he shall have the powers and perform the duties prescribed for inspectors in G.S. 160A-412-160A-433, insofar as such sections may relate to fire hazards and fire protection. 
(Code 1987, § 10-23) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Authority of fire chief, etc., to enter building, G.S. 69-4; duty of city fire chief to seek out and have corrected all places and conditions dangerous to the safety of the city and its citizens from fire, and make annual reports to the city council concerning these duties, G.S. 160A-292; investigation of fires and inspection of premises generally, G.S. 69-1-69-7; gasoline and oil inspection and regulation, G.S. ch. 119; inspections and regulation of liquefied petroleum gases, G.S. 119-54 et seq. 
Sec. 18-44. - Flammable liquids. 
(a)  The limits within which the storage of flammable liquids in outside above the ground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  The limits of the fire districts established in section 6-71; 
(2)  Any area within the city zoned for any purpose other than industrial. 
(b)  The limits within which new bulk plants for flammable liquids are prohibited are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  The limits of the fire districts established in section 6-71; 
(2)  Any area within the city zoned for any purpose other than industrial. 
(Code 1987, § 10-24) 
Sec. 18-45. - Liquefied petroleum gases. 
    The limits within which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  The limits of the fire districts established in section 6-71; 
(2)  Any area within the city zoned for any purpose other than industrial. 
(Code 1987, § 10-25) 
Sec. 18-46. - Explosives and blasting agents. 
    The limits within which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited are hereby established as any place within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 10-26) 
Sec. 18-47. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Fire lanes shall be designated in all shopping centers by the erection of appropriate signs and other markings. 
(b)  The type of signs and markings used to identify fire lanes shall be approved by the city manager or his designated official. 
(c)  The chief of police or his agent is hereby designated with the right and authority to remove vehicles or other obstructions parked or placed in a fire lane. 
(d)  The procedure for towing and storage of vehicles and other obstructions removed pursuant to this section shall be in accordance with sections 38-175-38-178 of this Code. 
(e)  The parking of motor vehicles or placement of other obstructions in any designated fire lane shall be unlawful and a violation of the laws of the city. The owners and operators of such vehicles or obstructions shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 10-27) 
Sec. 18-48. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention or his duly authorized agent shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application, in writing, by the owner or lessee of any property affected thereby when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification, when granted or allowed, and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention, shall be entered upon the records of the fire department and a signed copy shall be furnished to the applicant. 
(Code 1987, § 10-28) 
Sec. 18-49. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention to the city council within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1987, § 10-29) 
Sec. 18-50. - New materials, processes or occupancies requiring permits. 
    The city manager, building inspector, chief of the fire department and chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits in addition to those enumerated in the fire prevention code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office and distribute copies of such list to interested persons. 
(Code 1987, § 10-30) 
Sec. 18-51. - Amendments and new editions. 
    As amendments to, and new editions of, the fire prevention code are published from time to time, it shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to file a copy of each amendment or new edition in the office of the city clerk and to notify each member of the city council of his action. Upon adjournment of the second regular meeting of the city council following each such filing and notice by the chief of the fire department, the amendments or new editions filed by him and mentioned in his notice to the city councilmembers shall be deemed to have been adopted by the city council for incorporation in this article as a part thereof, unless otherwise provided by the city council prior to adjournment of the second regular meeting. Such amendments or new editions shall become effective as ordinances of the city when the copies thereof in the office of the city clerk have been authenticated by the signatures of the mayor and the city clerk and notice thereof, in summary form, has been posted on the city hall bulletin board. 
(Code 1987, § 10-31) 
Sec. 18-52. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the fire prevention code or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any notice or order issued under the fire prevention code, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under the fire prevention code, or who shall act in violation of any certificate or permit issued under the fire prevention code and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with an order as affirmed or modified by the city council or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed in the fire prevention code shall, severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by law. 
(b)  The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue. All such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The application of the penalty set forth in subsection (b) of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1987, § 10-32) 
Sec. 18-53. - Conflicts of law. 
    Whenever any provision of the fire prevention code is in conflict with any other provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city, the more stringent provision shall prevail. Whenever any provision of the fire prevention code is in conflict with any provision of state law or of any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to state law, the more stringent provision shall prevail unless otherwise provided by state law or by rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to state law. 
(Code 1987, § 10-33) 
Sec. 18-54. - Charges for special testing, inspection and other services. 
    The fire department is authorized to charge for special testing, inspection and other services provided in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The charges for such services shall be as set forth in the fee schedule adopted by city council. The charges for such services shall be due at the time of application for such test, inspection or services. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-14, § 1, 6-19-2007) 
Secs. 18-55-18-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Interfering with firefighters engaged in performing his duties, G.S. 69-39; appointment of firefighters, establishment of fire department, G.S. 160A-291; duties of fire chief, G.S. 160A-292; fire protection outside of city limits, G.S. 160A-293. 

Sec. 18-81. - Composition. 
    The fire department shall consist of a chief, assistant chief and a sufficient number of officers and firefighters to maintain and operate the fire department. 
(Code 1987, § 10-51) 
Sec. 18-82. - Chief. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the city manager. The chief shall be the commanding officer of the department and shall have control of all personnel and apparatus thereof. The chief shall appoint an assistant chief and whatever other officers he deems are appropriate to carry out the activities of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department shall take charge of and supervise the firefighting and extinguishing of all fires. In the absence of the chief of the fire department from the scene of a fire, the senior officer of the fire department present shall exercise the duties of the chief of the fire department. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department or, in his absence, the senior officer of the fire department present shall be in command of all police officers at the scene of a fire and such police officers shall obey all lawful commands given them by the chief or senior officer of the fire department present pursuant to this subsection. 
(Code 1987, § 10-52) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
Sec. 18-83. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager, in consultation with the chief of the fire department, shall prepare rules and regulations for the government of the fire department and the personnel thereof. Such rules and regulations, which may be amended from time to time, shall be submitted to the city council for approval. It shall be unlawful for any member of the fire department to violate any such rule or regulation which has been approved by resolution of the city council and placed on file in the office of the city clerk. A copy of all such approved rules and regulations shall also be placed on file at the fire department headquarters. 
(Code 1987, § 10-53) 
Sec. 18-84. - Volunteer members. 
    The constitution and bylaws applicable to volunteer members of the fire department shall be consistent with state law, this Code, other ordinances and the rules and regulations of the fire department. Provisions shall be made for the election of officers each year and for the holding of at least one practice drill per month with the names of the persons participating to be reported monthly to the chief of the fire department. Such constitution and bylaws and all amendments thereto shall be approved by the city council by resolution or motion and filed in the office of the city clerk before taking effect. A copy of such approved constitution and bylaws shall also be on file in the office of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1987, § 10-54) 
Chapter 20 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State Fair Housing Act, G.S. ch. 41A. 

Sec. 20-31. - Unlawful discrimination. 
    No owner of real property shall discriminate against any other person because of the religion, race, sex, color, handicapping condition, familial status, national origin or ancestry of such other person, or because of the religion, race, sex, color, handicapping condition, familial status, national origin or ancestry of the friends or associates of such other person in regard to the sale or rental of, or dealings concerning, real property located within the city. Any such discrimination shall be considered an unlawful housing practice. 
(Code 1987, § 13-16) 
Sec. 20-32. - Applicability. 
    Nothing in this article shall require an owner to offer property to the public at large before selling or renting it, nor shall this article be deemed to prohibit owners from giving preference to prospective tenants or buyers for any reason other than religion, race, color, handicapping condition, familial status or national origin. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to bar any religious or denominational institution or organization or any organization operated for charitable or educational purposes, which is operated, supervised or controlled by, or in connection with, a religious organization, from limiting admission, or giving preference, to persons of the same religion or denomination or from making such selection as is calculated by such organization to promote the religious principles for which the organization has been established or maintained. 
(Code 1987, § 13-17) 
Sec. 20-33. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  The rental of a housing accommodation in a building which contains housing accommodations for not more than four families living independently of each other if the lessor or a member of his family resides in one of the housing accommodations; 
(2)  The rental of a room in a private house, not a boardinghouse, if the lessor or a member of his family resides in the house; 
(3)  Religious institutions or organizations, or charitable or educational organizations operated, supervised or controlled by religious institutions or organizations which give preference to members of the same religion in a real estate transaction as long as membership in such religion is not restricted by race, color, sex, handicapping condition, familial status or national origin; 
(4)  Private clubs not in fact open to the public, which, incident to their primary purpose, provide lodging, which they own or operate, for other than a commercial purpose, to their members or give preference to their members; 
(5)  With respect to discrimination based on sex, the rental or leasing of housing accommodations in single-sex dormitory property; 
(6)  The sale, rental, exchange or lease of commercial real estate. For the purposes of this article, the term "commercial real estate" means real property which is not intended for residential use. 
(Code 1987, § 13-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 41A-6. 
Chapter 22 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 12; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 24; traffic, ch. 38.

ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 22-31. - General control. 
    The city manager shall have general control of the police department. 
(Code 1987, § 10-16) 
Sec. 22-32. - Composition. 
    The police department of the city shall consist of the chief of police and as many police officers and officers with special duties as the city council shall provide for from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 19-17) 
State Law reference- Authority to appoint police officers, G.S. 160A-281. 
Sec. 22-33. - Temporary and special police. 
    The city manager may appoint temporary police officers for any emergency and special police for private employment when, in his judgment, it may be deemed necessary. All such special police officers shall be appointed only after investigation by, and upon the recommendation of, the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 19-18) 
State Law reference- Authority to appoint auxiliary law enforcement personnel, G.S. 160A-282. 
Sec. 22-34. - Oath of office. 
    Each police officer shall take and subscribe, before a person authorized by law to administer oaths, the oath of office required by article VI, section 7 of the state constitution. The oath shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 19-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-284. 
Sec. 22-35. - Duties of police generally. 
    The police shall patrol the city at reasonable intervals, give their attention to the enforcement of the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city, perform all duties imposed upon them as is provided under the general law of the state, arrest all offenders, suppress all disturbances, give proper information to strangers and act in a civil manner to all with whom they have official business. 
(Code 1987, § 19-24) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of policemen, G.S. 160A-285; arrest, G.S. 15A-401 et seq. 
Sec. 22-36. - Duties at fire. 
    Upon the occasion of a fire, the police shall be present and shall preserve order and protect property. 
(Code 1987, § 19-25) 
Sec. 22-37. - Powers and duties regarding required licenses. 
(a)  Police officers shall promptly report to the city tax collector any person liable for the payment of a license tax under the provisions of this Code or an ordinance of the city and who is in arrears with respect to such payment. 
(b)  Any police officer may demand of any person that such person exhibit his privilege license and, upon failure of such person to do so, the chief of police or other officer under his direction shall prosecute such person in a proper court for the violation of the provisions of this Code or other ordinance in such cases made and provided. 
(Code 1987, § 19-26) 
Sec. 22-38. - Report of defective streets and sidewalks. 
    Police officers shall report to the chief of police any defects in the streets or sidewalks of their beats which are of such nature as to be likely to cause injury to person or property. Such reports shall be transmitted by the chief of police to the city official designated by the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 19-27) 
Secs. 22-39-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TELEPHONE ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alarm Systems Licensing Act, G.S. 74D-1 et seq. 

Sec. 22-71. - Purpose; definitions. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to reduce the number of false telephone dial alarms and thereby protect public safety by minimizing unnecessary use of the city's limited law enforcement and fire protection resources. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    False alarm means activation of an alarm system, eliciting a response by police or fire department personnel, when a situation requiring such response does not exist, including accidental, avoidable and unnecessary alarm activation due to user error, equipment malfunction, improper or unsuited equipment. 
    Fire or police telephone dial alarm device or system means any mechanical, electrical or radio electronic device, apparatus or system made or designed to automatically actuate or call the city fire or police department's telephone or radio circuits or frequencies, which uses a programmed verbal message or signal to accomplish such purpose. 
    User means any owner or occupant of the premises upon which the fire or police telephone dial alarm device or system is located. 
(Code 1987, § 19-41) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-72. - False alarms. 
(a)  A service fee shall be imposed upon the user for each false fire alarm in excess of two per calendar year. The service fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule adopted by city council. 
(b)  A service fee shall be imposed upon the user for each false burglary and robbery alarm in excess of five per calendar year. The service fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule adopted by city council. 
(c)  The fifth false fire alarm in a calendar year may, in the discretion of the fire chief, result in the alarm user being notified by the fire chief that the alarm shall be deactivated and any monitoring and response to signals from the alarm system shall cease until service is reinstated in accordance with this section. 
(d)  The tenth false burglary and robbery alarm in a calendar year will result in the alarm user being notified by the chief of police that the alarm shall be deactivated and any monitoring and response to signals from the alarm system shall cease until service is reinstated in accordance with this section. 
(e)  The chief of police and fire chief, as appropriate, shall certify to the director of finance the name of the user, the address from which alarms subject to penalty originated and the amount due the city on the last day of each month. The director of finance shall cause billing to be sent and shall in turn notify the chief of police or fire chief when any account is more than 30 days in arrears. Any account more than 30 days in arrears shall be subjected to a termination of response. Any fire alarm system required by the state building code that is disconnected due to failure to pay service fees shall also subject the alarm user to further civil or criminal penalty. 
(f)  Any fire or police telephone dial alarm device or system which has been deactivated pursuant to the terms of this section may be reinstated when the user has paid all past due fees and submits to the chief of police or the fire chief, whichever is appropriate, proof that the alarm system has been repaired to such an extent that it will minimize any false alarms. Proof of such repairs and the decision to reinstate the system shall be solely in the discretion of the chief of police or fire chief, whichever is appropriate. 
(Code 1987, § 19-42; Ord. No. O-2007-13, § 1, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 22-73. - Unlawful systems. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, sell, lease or use, or cause or permit to be installed, sold, leased or used, any fire or police telephone dial alarm device or system which operates through overhead or underground wires or by radio frequencies and which is designed, set or programmed to directly dial, actuate, call or in any other manner make direct contact with any telephone line or radio circuit or frequency of, or assigned to, the city fire and police departments. 
(Code 1987, § 19-43) 
Sec. 22-74. - Installation of alarm systems that do not directly contact fire or police department. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prohibit the installation, sale, lease or use of any alarm device not designed or programmed to dial, actuate, call or in any other manner directly contact, by telephone or radio circuit, the city fire or police department on any telephone line or radio circuit or frequency of, or assigned to, the city fire or police department, provided that the person installing such alarm system shall notify the city police and fire departments of each installation within five days of such installation. 
(Code 1987, § 19-44) 
Chapter 24 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 22; traffic, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- State criminal code, G.S. ch. 14. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Attempting; aiding and abetting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to commit any act which is prohibited by this Code or other ordinance, or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to aid or abet another in the commission, or attempted commission, of any act which is prohibited by this Code or other ordinance, or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority thereof. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to avoid the doing of any act which is required by this Code or other ordinance, or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to aid or abet another in the avoidance, or attempted avoidance, of any act which is required by this Code or other ordinance, or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 15-1) 
State Law reference- Principals and accessories, G.S. 14-5.2 et seq. 
Sec. 24-2. - Begging and soliciting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to beg on the streets of the city or otherwise solicit funds on streets in the city without first procuring a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 15-3) 
State Law reference- Obtaining money by false representation of physical defect, G.S. 14-113; authority to regulate begging, G.S. 160A-179. 
Sec. 24-3. - Trees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attach or fasten, or cause to be attached or fastened, any wire, cable, rope, band or any other similar device to any shade tree which is the property of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 15-4) 
Sec. 24-4. - Distributing and throwing samples, handbills, circulars, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, or procure any person to distribute, or throw upon any of the streets, sidewalks or public places of the city, or in or upon any motor vehicle, any advertising samples, handbills, dodgers, circulars, booklets or other commercial advertising in such a manner as to be scattered by the elements and become litter, provided that this shall not be construed to prohibit the distribution or delivery of any newspaper which is capable of being entered, or is entered, as second class matter under the provisions of the current United States Post Office regulations or any United States statutes. 
(Code 1987, § 15-5) 
Sec. 24-5. - Spraying pesticides, etc., from aircraft. 
    No person shall spray or release any pesticide, defoliant or similar material from any aircraft flying over the city. 
(Code 1987, § 15-8) 
Sec. 24-6. - Sleeping on streets and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep on any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1987, § 15-10) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
Sec. 24-7. - Stink bombs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry, leave or release, or cause to be carried, left or released, in any church, school, hotel, theater or other public place within the city, any stink bomb by whatever name called, or any other substance, contrivance or compound which, by reason of its odor, will cause discomfort, annoyance or danger to any person in such place where it shall have been released, brought or deposited. 
(Code 1987, § 15-11) 
Sec. 24-8. - Whistles and sirens similar to those of the fire and police departments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without special authority from the police department of the city, to carry or use any whistle or siren like or similar in appearance or sound to the whistles and sirens used by the police department or fire department. 
(Code 1987, § 15-12) 
Sec. 24-9. - Restrooms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the restroom of any public building or other place in the city which is designated as being reserved for persons of the opposite sex, with the exception of the building owner or employee actually doing maintenance work or cleaning up. 
(Code 1987, § 15-13) 
Sec. 24-10. - Public consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person may consume alcoholic beverages as defined in G.S. 18B-101(4) on any public streets, parks or sidewalks or in public buildings within the city, provided, however, that the possession and consumption of malt beverages and unfortified wine, as defined by G.S. Ch. 18B, is permitted during any community-sponsored public function, festival or celebration when conducted on a public street, sidewalk or other publicly owned area pursuant to a written permit issued by the city manager or his duly authorized representative. This permit, when issued, will also allow the sale, service and distribution of malt beverages and unfortified wine on designated streets, sidewalks and areas reserved for the event, subject to all applicable ABC regulations; provided, however, before such permit is issued under this section, the city manager or his duly authorized representative shall designate the boundaries of the event and temporarily close those streets within the boundaries for general public use. Applicants must demonstrate proof of proper insurance for the planned event and make adequate provision for traffic control and public safety. The city manager or his representative may place such additional restrictions on the event as he deems reasonably necessary to insure public safety and convenience. Application forms for such permits are available in the office of the city manager, and must be filed at least 14 days prior to the opening day of the event. 
(Code 1987, § 15-14; Ord. No. O-2017-21, § 1, 12-12-2017) 
Sec. 24-11. - Filing false claims for refunds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly file a false claim for a refund of money from the city. 
(Code 1987, § 15-15) 
Secs. 24-12-24-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIREARMS AND WEAPONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the discharge of firearms, G.S. 160A-189. 

Sec. 24-41. - Discharge of firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm within the city, except when lawfully used in defense of person or property, or pursuant to lawful directions of law enforcement officers or by special permission of the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 15-31) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate firearms, G.S. 160A-189. 
Sec. 24-42. - Blank cartridges. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge blank cartridges within the corporate limits of the city, provided that this section shall not apply to firing squads at military funerals, members of the cast of a theatrical performance or similar event or officials at athletic events. 
(Code 1987, § 15-32) 
Sec. 24-43. - Air guns, pellet guns and slingshots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or use any air gun, pellet gun, slingshot or any other mechanism or device designed or used to project a missile by compressed air or mechanical or human muscle action with less than deadly force, except by special permission of the chief of police.
