(Code 1987, § 15-33) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit pellet guns, G.S. 160A-190. 
Sec. 24-44. - Concealed handguns. 
(a)  It shall be lawful for any governmental unit to post a prohibition against carrying a concealed handgun as authorized pursuant to G.S. 14-415.23. The size of the notice shall be a minimum of 120 square inches and the words "CONCEALED HANDGUNS PROHIBITED" shall be printed in bold print at a typeset of at least three-quarters inch and, in smaller print, such notice shall contain the words "BY ORDER OF THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF LAURINBURG." The notice shall be posted at each entrance to the local government buildings and at prominent places on their appurtenant premises and in parks. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person carrying a concealed handgun to go in or upon any local government buildings, their appurtenant premises or parks where such notice of prohibition has been posted. 
(Code 1987, § 15-34) 
State Law reference- Authority to post signs prohibiting on local government property and parks, G.S. 14-415.11(c). 
Chapter 26 - PUBLIC RECORDS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Public records generally, G.S. ch. 132. 

Sec. 26-1. - Custodian; records management program administrator. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of all official city records and shall be responsible for administering the records management program. 
(Code 1987, § 19.5-1) 
Sec. 26-2. - Municipal records retention and disposition. 
    All official city records, both paper and those maintained in electronic form, shall be maintained in accordance with the municipal records retention and disposition schedule issued by the division of archives and history, department of cultural resources, which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 19.5-2) 
Sec. 26-3. - Public access. 
    Records shall be made available to the public, under the supervision of city personnel in the department in which the record is maintained, during regular office hours. No city record may be removed from the premises. 
(Code 1987, § 19.5-3) 
State Law reference- Inspection and examination of records, G.S. 132-6. 
Sec. 26-4. - Copying. 
(a)  Requests. Photocopies of any public record, unless the document has been deemed, according to state law, to be a confidential record, shall be provided to any citizen upon request and payment of the appropriate fee. 
(b)  Need to create records. If the information requested is contained in a set of records, but would require compilation in order to create the record desired, it will be the requester's responsibility to perform such compilation and not the responsibility of the city. If the city finds it appropriate to provide such service, it may negotiate a reasonable charge to provide the information to the requester. 
(1)  Computer database records. Requests for copies of computer databases must be submitted, in writing, to the department in which the record is maintained. Any copies furnished shall exclude any information which has been determined by state law to be confidential. Any confidential data contained in a record shall be eliminated from the record furnished to the public. 
(2)  Geographic information systems (GIS). Any person requesting a copy of information contained in the geographic information system (GIS) must sign a document agreeing not to resell or otherwise use the information for trade or commercial purposes. If a person requesting a copy of the GIS wishes to resell the information or otherwise use it for trade or commercial purposes, the cost for the information supplied by the city shall be negotiated by the city manager and city engineer. 
(3)  Forms of available records. If a record is maintained in nonelectronic form, the city will not be required to create an electronic version for the sole purpose of public distribution. 
(c)  Fees. Copies of records may be obtained at the current rates which are set from time to time and a schedule of such rates is on file and available in the city clerk's office. 
(d)  Diskettes and/or CDS. All diskettes and/or CDS used to obtain city data shall be furnished by the city. No other diskettes and/or CDS shall be used in city owned computers. 
(e)  Special service charge. A special service charge, in addition to the actual cost of duplication, shall be charged where: 
(1)  The request requires extensive use of information technology resources or extensive clerical or supervisory assistance by personnel; or 
(2)  Producing the record in the medium requested results in a greater use of information technology resources than that established by the city for reproduction of the volume of information requested. This special service charge will be based on the actual cost incurred for such extensive use of the resources or personnel involved in the fulfillment of the request. 
(f)  Confidential information commingled with public information. If the records being requested contain confidential information which is commingled with public information, the confidential information shall be deleted from the record before it is distributed to the public or made available for review by the public. 
(Code 1987, § 19.5-4) 
State Law reference- Requests, scope, examination, copying, G.S. 132-6-132-6.2. 
Chapter 28 - SALES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate itinerant merchants, salesmen, peddlers and flea markets, G.S. 160A-178. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Solicitations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler, hawker, itinerant merchant, transient vendor or solicitor for the sale of merchandise or periodicals, whether for present or future delivery, to go in or upon private residences, offices or places of business, not having been invited to do so by the owner or occupant, for the purpose of selling or soliciting the sale of merchandise or periodicals, and such solicitation is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale or soliciting of orders for the sale of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden produce as far as the sale of such commodities are authorized by law. 
(Code 1987, § 20-1) 
Sec. 28-2. - Auction sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold or conduct any auction sale on any street within the city, except at the courthouse, without having first procured a permit from the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 20-3) 
Secs. 28-3-28-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - YARD SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Yard sale means and includes all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises in any "residential zone," as defined by appendix A of this Code, for the purpose of disposing of personal property, including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," "flea market" or "rummage" sale. This definition shall not include a situation where no more than five specific items are held out for sale and all advertisement of such sale specifically names the items to be sold. 
(Code 1987, § 20-21) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-32. - Inspections; closing of premises. 
    A police officer, or any other official designated by any city ordinance to make inspections under the licensing or regulating ordinance or to enforce such ordinance, shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a yard sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may close the premises from such a sale or arrest any individual who violates the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 20-22) 
Sec. 28-33. - General retail sales. 
    The conduct of general retail sales or commercial activities in residential areas is prohibited, except as otherwise expressly authorized under this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 20-23) 
Sec. 28-34. - Days of operation. 
    Sales permitted under this article may be held on any day, except Sunday. 
(Code 1987, § 20-24) 
Sec. 28-35. - Display location of sale items. 
    Personal property offered for sale at a yard sale may be displayed only on a driveway, in a garage and/or in a front or rear yard. No property offered for sale at a yard sale shall be displayed in any public right-of-way. 
(Code 1987, § 20-25) 
Sec. 28-36. - Signs. 
(a)  Types permitted. Only the following signs may be displayed in relation to a pending yard sale: 
(1)  Signs on property: Two signs of not more than four square feet shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where the yard sale is being conducted. 
(2)  Directional signs: Two signs of not more than two square feet each are permitted, provided that the premises upon which the yard sale is conducted is not on a major thoroughfare and written permission to erect such signs is received from the property owner upon whose property such signs are to be placed. 
(b)  Time limitations. Signs may be displayed only during the hours when the yard sale is actively being conducted and must be removed at the close of the yard sale activities or by 6:00 p.m., whichever occurs first. 
(c)  Public right-of-way and utility fixtures. No signs may be placed in the public right-of-way and on telephone poles, light poles or other public utility fixtures. 
(Code 1987, § 20-26) 
Sec. 28-37. - Parking. 
    All parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. The police department may enforce such temporary controls to alleviate any special hazards and/or congestion created by any yard sale. 
(Code 1987, § 20-27) 
Sec. 28-38. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  If any individual is convicted of an offense under this article, the city is instructed to cancel any existing yard sale permit held by the individual convicted and not to issue such individual another yard sale permit for a period of two years from the time of conviction. 
(b)  Every article sold, and each yard sale that is conducted, in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor which shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 20-28) 
Secs. 28-39-28-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 28-61. - Required. 
    No yard sale shall be conducted unless and until the individuals desiring to conduct such sale shall obtain a permit from the city. Members of more than one residence may join in obtaining a permit for a yard sale to be conducted at the residence of one of such persons. 
(Code 1987, § 20-41) 
Sec. 28-62. - Applications. 
    Prior to issuance of any yard sale permit, the individuals conducting such sale shall file a written statement with the city in a reasonable time for issuance of a permit. Mailed applications must be postmarked a reasonable time in advance of the sale. All applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The location at which the proposed sale is to be held; 
(3)  The date on which the sale shall be held and the hours of the sale; 
(4)  The dates of any other yard sales held on the same premises within the current calendar year; 
(5)  An affirmative statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his own personal property and was neither acquired, nor consigned for the purpose of resale; 
(6)  The nature of the items to be sold at the sale; 
(7)  The location of any off-site directional signs. 
(Code 1987, § 28-62) 
Sec. 28-63. - Fee. 
    There shall be an administrative processing fee for the issuance of the permit required in this division. The amount of such fee shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file and available in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 20-43) 
Sec. 28-64. - Investigation. 
    Before issuing a permit as required by this division, the city may conduct such investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this division. 
(Code 1987, § 20-47) 
Sec. 28-65. - Conditions. 
    The yard sale permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such yard sale. No more than four such permits may be issued to one residence and/or family household during any calendar year, provided that subsequent yard sales shall be permitted if satisfactory proof of a bona fide change in ownership of the real property is first presented to the city. If members of more than one residence join in requesting a permit, then such permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all of such residences. 
(Code 1987, § 20-44) 
Sec. 28-66. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued under this division may be revoked or any application for issuance of a permit may be refused by the city if the application submitted by the applicant or permit holder contains any false, fraudulent or misleading statement. 
(Code 1987, § 20-46) 
Sec. 28-67. - Display. 
    Any yard sale permit in the possession of the holder of a yard sale shall be posted on the premises in a conspicuous place so as to be seen by the public and the appropriate city officials. 
(Code 1987, § 20-45) 
Sec. 28-68. - Inclement weather. 
    If a yard sale is not held on the date for which the permit is issued or is terminated during the sale because of inclement weather conditions and an affidavit by the permit holder to this effect is submitted to the city, the city may issue another permit to the same applicant for a yard sale to be conducted at the same location within 30 days from the date when the first sale was to be held. No additional permit fee is required. 
(Code 1987, § 20-48) 
Sec. 28-69. - Maintenance of good order and decorum. 
    The individual to whom a permit as required by this division is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such individual shall permit any loud or boisterous conduct on such premises or permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises. All such individuals shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police or fire department of the city in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1987, § 20-49) 
Chapter 30 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; disposition of rubbish, § 10-182; environment, ch. 16; throwing stones, trash, substances and filth in reservoirs and settling basins, § 40-6; loitering and littering in parking lots, § 38-168; utilities, ch. 40; unlawful deposits of wastes, § 40-165. 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, G.S. 130A-290 et seq.; authority to regulate the illegal disposal of solid waste, G.S. 160A-185; authority to regulate the placing of trash and refuse with the city, G.S. 160A-303.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Batteries means all transportation type batteries, such as those found in motorcycles, boats, cars, trucks, tractors, lawnmowers, etc. 
    Bulk container means a container of steel construction, with a four, six or eight cubic yard capacity that is watertight and capable of being dumped by the city's front-loading garbage truck. 
    Bulk recycling container means a container of steel construction, with an eight cubic yard capacity that is designed for the purpose of recycling corrugated cardboard or other designated products and is capable of being dumped by the city's front-loading garbage truck. 
    Bulky items means large trash items, such as furniture, white goods, electronic waste, large toys, such as bicycles and dismantled swing sets, and lawn equipment. 
    Construction and demolition waste shall mean all waste resulting from construction, demolition, remodeling, or repair work done by the homeowner or contractors, which shall include, but not limited to, building materials, bricks, concrete, sand, wood, drywall, roofing materials, plumbing or electrical materials, metal, carpet, or vinyl or other flooring, etc. 
    Contract waste means any waste materials resulting from work performed by contractors or persons for hire, but not including waste resulting from work performed by persons doing routine yard work, such as raking, pruning and grass cutting. Such term shall include, but not be limited to, construction materials and materials resulting from tree removal or lot clearing. 
    Electronic waste means any type of electronic equipment, such as television sets, computer equipment and accessories, copiers, VCR's, microwaves, etc. 
    Furniture means couches, chairs, tables, beds, bed springs and mattresses, cabinets and other types of furniture. 
    Garbage means the organic waste matter, both animal and vegetable, from houses, kitchens, restaurants, hotels, hospitals, etc., comprised chiefly of waste food, and not including liquid, that may be drained into the sanitary sewer. Such term shall also mean various kinds of paper, but does not include newspaper, corrugated cardboard or other paper products designated as recyclable. Such term shall also mean small household trash items that can fit in a garbage can. 
    Hazardous material means any substance, liquid, solid or gas, inside or out of a container, that has been determined to be hazardous to humans, animals or the environment. Such term shall include, but not be limited to, explosives, flammables, corrosives, carcinogens, cleaners, solvents, paints, gases, oils, human and animal feces, medical wastes and any other substances declared by state or federal agencies to be hazardous. 
    Medical waste means any substance resulting from medical procedures that is or contains human blood or human blood components, human tissue, human parts or medical material or equipment contaminated with any such items. Such term includes all needles and sharps of any kind used on humans or animals. 
    Recyclable means any product determined to be of a recyclable nature and designated as such by the city council, including, but not limited to, aluminum, green, brown or clear glass, newspaper, mixed paper, magazines, all plastic bottles (#'s 1-7), steel cans, corrugated cardboard and batteries. 
    Solid waste means all bulky items, garbage, medical waste, recyclables and yard waste that is collected by the city. 
    White goods means stoves, refrigerators, washing machines, dryers, water heaters and dishwashers. 
    Yard waste means shrub and grass clippings, pine straw, pine cones, tree limbs and leaves. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. O-2003-09, § 1, 4-22-2003; Ord. No. O-2012-31, §§ 1-3, 9-18-2012) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-2. - Disposal of solid waste generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast or deposit upon any yard or premises, public or private, any solid waste, except in compliance with this chapter and/or the city's solid waste policies adopted from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-2, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-3. - Depositing solid waste on streets, sidewalks and gutters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit in, sweep or rake into any street, sidewalk or gutter any solid waste, except in accordance with policies adopted from time to time by the city council for depositing of such solid waste. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-3, 6-18-2002) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
Sec. 30-4. - Unauthorized hauling and removal of solid waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a person under the direction of the superintendent of the sanitation department, to haul or remove any solid waste set out for collection as provided in policies adopted from time to time by the city council. No person shall pick through, handle, interfere with or remove any solid waste set out for removal by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-4, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-5. - Solid waste from outside the city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or carry any solid waste into the city from outside the city, except for recyclables, and leave or deposit such solid waste within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-5, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-6. - Transporting garbage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to haul, or have hauled, carried or transported, any garbage on any street within the city, except in metal containers, covered vessels or containers for liquids with tightfitting covers that prevent all liquids from leaking onto city streets. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-6, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-7. - Transporting solid waste generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to haul, or have hauled, carried or transported, any solid waste on any street in the city unless such solid waste is secured or covered in such a manner so as to prevent its escape from the means of transportation. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-7, 6-18-2002) 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 38. 
Sec. 30-8. - Disposal of hazardous materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of, or place for disposal, any hazardous material within the city limits; provided, however, that the city may from time to time provide means for disposal of certain hazardous materials. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-8, 6-18-2002) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16. 
Sec. 30-9. - Disposal of recyclable materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any material determined by the city to be recyclable in any manner other than that prescribed by the city for recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-9, 6-18-2002) 
Secs. 30-10-30-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-41. - Level of service. 
(a)  It is the intention of the city to provide the level of solid waste service necessary to protect the public health and safety and to maintain an aesthetically pleasing community in the most economical way possible. 
(b)  The actual level of service shall be established by the city council from time to time, as a matter of policy. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-21, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-42. - Preparation and placement of solid waste for collection. 
    All solid waste shall be prepared and placed in a manner as prescribed by the city council from time to time in its solid waste policy. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-22, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-43. - Rates for removal of solid waste from vacant lots, houses and businesses. 
    For the service of collecting any solid waste from vacant lots, houses or businesses, the property owner shall be charged such rates in accordance with policies established from time to time by the city council. Such charges shall be considered a debt owing to the city and shall be billed for each occurrence that collection services are rendered. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-23, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-44. - Placement and location of bulky items, yard waste and recyclables. 
    All bulky items, yard waste and recyclables shall be placed within the parkway strip between the curb and the sidewalk contiguous to the front of the premises of the origin of such materials. Where there is no sidewalk and/or curb, the materials shall be placed contiguous to the front of the premises of origin reasonably adjacent to the street. None of the items shall be placed in any street, gutter, canal or ditch or upon any sidewalk in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-27, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-45. - Removal of containers after collection by sanitation department. 
    Garbage and recycling containers placed adjacent to the street for removal by the sanitation department shall be removed from their position adjacent to the streets or sidewalks after the contents have been taken by the sanitation department, not later than 7:00 p.m. on the same day of garbage or recyclable removal, except that, at places of business or manufacturing, empty containers shall not be left on the street for more than 30 minutes during the hours between 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-28, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. O-2012-31, § 4, 9-18-2012) 
Sec. 30-46. - Collection of solid waste by unauthorized persons. 
    No person, other than the city, shall perform, for pay, the service of collecting, hauling and disposing of solid waste from within the city limits unless authorized to do so by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-29, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-47. - Charges for collection and disposal of solid waste. 
    For the service of collecting and disposing of solid waste, the owner or occupant of each premises located within the city shall be charged such rates as may be established from time to time by the city council. Such charges shall be considered a debt owing to the city from the owner or occupant of such premises and shall be billed to the owner or occupant on a monthly basis. 
(1)  Delinquent accounts. If any account representing charges for solid waste fees or other solid waste charges shall become more than 90 days delinquent, all services for solid waste collection shall be discontinued, which shall include the removal of all city-owned roll-out carts, recycling bins, and/or bulk containers. Notwithstanding the discontinuance of service and the removal of city-owned carts, bins and/or containers, the applicable monthly solid waste fee shall nevertheless continue to be charged to the monthly utility bill of the premises and due from the owner or occupant thereof. 
(2)  Service charge for restoring service. If services shall be discontinued for nonpayment of an account, a charge shall be added to the account, and full payment or satisfactory arrangements for full payment shall be required before services are restored and solid waste receptacles are returned. This charge shall be as established from time to time by the city council in the schedule of fees. Service shall only be restored during normal working hours. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-30, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. O-2008-09, § 1, 5-20-2008, eff. 6-1-2008) 
Sec. 30-48. - Billing adjustment. 
    In the event of a major billing error, the city will make an adjustment, plus or minus, for a period covering the immediate preceding 12 months. 
Sec. 30-49. - Removal of contract waste. 
    Contract waste shall be removed by the contractor, the person hired to do the work or the owner of the premises where the waste may be located at the owner's expense. City crews shall not collect contract waste and it shall not be placed at the street or in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-32, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-50. - Removal of construction and demolition waste. 
    The homeowner, contractor or person generating the waste shall remove construction and demolition waste. City crews shall not collect construction and demolition waste and it shall not be placed at the street or in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-33, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-51. - Violations; penalties. 
    The city shall assess fines and/or penalties to any person or business disposing of any solid waste in a manner not in compliance with this article and/or the city's solid waste policies adopted from time to time by the city council. The amount of such fines shall be in accordance with policies established from time to time by the city council. Such fines shall be considered a debt owing to the city from the person or business and shall be billed as violations are discovered. In addition to, or in lieu of, such penalties, violations of this article may be prosecuted as misdemeanors in accordance with the state statutes. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-31, 6-18-2002) 
Secs. 30-52-30-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RECEPTACLES 

Sec. 30-71. - Required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, renting or occupying any dwelling, business, building or other place where garbage accumulates or is produced to provide receptacles for all such garbage for removal by the sanitation department in accordance with policies established from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-46, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-72. - Construction and maintenance. 
    All receptacles, residential and commercial, shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with policies established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-47, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-73. - Location. 
    All receptacles, residential and commercial, shall be located in accordance with policies established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-48, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-74. - Use by persons other than owners. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall place any garbage or trash in any receptacle owned by another person, whether corporate or individual, without the consent of such owner. No person residing outside the city limits shall place any garbage or trash in any receptacles serviced by the sanitation department, except receptacles placed on public streets or rights-of-way for use by the public. 
(b)  Recycling receptacles. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any materials into any container which has been designated by the city to be a recycling container unless the label or some other type of document posted on or at the container authorizes such items to be deposited in such container. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-49, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-75. - Handling and treatment. 
    Sanitation workers shall exercise every reasonable care in the handling of garbage, trash and recyclable receptacles provided for in this division, and shall not willfully break, deface or damage such receptacles. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-50, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-76. - Burning solid waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any solid waste in any solid waste container. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-51, 6-18-2002) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 18. 
Sec. 30-77. - Cleaning. 
    No solid waste receptacle shall be cleaned on public property, except under the supervision of the superintendent of the sanitation department, and no residual solid waste from the cleaning of solid waste receptacles shall be allowed to drain into a public gutter, street, sidewalk or storm sewer or into a constant flowing or intermittent flowing stream or stream bed. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-52, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-78. - Removal of improperly placed solid waste. 
    The city shall not be responsible for the removal of any solid waste which is not placed in the proper receptacle or located in the proper location as prescribed by policy adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-53, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-79. - Liquids and semiliquids. 
    No liquid or semiliquid matter will be collected by the city, nor shall such matter be put in receptacles placed for removal by the sanitation department. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-54, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-80. - Nonstandard receptacles. 
    The city sanitation workers shall remove all boxes, pails and wooden or metallic receptacles which do not meet standards established by policy adopted by the city council from time to time, and such nonstandard receptacles shall not be returned to the owner. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-55, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 30-81. - Interference. 
    No person shall pick through, handle, interfere with or remove the contents of any receptacle set out for removal of the contents by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-08, § 12-56, 6-18-2002) 
Chapter 32 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(8); buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; itinerant merchants, peddlers or vendors, § 8-71 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 10; environment, ch. 16; congregating on streets near fire, § 18-2; sleeping on streets and sidewalks, § 24-6; depositing solid waste on streets, sidewalks and gutters, § 30-3; telecommunications, ch. 36; traffic, ch. 38; riding bicycles on sidewalks, § 38-15; one-way streets, § 38-83; driving on sidewalks, § 38-85; utilities, ch. 40; throwing stones, trash, substances and filth in reservoirs and settling basins, § 40-6; vegetation, ch. 42; street tree species list, § 42-33; curbs and sidewalks, § 42-35; vehicles for hire, ch. 44; unified land development ordinances, app. A. 
State Law reference- Roads and highways, G.S. ch. 136; municipal authority as to roads, G.S. 136-66.4; city's authority to make special assessments, G.S. 160A-216 et seq.; streets, traffic and parking, G.S. 160A-296 et seq.; city's general authority and control over streets, sidewalks, etc., G.S. 160A-296. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Paving. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any paving on any sidewalk or street without first securing permission from the city. As a prerequisite to such paving, the street or sidewalk to be paved shall be surveyed by a competent surveyor to ascertain the proper grade and a report of such survey shall be filed with the city. 
(Code 1987, § 22-1) 
Sec. 32-2. - Excavation permit required; bond. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation or cut through the paved portion of any street or sidewalk without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(b)  Before the issuance of any permit required by subsection (a) of this section, there shall be executed by the applicant to the city on a form approved by the city, a bond, in a sum determined by the city to be sufficient, to ensure that the streets and sidewalks will be replaced in a good and workmanlike manner. Such bond shall run for a period of not less than 12 months, so that if the place where the excavation or cut is made pursuant to the permit shall give trouble within such 12-month period, the city will be protected against loss or damage by reason of repair to such cut or excavation. 
(Code 1987, § 22-2) 
Sec. 32-3. - Excavation safety measures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to: 
(1)  Securely cover, with planks, any excavation in a street or sidewalk; 
(2)  Place ropes around such excavation three feet from the ground; 
(3)  Place a sufficient number of lights around such excavation before dark, and exercise reasonable diligence to keep such lights burning. 
(Code 1987, § 22-3) 
Sec. 32-4. - Removal of dirt. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any dirt from any street or sidewalk without first securing a permit to do so from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 22-4) 
Sec. 32-5. - Ditches or gutters crossing sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any open ditch or gutter to run across any sidewalk. All ditches or drains crossing a sidewalk shall be run underground. It shall be unlawful for any person, after having been duly notified to remove or place underground any and all drains or ditches leading from his property and across the sidewalk, to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such notice. 
(Code 1987, § 22-5) 
Sec. 32-6. - Railroad crossings. 
    At any point where a railroad crosses a street, such crossing shall be constructed so as to maintain a uniform grade the entire width of the street intersection. Such crossing shall be constructed of clay, wood or other material in such a way as to prevent a sudden rise or bump in the roadway or sidewalk. When the roadbed of the railroad is lower than the street, the incline shall be uniform and gradual. Where such crossings cannot be constructed so as to meet such requirements, an elevated crossing shall be constructed according to such plans as shall be submitted to, and approved by, the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 22-6) 
Sec. 32-7. - Telephone wires and other wires transmitting electricity. 
    Before any person shall place or locate, in or over the streets or buildings in the city, any fiber optic cable, telephone or other wires transmitting electricity or light, a plan, in writing, of the proposed location thereof shall be submitted to the electric superintendent for his approval. 
(Code 1987, § 22-7) 
Sec. 32-8. - Awnings, shelters and sunshades. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any awning, shelter or sunshade in front of any building if the awning, shelter or sunshade is less than seven feet above the level of the sidewalk. Stationary awning arms shall not be less than eight feet above the level of the sidewalk. The provisions of this section shall apply outside of the fire limits described in section 6-71. 
(Code 1987, § 22-8) 
Sec. 32-9. - Harrows and other machinery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drag or run, or cause to be drug or ran, any harrow or other implement, engine, machine or tool upon any asphalt, batholithic, warrenite or other permanently paved street of the city, which may in any way injure or cut the surface thereof. It shall also be unlawful to injure any unpaved street and sidewalk in a like manner. 
(Code 1987, § 22-9) 
Sec. 32-10. - Skating, skateboarding and in-line skating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate, skateboard or use in-line skates upon any sidewalk or street. except the streets which are designated as play streets by resolution or ordinance of the city council and are blocked or closed to traffic during certain hours. 
(Code 1987, § 22-10) 
Sec. 32-11. - Sidewalks in central business district. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central business district means the boundaries of the central business district as determined by the official zoning map of the city. 
    Developer means any person, firm or corporation that improves land or buildings for commercial or related purposes. 
    Sidewalk means a walkway constructed of concrete. 
(b)  Responsibility for construction and maintenance. It shall be the responsibility of any developer developing or redeveloping property, land or buildings in the central business district to provide sidewalks along streets which are adjacent to that property. All construction shall conform to the city engineering department design standards, and upon completion and acceptance by the city, the sidewalks shall be maintained by the city in accordance with existing policies. 
(Code 1987, § 22-12) 
Sec. 32-12. - Sidewalks along primary and collector streets. 
    The city will install sidewalks along streets which are designated as state or federal routes, as funds are available and at no expense to the adjoining property owners, in accordance with the policies of the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1987, § 22-13) 
Sec. 32-13. - Sidewalks in residential areas. 
    The city will install sidewalks along streets in residential areas when the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The street has curb and gutter. 
(2)  There is a sufficient right-of-way to permit construction of the sidewalk or, where there is an insufficient right-of-way or there are obstructions (trees, utilities, etc.) which require the sidewalk to be placed on private property, all of the owners of property on which the sidewalk will be constructed grant an easement for the sidewalk. 
(3)  A petition is submitted to the city, in accordance with G.S. 160A-216-160A-236, which petition shall: 
a.  Request a project, the length of which shall be at least one block. 
b.  Be signed by the owners of more than 50 percent of the lots abutting the street for which the sidewalk is requested and such lots shall comprise more than 50 percent of the linear footage along such street. 
c.  Specify that the cost of materials used for the project be assessed to the owners of property abutting the project at an equal rate per foot of frontage. 
(Code 1987, § 22-14) 
Secs. 32-14-32-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS 

Sec. 32-41. - Food and drink stands. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any sidewalk any table, stand or cart for the purpose of selling fruit, vegetables, lemonade, ice cream, soda water, popcorn, cooked food or other like articles, except pursuant to a permit issued by the city council at a regular meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 22-31) 
Sec. 32-42. - Display of foodstuffs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display any fruit, vegetables, breadstuff, sugar, meat, cereal or any other edible foodstuff on a sidewalk. 
(Code 1987, § 22-32) 
Sec. 32-43. - Display of goods. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display, for the purpose of sale or advertising, any goods, wares or merchandise on the streets or sidewalks of the city, except pursuant to a permit issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 22-33) 
Sec. 32-44. - Storage of lumber, building materials and other merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store lumber, building materials, merchandise or any other product or article on the streets or sidewalks between the hours of sunset and sunrise without a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 22-35) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 
Sec. 32-45. - Dumping wood, coal and other materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or unload upon any street or sidewalk any coal, wood or any other like material having a tendency to impede or prevent the free and unobstructed use of such street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1987, § 22-36) 
Sec. 32-46. - Porches, steps, fences and other encroachments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build, erect, construct or place any porch, steps, fence, wall, gate or any other encroachment on or over any of the streets or sidewalks of the city or to make any repairs to or on any such encroachment without having procured a permit from the city. 
(Code 1987, § 22-37) 
Sec. 32-47. - Gates. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hang, or cause to be hung, any gate which, when open, may swing over the sidewalk. 
(Code 1987, § 22-38) 
Sec. 32-48. - Cellar doors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any cellar door on the street to stand open, either by day or by night, unless a competent person is in attendance. 
(Code 1987, § 22-39) 
Sec. 32-49. - Overhanging tree limbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property to permit the limbs from any tree growing on his property to obstruct or interfere with the free passage of persons along the sidewalks or streets, provided that any such limb shall be removed upon one day's notice from the chief of police to the owner of such property. If such owner, having received such notice, shall continue to permit, or fails, neglects or refuses to remove, such limb, such limb shall be removed under the direction of the chief of police at the cost of the owner. 
(Code 1987, § 22-40) 
Sec. 32-50. - Shrubbery, hedges and vines. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any premises to permit shrubbery, vines or hedges to be located closer than six inches to any sidewalk or street. The public shall be protected from thorny plants, shrubbery or hedges situated near any sidewalk or street. 
(Code 1987, § 22-41) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 42. 
Sec. 32-51. - Obstruction of view. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the view of approaching traffic at any intersection by signs, trees, shrubbery or structures within 25 feet of the intersection of curblines. 
(Code 1987, § 22-42) 
Sec. 32-52. - Sweeping and cleaning sidewalks. 
    The owners or occupants of improved property used for business purposes, such as banks, theaters, hotels, barbershops, stores or offices, within the fire limits described in section 6-71, which have paved or improved sidewalks fronting such places, shall sweep and clean such sidewalks daily, and at the close of business each Saturday night, all sidewalks fronting such places of business shall be cleaned. 
(Code 1987, § 22-43) 
Sec. 32-53. - Removal of snow, ice, clay and similar substances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or occupying any property within the city to fail, refuse or neglect to remove from all sidewalks fronting such property any snow, ice, clay or other like substance within 12 hours after such substance has fallen or been placed on such sidewalks. The duty of removing such substances from or cleaning the sidewalks as provided in this section shall be upon the occupants of buildings adjacent to such sidewalks and if such property is vacant, the duty shall be upon the owner of such property. 
(Code 1987, § 22-44) 
Secs. 32-54-32-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF DRIVEWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-81. - Inspections. 
    All driveways, approaches or other improvements on the right-of-way, after having been constructed, shall at all times be subject to inspection. 
(Code 1987, § 22-61) 
Sec. 32-82. - Commercial establishments. 
(a)  The location, design, materials and manner of doing work to driveways in connection with commercial establishments in the city shall be in accordance with the standards set out in the pamphlet entitled, Manual on Driveway Entrance Regulations, current edition, published by the state highway commission, including the sketches set out in such pamphlet, as far as such standards are applicable. Copies of such pamphlet shall be kept on file in the office of the city manager. 
(b)  Any conditions relative to the location, design, materials and construction of driveways in connection with commercial establishments in the city not covered in the pamphlet referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be left to the discretion of the city manager and his decision will be final. 
(Code 1987, § 22-62) 
Sec. 32-83. - Residential and noncommercial establishments. 
    The location, design, materials and manner of doing work to driveways in connection with residential or noncommercial establishments in the city shall be in accordance with standards provided by the public works department of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 22-63) 
Sec. 32-84. - Changes, additions, repairs and relocation required by city. 
    The right is reserved to the city to require such changes, additions, repairs and relocation to a driveway constructed pursuant to a permit issued under this article, to be made as may be considered necessary at any time to permit the relocation, reconstruction, widening and maintaining of the street or to provide proper and safe protection to life and property on or adjacent to the street. The cost of making such changes, additions, repairs and relocation shall be borne by the permit holder. 
(Code 1987, § 22-64) 
Sec. 32-85. - Relocation and change in dimensions by owner. 
    No driveway, approach or other improvement constructed on the right-of-way pursuant to a permit issued under this article shall be relocated or its dimensions altered without a written permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 22-65) 
Secs. 32-86-32-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 32-111. - Required. 
    Any person desiring to construct a driveway connecting property along any street with the street shall first procure a permit for such construction from the city. Any person desiring such a permit shall file three copies of an application for such permit with the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 22-81) 
Sec. 32-112. - Application and issuance. 
    Approval by the city of applications for permits required by this division shall be subject to the restrictions set out in this division. Upon approval by the city of such an application, a permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1987, § 22-82) 
Sec. 32-113. - Conditions. 
    A person filing an application for a permit required by this division shall own the property involved and any driveway or approach constructed by him shall be for the bona fide purpose of gaining access to such property and not for the purpose of parking or servicing vehicles on the street right-of-way. 
(Code 1987, § 22-83) 
Sec. 32-114. - City held harmless. 
    Each applicant for a permit under this division shall agree to hold harmless the city and its duly appointed agents and employees against any action for personal injury or property damage sustained by reasons of the exercise of the permit. 
(Code 1987, § 22-84) 
Secs. 32-115-32-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROPERTY NUMBERING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 

Sec. 32-151. - Property numbers. 
    Property numbers are assigned by the city's engineering office. No other property numbers shall be used or displayed in the city, except numbers assigned in accordance with those assigned by the engineering office. 
Sec. 32-152. - Addressing system. 
    The city's property addressing system is kept in the engineering office. The system displays official street names, north-south axis, east-west axis, and the numbering of blocks, and areas inside the city limits. 
Sec. 32-153. - Display of assigned numbers. 
    Every property owner of improved property shall display in a conspicuous place, visible from the center of the abutting street, the number assigned. 
Sec. 32-154. - New building number assignment. 
    All residence and business buildings, when erected, shall be assigned a number in accordance with the city's property addressing system. 
Sec. 32-155. - Altering, defacing, concealing and removing numbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, deface, conceal, screen from view or take down any number placed on any property in accordance with this article, except for repair or replacement of such number. 
(Code 1987, § 22-105) 
Secs. 32-156-32-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARADES, PICKET LINES AND GROUP DEMONSTRATIONS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Picketing or parading, G.S. 14-225.1; failure to disperse, G.S. 14-288.5; power of city to regulate use of street for processions or assemblages, G.S. 20-169. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block means the portion of any street lying between its intersection with other streets. 
    Group demonstration means any assembly together or concert of action between or among two or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter or of making known any position or promotion of such persons, or of or on behalf of any organization or class of persons, or for the purpose of attracting attention to such assembly. 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public grounds or places. 
    Picket line means any two or more persons formed together for the purpose of making known any position or promotion of such persons, or of or on behalf of any organization or class of persons. 
(Code 1987, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 32-192. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to or from school classes or participating in educational or recreational activity where such activity is under the supervision and direction of proper school authorities; 
(3)  Any governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1987, § 16-2) 
Sec. 32-193. - Interference. 
    No person shall hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade, picket line or group demonstration being conducted under authority of a permit duly issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 16-3) 
Sec. 32-194. - Certain acts and activities declared unlawful. 
    The following acts or activities, when performed or undertaken in conjunction with, or as a part of, any parade, picket line or group demonstration, are hereby prohibited and declared unlawful: 
(1)  Carrying on or about the person any firearm or any weapon or article, including, but not limited to, blackjacks, which constitutes a deadly weapon; 
(2)  Taking or keeping of any dog or vicious animal, whether leashed or unleashed, except Seeing Eye or service dogs properly trained to assist blind and other disabled persons or law enforcement animals. 
(Code 1987, § 16-4) 
Sec. 32-195. - Picket and picket line regulations. 
    Picket lines and picketing shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Picketing may be conducted only on the sidewalks reserved for pedestrian movement and may not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Not more than ten picketers promoting the same objective shall be permitted to use either of the two sidewalks within a single block at any one time. 
(3)  Picketers may carry written or printed placards or signs, not exceeding two feet in width and two feet in length, promoting the objective for which the picketing is done, provided that the words used are not derogatory or defamatory in nature. 
(4)  Picketers must march in single file and not abreast and not march closer together than 15 feet, except in passing one another. Picketers shall not be allowed to walk more than five feet from the curbline and shall be in continuous motion. 
(5)  If picketers promoting different objectives desire to use the same sidewalk for picketing and such use would result in the presence of more than ten picketers on such sidewalk, the chief of police shall allot time to each group of picketers for the use of such sidewalk on an equitable basis. 
(Code 1987, § 16-5) 
Secs. 32-196-32-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 32-221. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to organize, conduct or participate in any parade, picket line or group demonstration in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city unless a permit has been issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 16-21) 
Sec. 32-222. - Applications. 
    The chief of police requires a written application for the permit required in section 32-221 to be filed not less than 72 hours in advance of such parade, picket line or group demonstration. Such application shall be on a form prescribed by the chief of police. The chief of police shall require the application to be signed by the applicant and shall require that the applicant show the proposed time, place, purpose and size of such parade, picket line or group demonstration and whether or not any minors below the age of 18 years shall participate. 
(Code 1987, § 16-22) 
Sec. 32-223. - Conditions. 
(a)  The chief of police shall refuse to issue the permit required in section 32-221 when the activity or purpose stated in the application would violate any ordinance of the city or statute of the state or when the activity or purpose would constitute a clear and present danger to the public health or safety or would hinder or prevent the orderly movement of pedestrian or vehicular traffic on streets, alleys or sidewalks. 
(b)  The chief of police shall specify in the permit whether or not minors below the age of 18 years will be permitted to participate. The chief of police shall pass upon whether or not such minors may participate and shall base his determination upon whether or not the purpose, time or place of the particular activity would be detrimental to, or endanger the health, safety or welfare of, such minors or would interfere with their education. 
(c)  The chief of police shall require that the application for a permit shall specify, and the permit shall designate, the person in charge of the activity. Such person shall be required to accompany the parade, picket line or group demonstration and shall carry such permit with him at that time. Such permit shall not be valid in the possession of any other person. 
(d)  The permit may set the starting time, duration, speed of travel and space between persons or vehicles in the parade, picket line or group demonstration. The permit may prescribe the portions or areas of streets, sidewalks or other public places to be used and may impose such other reasonable requirements as the chief of police may prescribe for the control and free movement of pedestrian or vehicular traffic or for the health, safety and property rights of the participants and the general public. 
(e)  Among other considerations, the chief of police shall consider and find, as a requisite to issuance of the permit, the following: 
(1)  The activity will not require excessive diversion of police from other necessary duties; 
(2)  The activity will not interfere with the rights of property owners in the area to enjoy peaceful and lawful occupancy and use of their property; 
(3)  The activity can be conducted without unreasonable interference with normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic in the area and will not prevent normal police and fire protection to the public and will not be likely to cause injury to persons or property or to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a public disturbance. 
(Code 1987, § 16-23) 
Sec. 32-224. - Authority to issue. 
    The chief of police is authorized to issue permits as required in section 32-221. 
(Code 1987, § 16-24) 
Sec. 32-225. - Revocation. 
    The chief of police shall revoke any permit granted for a parade, picket line or group demonstration for any of the following causes: 
(1)  The violation by any participant of section 32-194; 
(2)  The failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit. 
(Code 1987, § 16-25) 
Chapter 34 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(1); any annual tax levy, appropriation or budget saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Taxation, G.S. ch. 105. 

Sec. 34-1. - Discount for advance payment of ad valorem taxes. 
    The following discount shall be allowed for payment of ad valorem taxes prior to the due date of such taxes: 
 If paid on or before August 31 of the fiscal year for which the tax is levied, the discount shall be one percent. 
(Code 1987, § 23-1; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 1, 7-18-2006) 
Chapter 36 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; utilities, ch. 40. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 36-1-36-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 regulates certain aspects of cable television and may supersede certain provisions of this article. 
State Law reference- Theft of services, G.S. 14-118.5; cable television franchises, G.S. 160A-319; franchise tax, G.S. 160A-214. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Basic subscriber television service means service tiers which include the delivery of broadcast signals, public, educational and government access channels, and local origination channels, covered by the regular monthly charge paid by all subscribers. 
    Cablecast signal means a nonbroadcast signal that originates within the facilities of the cable communications system. 
    Cable communications system, cable system or system, means a system of antennas, cables, amplifiers, towers, microwave links, cablecasting studios and any other conductors, converters, equipment or facilities designed and constructed for the purpose of distributing video programming to home subscribers and/or producing, receiving, amplifying, storing, processing or distributing audio, video, digital or other forms of electronic or electrical signals sold or distributed to subscribers. Such term shall not include any similar facility that serves only the residents of one or more apartment or multifamily dwellings or condominiums under common ownership, control or management, nor other closed circuit systems for industrial, commercial or similar use to which the general public may not subscribe as long as the public streets or rights-of-way are not utilized in the provision of such service or interconnection of such facilities. 
    Channel means a six megahertz (MHz) frequency band, which is capable of carrying either one standard video signal, a number of audio, digital or other nonvideo signals or some combination of such signals. One channel of high definition television will utilize more than six MHz. 
    Closed circuit or institutional service means such video, audio, data and other services provided to institutional users on an individual application basis, including, but are not limited to, one-way video, two-way video and audio or digital signals among institutions to residential subscribers. 
    Commercial subscriber means a subscriber who receives a service in a place of business where the service may be utilized in connection with a business, trade or profession. 
    Communications Policy Act or cable act means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 as it may be amended or succeeded. 
    Complaint means a subscriber contact or inquiry regarding the grantee's service or picture quality and requiring some followup or investigation and resolution by a customer service representative or the cable television system's technical staff. Complaints will not include the contacts or inquiries by subscribers which are resolved on the telephone with the subscriber at the time of the contact or inquiry or the contacts or inquiries regarding programming or rates. 
    Converter means an electronic device which converts signals to a frequency not susceptible to interference within the television receiver of a subscriber, and any channel selector which permits a subscriber to view all signals delivered at designated converter dial locations at the set or by remote control. 
    Dedicated institutional access channels means broadband communications channels dedicated to serving town, county, state or federal governmental agencies, educational institutions, health care institutions or other nonprofit and profitmaking organizations that may be qualified by the council. 
    Discrete channel means a channel which can only be received by the person and/or institution intended to receive signals on such channel. 
    Drop means a coaxial connection from feeder cable to the subscriber/user television set, radio or other terminal. 
    Educational access channel means any channel designated for educational access use. 
    Fair market value means the price that a willing buyer would pay to a willing seller for a going concern based on the system valuation prevailing in the industry at the time. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission and any legally appointed successor. 
    Franchise means the nonexclusive rights granted pursuant to this article to construct, operate and maintain a cable communications system along the public ways within the city as specified in the franchise. Any such authorization, in whatever form granted, shall not mean or include any license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within the city as required by other ordinances and laws of the city. 
    Franchise area means the entire city, or portions thereof, for which a franchise is granted under the authority of this agreement. If not otherwise stated in the franchise, the franchise area shall be the corporate limits of the city, including all territory thereafter annexed to the city. 
    Franchise fee means an amount equal to the percentage, as specified by the city, of the grantee's gross revenues from all sources payable in exchange for the rights granted pursuant to this article and the franchise. 
    Government access channel means any channel specifically designated or dedicated for government access use. 
    Grantee means the natural persons, partnerships, domestic and foreign corporations, associations, joint ventures or organizations of any kind which have been legally granted a franchise by the city, and their lawful successor, transferee or assignee. 
    Grantor means the City of Laurinburg as represented by the city council acting within the scope of its jurisdiction. 
    Gross annual revenue means all revenue received, directly or indirectly, from the operation of the cable system, as permitted in the cable act, by the grantee, its affiliates, subsidiaries and any person in which the grantee has a financial interest. 
    Installation means the connection of the system from feeder cable to the subscribers' terminals. 
    Leased access channel or commercial access channel means any channel designated or dedicated for use by persons unaffiliated with the grantee in accordance with section 612 of the cable act. 
    Monitoring means observing a communications signal, or the absence of a signal, where the observer is not a party to the communication, whether the signal is observed by visual or electronic means, for any purpose whatsoever. 
    Narrowcasting means the ability to distribute cable programming to a particular segment of the cable subscribers. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, association, organization, corporation or any lawful successor transferee of such individual, partnership, association, organization or corporation. 
    Plant mile means a linear mile of cable as measured on the street or easement from pole to pole or pedestal to pedestal. 
    Public access channel means any channel designated or dedicated for use by the general public or noncommercial organizations, which is made available for use without charge in accordance with the rules and regulations specified in the franchise. 
    Public way or public rights-of-way means the surface, air space above the surface and area below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway, waterway, utility easement or other public right-of-way or held by the city which shall entitle the city and the grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining the grantee cable television system. No reference in this article, or in any franchise, to the "public way" shall be deemed to be a representation or guarantee by the city that its title to any property is sufficient to permit its use for such purpose, and the grantee shall, by its use of such term, be deemed to gain only such rights to use property in the city as the city may have the undisputed right and power to give. 
    Reasonable notice means a written notice addressed to the grantee at its principal office within the city or such other office as the grantee has designated to the city as the address to which notice shall be transmitted to it, which notice shall be certified and postmarked not less than seven days prior to the day in which the party giving such notice shall commence any action which requires the giving of notice. Holidays recognized by the city shall be excluded in computing such seven days. 
    Resident means any person residing in the city, as otherwise defined by applicable law. 
    Residential subscriber means a subscriber who receives the grantee's service in an individual dwelling unit where such service is not to be utilized in connection with a business, trade or profession. 
    Sale includes any sale, exchange, barter or offer for sale. 
    School means any public or nonprofit educational institution, including primary and secondary schools, colleges and universities, both public and private. 
    Service area means the entire geographic area within the franchise territory. 
    System facilities or facilities means the cable communications system constructed for use within the city, without limitation, the headend, antenna, cables, wires, lines, towers, amplifiers, converters, health and property security systems, equipment or facilities located within the corporate limits of the city designed, constructed or wired for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying and distributing by coaxial cable, fiber optics, microwave or other means, audio and visual radio, television and electronic signals to and from subscribers in the city, and any other equipment or facilities located within the corporate limits of the city intended for the use of the system; provided, however, such system facility excludes buildings, contracts, facilities and equipment where primary use is for providing service to other system facilities located outside the city limits. 
    Transfer means the disposal by the grantee, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, voluntary sale, merger, consolidation or otherwise, of 15 percent or more at one time of the ownership or controlling interest in the system, or 25 percent cumulatively over the term of the franchise of such interests to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust or association, or person or group of persons acting in concert; provided, however, that: 
(1)  If the persons who presently control the grantee, including affiliated trusts and the estates of any such persons and members of the family of any such persons, remain in control of the grantee after any such transfer, such action shall not be deemed to be a transfer or taken into account in determining whether there has been a transfer for the purposes of this definition or section 36-73; 
(2)  Purchases and sales over a securities exchange or in the over-the-counter market or those over which the persons in control of the grantee do not exercise any control shall not be, or be deemed to be, a transfer or taken into account in determining whether there has been a transfer for the purposes of this definition or section 36-73; 
(3)  No grant, transfer or assignment by persons who presently control the grantee to a lending institution as security for any indebtedness or other obligations shall be, or be deemed to be, a transfer for the purposes of this definition or section 36-73. 
    Trunk line means the major distribution cable used in cable communications, which divides into feeder lines which are tapped for service to subscribers. 
    Upstream signal means a signal originating from a terminal to another point in the cable television system, including video, audio or digital signals for either programs or other uses, such as security alert services, etc. 
    User means a person or organization utilizing channel or equipment and facilities for the purpose of producing and/or transmitting material, as contrasted with receipt thereof in a subscriber capacity. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-23) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-32. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city finds that the development of cable television and communications systems has the potential of having great benefit and impact upon the people of the city. Because of the complex and rapidly changing technology associated with cable television, the city further finds that the public convenience, safety and general welfare can best be served by establishing regulatory powers which should be vested in the city or such persons as the city shall designate. It is the intent of this article and subsequent amendments to provide for and specify the means to attain the best possible public interest and public purpose in these matters and any franchise issued pursuant to this article shall be deemed to include this finding as an integral part thereof. 
(b)  It is further recognized that cable communications systems have the capacity to provide not only entertainment and information services to the city's residents, but can provide a variety of broadband, interactive communications services to institutions and individuals. Many of these services involve city agencies and other public institutions, by providing governmental, educational or health care communications. 
(c)  For such purposes, the following goals underlie the regulations contained in this article: 
(1)  Communications services should be provided to the maximum number of city residents. 
(2)  The system should be capable of accommodating both the present and reasonably foreseeable future communications needs of the city. 
(3)  The system should be improved and upgraded during the franchise term so that the new facilities necessary for the operation of the system shall be integrated, to the maximum extent possible, with existing facilities. 
(4)  The communications system authorized by this article shall be responsive to the needs and interests of the local community, and shall provide the widest possible diversity of information sources and services to the public. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-21) 
Sec. 36-33. - Public notice. 
    Minimum public notice of any public meeting relating to this article or the franchise shall be by: 
(1)  Publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area at least seven days prior to the meeting; 
(2)  Posting at city hall; 
(3)  Announcement on at least one local origination channel of the grantee's cable communications system between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. for five consecutive days prior to the meeting. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-24) 
Sec. 36-34. - Franchise applications. 
    Applicants for a franchise shall submit written applications to the city, utilizing the standard format provided by the city, at the time and place designated by the city for accepting applications and including the designated application fee. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-25) 
Secs. 36-35-36-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRANT OF FRANCHISE 

Sec. 36-61. - Obligation; terms and conditions; conflicts. 
(a)  If the city shall grant to the grantee a nonexclusive, revocable franchise to construct, operate and maintain a cable communications system within the city, such franchise shall constitute both a right and an obligation to provide the services of a cable communications system as regulated by the provisions of this article and the franchise. The franchise shall include such provisions of the grantee's application for a franchise that are finally negotiated and accepted by the city and grantee. 
(b)  The franchise shall be granted under the terms and conditions contained in this division, consistent with the city's Charter and/or other applicable statutory requirements. In the event of conflict between the terms and conditions of this article and the franchise, or the terms and conditions on which the city can grant a franchise, this article or the laws of the state shall control. 
(c)  Any franchise granted by the city is hereby made subject to the general article provisions in effect, provided that any ordinance which is made effective or which is amended after the grant of a franchise shall not diminish the rights or increase the obligations of the grantee under such franchise. Nothing in the franchise shall be deemed to waive the requirements of the various codes and ordinances of the city regarding permits, fees to be paid or manner of construction. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-41) 
Sec. 36-62. - Franchise area. 
    The franchise area shall be the entire city, or portions thereof, for which a franchise is granted. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-42) 
Sec. 36-63. - Service area. 
(a)  The grantee shall offer full cable television service to all areas of the city which are within the corporate limits of the city as of the effective date of the franchise, in accordance with the timetable specified in the franchise. 
(b)  For new dwelling units within the corporate limits of the city, including all territories annexed by the city, the grantee shall extend full cable service within six months of the request in an area with a density equivalent to at least 20 dwelling units per mile. 
(c)  In other areas with less than 20 residential dwelling units per proposed mile, the grantee shall offer a cost sharing arrangement with residents. A dwelling unit will be counted for such purpose if its lot fronts a street. The cost sharing arrangement shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Upon the request of a subscriber desiring service, the grantee shall prepare, at its cost, an engineering survey and cost analysis to determine the cost of the plant extension required to provide service to the subscriber from the closest point on the cable system. 
(2)  The cost of construction shall be allocated based on the following formula: 
If a request for extension of service into a residential area requires the construction of a cable plant which does not pass at least 20 potential subscribers per mile, the grantee and subscribers will each bear their proportionate share of construction costs. For example, if there are ten dwelling units per mile, the grantee's share will equal 10/20 or one-half of the construction cost. The remaining cost will be shared equally by each subscriber. Such line extension formula shall also be applied to a portion of a mile meeting proportionate density requirements. For example, if there are ten dwelling units per one-half mile, the grantee shall construct the plant. Such cost sharing plan would be utilized if there were less than the proportionate share of dwelling units per the portion of a mile needed to reach the dwelling units. 
(3)  Subscribers utilizing the cost sharing plan for extensions shall be reimbursed pro rata for their contribution, or a proportional share thereof, should additional subscribers to the respective network extension request cable television service. In such case, the pro rata shares shall be recalculated and each new subscriber shall pay the new pro rata share, and all prior subscribers shall receive pro rata refunds. At such time as there are 20 potential subscribers per mile, the subscribers shall receive their pro rata share of construction costs. In any event, at the end of one year from the completion of a project, the subscribers are no longer eligible for refunds, and the amounts paid in construction costs will be credited to the plant account of the grantee. 
(4)  The average cost of line extension shall be recalculated annually and based upon the current costs for labor and materials at that time. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-43) 
Sec. 36-64. - Use of public rights-of-way.
