(c)  System monitor test points shall be established at or near the output of the last amplifier in the longest feeder line, at or near trunk line extremities. Such periodic tests shall be made at the test points as shall be required by the FCC and/or the franchise. 
(d)  In addition to the performance test reports required in this section, a copy of any performance test reports required by the FCC shall be submitted to the city within 60 days of completion. 
(e)  Whenever there have been more than five similar complaints made, or when there exists other evidence, which, in the judgment of the city, casts doubt on the reliability or quality of the grantee's system, the city shall have the right and authority to compel the grantee to test, analyze and report on the performance of its system. The city may require additional tests, full or partial repeat tests, different test procedures or tests involving a specific subscriber's terminal. Reports on such tests shall be delivered to the city no later than 14 days after the city formally notifies the grantee and shall include the following information: 
(1)  What system component was tested; 
(2)  The equipment used and procedures employed in such testing; 
(3)  The results of such tests; and 
(4)  Methods by which such complaints were resolved. 
Such tests and analyses shall be supervised by the grantee's regional engineer, who shall sign all records of the special tests and forward such records to the city, with a report interpreting the results of the tests and recommending what actions should be taken by the city. All such tests shall be at the expense of the grantee. 
(f)  The city shall have the right to employ qualified consultants, if necessary or desirable, to assist in the administration of this section or any other section of this article or the franchise. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-118) 
Secs. 36-149-36-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SERVICE PROVISIONS 

Sec. 36-171. - Services to subscribers and users. 
(a)  Generally. Concurrently with the activation of the cable communications system in the city, the grantee shall provide all services to subscribers as described in this division and in the franchise. 
(1)  The system shall carry the broad categories of programming and services listed in the franchise. Should the grantee desire to change the selection of programs or services offered on any of its tiers, it shall maintain the mix, quality and level of services provided over the system. Any such change in programs or services offered shall comply with the conditions and procedures contained in the franchise, and shall be reported to the city at least 30 days prior to the proposed implementation. The grantee shall use its best efforts to ensure diversity of programming. 
(2)  A basic service tier shall be offered to subscribers throughout the term of this article and the franchise. 
(3)  The grantee shall provide and maintain, at a minimum, the following access channels, for the following purposes: 
a.  Government access channel, which shall be a specifically designated channel for governmental use and shall be shared with the county and managed, scheduled and programmed by the city in cooperation with the county. 
b.  Educational channel, which will be a specifically designated channel for use by public and private school authorities of the city and county, and shall be managed, scheduled and programmed by the city in cooperation with the county. 
c.  Public access channel, which will be a specifically designated channel, available on a nondiscriminatory, shared basis between subscribers in the city and the county. 
(4)  In accordance with the cable act, the grantee shall make leased access channels available to ensure that the widest possible diversity of information sources are made available to subscribers. 
a.  Such channels shall be specially designated for leased access use by persons unaffiliated with the grantee, at rates which are fair and reasonable. 
b.  The number of such channels shall be determined by the provisions of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 or other applicable federal or state law. Notwithstanding changes in applicable law, the grantee shall make available at least one leased access channel, or a reasonable number of such channels as determined by the city, throughout the life of the franchise to accommodate persons seeking leased access. The grantee shall periodically advertise the availability of such channels. 
c.  The grantee shall not exercise any editorial control over any programming provided over such channels, except that the grantee may consider such content to the minimum extent necessary to establish a fair and reasonable price for the use of such channels. 
(5)  The grantee shall fully provide, at a minimum, services, facilities and equipment for public, educational and government access as indicated in the franchise. 
(b)  Emergency transmission facilities. The grantee shall, without charge, provide, service and maintain public emergency transmission facilities to the city, as described in the franchise. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-131) 
Sec. 36-172. - Installations, connections and other grantee services. 
(a)  Standard installations. Standard installation shall consist of a service drop not exceeding 150 feet from the closest point on the cable system to the customer's residence, in accordance with section 36-144. For drops exceeding 150 feet, the grantee shall pay for the first 150 feet and may charge the subscriber for any additional feet at cost. The subscriber's desired point of entry into the residence shall be observed, whenever feasible. Runs in building interiors shall be as unobtrusive as possible. The grantee shall use due care in the process of installation and shall repair any damage to the subscriber's property caused by such installation. Such restoration shall be undertaken within no more than ten days after the damage is incurred and shall be completed as soon as possible thereafter. 
(b)  Deposits. Any deposit required by the grantee shall bear interest at a rate of not less than the annual one-year treasury bill rate and shall be promptly refunded upon termination of related service or return of related equipment. 
(c)  Antennas and antenna switches. The grantee shall not, as a condition to providing cable communications service, require any subscriber or potential subscriber to remove any existing antenna structures for the receipt of over-the-air television signals. The grantee shall install, upon the request of the subscriber, an RF or antenna switch, where required for the provision of services provided by the grantee. 
(d)  Parental control. The grantee shall provide to the potential subscriber, as part of its promotional literature, information concerning the availability of a lockout device for use by a subscriber. 
(e)  Reconnection. The grantee shall restore service to customers wishing restoration of service, provided, the customer shall first satisfy any previous obligations owed. 
(f)  Disconnection. Disconnection of cable service shall be made as soon as practicable and in no case later than 15 days following notice thereof to the grantee. A refund of unused service charges shall be paid to the customer within 30 days from the date of termination of service. 
(g)  Delinquent accounts. The grantee shall use its best efforts to collect on delinquent subscriber accounts. In all cases, the grantee shall provide the customer with at least ten days' written notice prior to disconnection. 
(h)  Prohibited activities. In the conduct of its business franchised under this article, neither the grantee, nor its officers, employees or agents shall directly or indirectly sell, lease, repair, install or maintain television sets or receivers, or antennas; provided, however, that nothing under this subsection shall prohibit the grantee, at the customer's request and without payment, from examining or adjusting the customer's receiving set to determine whether reception difficulties originate in the set or in the grantee's system. 
(i)  Advance charges and deposits. A grantee may require subscribers to pay the installation charge in advance and to pay for each month of basic service in advance at the beginning of each month. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit charges for, or a waiver of charges for, initial installation or reconnection. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-132) 
Sec. 36-173. - Service calls and complaint procedures. 
(a)  The grantee shall establish, operate and maintain a business office and maintenance and repair facility within the city for the purpose of receiving inquiries, requests and complaints concerning all aspects of the construction, installation, operation and maintenance of the system and for the payment of subscribers' service charges. 
(b)  The grantee shall have a listed, locally staffed telephone number for service calls, and such telephone service shall be available from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. A staffed answering service or equivalent shall be available at all other times. Such telephone number shall be made available to subscribers and the general public. The grantee shall provide an unlisted locally staffed telephone number to the city and utility companies to enable the city or utility companies to reach the grantee in case of an emergency on a 24-hour, seven days a week basis. 
(c)  The grantee shall respond to and resolve subscribers' complaints or requests for service in connection with repairs, maintenance and malfunctions of system facilities. The grantee shall respond as quickly as possible to such complaints and requests, but shall, in any case, respond within 24 hours. Complaints or requests which may pose a potential health and safety hazard will be responded to immediately. The grantee shall respond within seven business days to billing complaints. 
(d)  The grantee shall prepare and file with the city copies of all of its rules and regulations in connection with the handling of inquiries, requests and complaints. The grantee shall, by appropriate means, such as a card or brochure, furnish information concerning the procedures for making inquiries or complaints, including the name, address and local telephone number of the employee or agent to whom such inquiries or complaints are to be addressed, and furnish information concerning the city office responsible for the administration of the franchise, including, but not limited to, the address and telephone number of such office. 
(e)  The grantee shall keep full records in connection with all inquiries, complaints and requests in connection with the system. Such records shall identify the person contacting the grantee and the person responding on behalf of the grantee, the subject matter of the contact, the date and time it was received, the resolution of the matter in question or the action taken by the grantee in connection with the contact and the date and time thereof, and such other information as may be deemed pertinent by the grantee. The records shall be made available, as allowed by the cable act, for periodic inspection by the city. 
(f)  For recurrent complaints regarding service deficiencies, other than total or partial loss of service, such as ghosting, weak audio signal, distortion, etc., the city manager may require the grantee to investigate and report to him the causes and cures thereof, and the city manager may also conduct his own investigation. Thereafter, the city manager may order specified remedial action to be taken within reasonably feasible time limits. If such action is not taken or is ineffective, or if, within 30 days, the grantee files with the city council a notice of objection to the order, the city council may conduct a hearing and may, if the evidence warrants a finding of fault on the part of the grantee, take appropriate action pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(g)  The grantee shall, without charge for installation, maintenance or service, excluding premium services, make single installations of its cable communications service facilities to the public buildings operated by units of local government when the building is located on the grantee's system when the system is constructed consistent with the requirements of this article. Such provision excludes service to any housing developments the city may own. Such installations shall be made at such reasonable locations as shall be requested by the chief administrative officer of the unit involved. Additional installations at the same location may be made at normal charge. No monthly service charges shall be made for distribution of all of the grantee's services, excluding premium services, within such publicly owned buildings. In addition, the grantee shall, without charge for installation, maintenance or service, make single installations of its standard community service facilities at any other city owned facility identified in the franchise. No monthly service charge shall be made for distribution of all of the grantee's services, excluding premium services, for such facilities. Further, no installation to any of the locations shall be made until such installation is requested, in writing, by the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-133) 
Sec. 36-174. - Continuity of service. 
(a)  Subscribers' right. It shall be the right of all subscribers to receive continuous, uninterrupted service insofar as such subscribers' financial and other obligations to the grantee are honored. 
(b)  Failure to perform. If the grantee fails to operate the system for seven consecutive days, without prior approval of the city or without just cause, the city may, at its option, operate the system or designate an operator until such time as the grantee restores service under conditions acceptable to the city or a permanent operator is selected. If the city is required to fulfill such obligation for the grantee, the grantee shall reimburse the city for all reasonable costs or damages in excess of revenues from the system received by the city that are the result of the grantee's failure to perform. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-134) 
Sec. 36-175. - Protection of subscriber privacy. 
(a)  Required. The grantee shall at all times protect the privacy of subscribers, as provided in this article, the cable act, federal laws and other applicable and consistent state and local laws. 
(b)  Notice of privacy provisions. At the time of entering into an agreement to provide any cable service or other service to a subscriber, and at least once a year thereafter, the grantee shall provide notice, in the form of a separate written statement, to the subscriber, which clearly and conspicuously informs the subscriber of the: 
(1)  Privacy rights of the subscriber and the limitations placed upon the grantee with regard to this division and all other applicable federal laws or consistent state and local subscriber privacy provisions; 
(2)  Nature of personally identifiable information collected, or to be collected, with respect to the subscriber and the nature of the use of such information; 
(3)  Nature, frequency and purpose of any disclosure which may be made of such information, including an identification of the types of persons to whom the disclosure may be made; 
(4)  Period during which such information might be maintained by the cable operator; 
(5)  Times and places at which the subscriber may have access to such information in accordance with this article and other applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(c)  Disclosure of subscriber information. The grantee shall not, without the specific written authorization of the individual subscribers involved, sell or otherwise make available to any party any list of the names and addresses of individual subscribers, any list which identifies the viewing habits of individual subscribers, or any personal data, social security number, income and other data the company may have on file about individual subscribers, except as necessary to render or conduct a legitimate business activity related to a cable service or other service provided by the cable operator to the subscriber, provided however that such disclosure shall not reveal directly or indirectly the extent of viewing or other use by the subscriber of a cable service or other service provided by the cable operator, or the nature of any transaction made by the subscriber over the cable system. 
(d)  Revocation of permission. The grantee shall not predicate regular subscriber service on the subscriber's grant or denial of permission to collect, maintain or disclose personally identifiable information. A subscriber may at any time revoke any permission previously given by delivering to the grantee a written statement of such intent. 
(e)  Subscriber access. Each subscriber shall be provided access to all personally identifiable information regarding such subscriber that the grantee collects or maintains, or allows to be collected or maintained, and such subscriber shall be provided the opportunity to correct any error in such information. 
(f)  Control and measurement of system performance. This section is not intended to prohibit the use or transmission of signals useful only for the control or measurement of system performance. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-135) 
Sec. 36-176. - Rights of individuals. 
(a)  Nondiscrimination required. The grantee shall not deny service or access, or otherwise discriminate against subscribers, channel users or general citizens on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, age, sex, or physical or mental handicap, provided, the subscriber shall pay all applicable fees for the service desired. The grantee shall comply at all times with all other applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, and all executive and administrative orders relating to nondiscrimination which are hereby incorporated and made part of this article by reference. 
(b)  Fairness of accessibility. The entire system of the grantee shall be operated in a manner consistent with the principles of fairness and equal accessibility of its facilities, equipment, channels, studios and other services to all citizens, businesses, public agencies and other entities having a legitimate use for the network, and no person shall be arbitrarily excluded from its use. The allocation of use of such facilities shall be made according to the rules or decisions of the grantee and any regulatory agencies affecting the use. 
(c)  Information accessibility. 
(1)  Each individual shall have the right to information concerning the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations formulated pursuant to this article by the city council, the grantee, agent or entity created under or pursuant to this article. The location and hours of operation for the delivery of such information shall be published in the newspaper of the greatest circulation within the city and in such other media as the city council may determine. 
(2)  Each individual subscribing to the services of the cable communications system, leasing channels thereof or using the access channels shall be provided with a memorandum setting forth all rules and regulations specifically outlining such individual rights pertinent to such use. All rights specifically provided in this section shall be noted. 
(3)  Such information as may be prescribed in this section will be made available to the public and individual subscribers in such form required for understanding, including the deaf and blind, and in such languages as may be specified by the city council. 
(4)  Each document required to be maintained, prepared, filed or submitted under the provisions of this article or pursuant to it, except the documents required and designated as confidential by the Federal Communications Commission, is a public document, available for public inspection and copying at the requestor's expense, at the office of the grantee or the city during normal business hours. The charge for such copying shall approximate the cost of mechanical reproduction and shall not include a charge for labor. 
(5)  Each individual shall have the right to representation on such boards, commissions, agencies or other entities created by the city council pursuant to the provisions of this article. Such representation by citizens of the city shall be in the manner and form as the city council may determine, ensuring equal participation of all protected groups. The grantee shall strictly adhere to the equal employment opportunity requirements of federal, state and local regulations, as may be applicable, and as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-136) 
Secs. 36-177-36-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - BOOKS, RECORDS AND REPORTS 

Sec. 36-201. - Office required within franchise territory; right of inspection of books and records. 
(a)  The grantee shall maintain an office within the franchise territory. The city's duly authorized agent shall have the right to inspect at any time, upon reasonable notice, during normal business hours, all books, records, maps, plans, income tax returns, financial statements, service complaint logs, performance test results and other like materials of the grantee and/or grantee's parent company which relate directly to the operation of the franchise. Subject to applicable law, including, but not limited to, laws concerning subscriber privacy, access by the city to such records shall not be denied by the grantee on the basis that such records contain confidential or proprietary information; however, confidential or proprietary information shall be held in confidence by the city and not disclosed to any third party. 
(b)  The grantee shall permit any duly authorized representative of the city to examine and copy or transcribe any and all maps and other records kept or maintained by the grantee or under its control concerning the operations, affairs, transactions or property of the grantee directly related to this article and the franchise. If any such maps or records are not kept in the city, or upon reasonable request made available in the city, and if the city shall determine that an examination of such maps or records is necessary or appropriate to the performance of any of their duties, then all travel and maintenance expenses necessarily incurred in making such examination shall be paid by the grantee. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-151) 
Sec. 36-202. - Reports required. 
    The grantee shall file the following with the city: 
(1)  Facilities report. If there is some change in the facilities of the cable system, an annual report setting forth the physical miles of plant construction and plant in operation during the fiscal year shall be submitted to the city. Such report shall also contain any revisions to the system as-built maps filed with the city. 
(2)  Construction reports. Construction reports shall be sent quarterly to the city after the franchise is awarded and until construction is completed as specified in section 36-147(a) and (b). 
(3)  Proof of performance tests. Proof of performance test results shall be supplied to the city when sections of the system are rebuilt and annually as required in section 36-148(b) and (e). 
(4)  Tests required by city. Tests required by the city as specified in section 36-148(e) shall be submitted within 14 days of notification. 
(5)  Change in service. A report on any removal or addition of programming or service shall be provided to the city 30 days prior to implementation of such change. 
(6)  Proof of bonds and insurance. The grantee shall submit to the city the required performance bond, or a certified copy thereof, and written evidence of payment of the required premium, and all policies of insurance required by this article, or certified copies or a certificate thereof, and written notice of payment of the required premium. 
(7)  Financial and ownership reports. The following financial and ownership reports for the franchise area shall be submitted to the city: 
a.  An annual ownership report, indicating all persons who, to the grantee's knowledge, at any time during the preceding year, did control or benefit from an interest in the franchise, in excess of five percent. 
b.  Prior to transfer, renewal, extension and at three additional times during the franchise period, upon the request of the city, a fully audited and certified financial report from the previous calendar year, including the: 
1.  Year end balance sheet; 
2.  Income statement showing subscriber revenue from each category of service and every source of nonsubscriber revenue, line item operating expenses, depreciation expense, interest expense and taxes paid; 
3.  Statement of sources and applications of funds; and 
4.  Depreciation schedule. 
c.  A current statement of all capital expenditures, including the cost of construction and equipment, upon the request of the city. 
d.  An annual list of officers and members of the board of the grantee and of any parent corporation. 
(8)  Operational reports. The following system and operational reports shall be submitted to the city: 
a.  A report on the system's technical tests and measurements as set forth in this article and the franchise. 
b.  A report on leased access programs and services offered by the grantee, upon request of the city. 
c.  An annual summary of the previous year's activities, including, but not limited to, subscriber totals for each category of service offered, including the number of pay units sold, new services offered and the amount collected annually from other users of the system, and the character and extent of the service rendered thereto. 
d.  An annual summary of complaints received and handled, in addition to any reports required in the franchise. 
e.  An annual projection of system and service plans for the future, upon request of the city. 
(9)  Additional reports. The grantee shall prepare and furnish to the city, at the times and in the form prescribed, such additional reports with respect to its operation, affairs, transactions or property, as may be reasonably necessary and appropriate to the performance of any of the rights, functions or duties of the city in connection with this article or the franchise. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-152) 
Sec. 36-203. - Reports to be provided on request. 
    The grantee shall provide the following information or report, upon request by the city: 
(1)  Regulatory communications. Upon request, all reports required by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), including Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) reports, and all petitions, applications and communications of all types submitted by the grantee to the FCC, the Security and Exchange Commission (SEC) or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction over any matter affecting operation of the grantee's system shall be simultaneously submitted to the city by delivery to the city clerk, who shall advise interested city departments of such filing. 
(2)  Filing of grantee's rules, regulations, terms and conditions. The grantee's contract or application forms of the regular subscriber service policy regarding the processing of subscriber complaints, delinquent subscriber disconnect and reconnect procedures, and any other terms and conditions adopted as the grantee's policy in connection with its subscribers shall be filed with the city and conspicuously posted in the grantee's local office. All such terms and conditions must have been filed with the city prior to the terms and conditions becoming effective. Such rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions of this article or applicable state and federal laws, rules or regulations. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-154) 
Sec. 36-204. - Records required. 
(a)  Maintenance. The grantee shall maintain the following at all times: 
(1)  A record of all complaints received and interruptions or degradation of service experience for the preceding period prior to a performance review. 
(2)  A full and complete set of plans, records and as-built maps showing the exact location of all cable communications system equipment installed or in use in the city, exclusive of subscriber service drops. 
(3)  A comprehensive record of all personnel transactions and utilization of contractors, subcontractors, vendors and suppliers by race and sex. 
(b)  Requests for additional information. The city may impose reasonable requests for additional information, records and documents from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 6.5-154) 
Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance pertaining to traffic or parking regulations applying to specific streets saved from repeal, § 1-6(10); restriction of motor vehicles and other vehicles; responsibility for damages, § 10-174; abandoned, nuisance and junked motor vehicles, § 16-101 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 22; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 24; transporting solid waste generally, § 30-7; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; vehicles for hire, ch. 44. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, G.S. ch. 20; powers of local authorities, G.S. 20-169; traffic control by municipalities, G.S. 160A-300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means a vehicle of the fire department, a police vehicle and any ambulance or rescue squad designated or authorized by the chief of police. 
    Block means a portion of any street located between two intersections adjacent to each other. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to a highway when 75 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Crosswalk means the portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of the lateral lines of sidewalks at intersections or any portion of a roadway distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Driver means a person in actual physical control of a vehicle which is in motion or which has the engine running. The terms "operator" and "driver" and their cognates are synonymous. 
    Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral edge of roadway lines of two or more highways which join one another at any angle, whether or not one such highway crosses the other. Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. If such intersecting highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Moped means a vehicle having two or three wheels and operable pedals and equipped with a motor which does not exceed 50 cubic centimeters piston displacement and cannot propel the vehicle at a speed greater than 20 miles per hour on a level surface. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle designed to run upon the highways which is pulled by a self-propelled vehicle. Such term shall not include mopeds. 
    Official traffic control devices means all signs, signals, markings and devices, not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the city council or city official having jurisdiction for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Official traffic signal means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Operator means a person in actual physical control of a vehicle which is in motion or which has the engine running. The terms "operator" and "driver" and their cognates are synonymous. 
    Park means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police officer means any officer of the police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway means any road or driveway not open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
    Residential district means the territory contiguous to a highway not comprising a business district, where 75 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is mainly occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Roadway means the portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulder. If a highway includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway," as used in this chapter, shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or marked or indicated by adequate signs so as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Sidewalk means the portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Standing means any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Stop, when stopping is required, means complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop and standing mean any stopping of a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Street and highway mean the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for purposes of travel. 
    Vehicle means any device in, upon or by which any person or property is, or may be, transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, provided that for the purpose of this chapter, a bicycle or a ridden animal shall be deemed to be a vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, G.S. 20-4.01. 
Sec. 38-2. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden in this chapter or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 25-2) 
Sec. 38-3. - Obedience to police officers required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction made or given by a police officer pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 25-3) 
Sec. 38-4. - Direction of traffic in emergency. 
    In the event of a fire or other emergency or when necessary to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, police officers of the city may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 25-4) 
Sec. 38-5. - Pushcarts, bicycles and animals. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except the provisions of this chapter which, by their very nature, can have no application. 
(Code 1987, § 25-5) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 4. 
State Law reference- Application of traffic laws to persons riding animals or driving animal-drawn vehicles, G.S. 20-171. 
Sec. 38-6. - Government owned vehicles. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government or this state or any other state, county or municipality. It shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any such provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statutes. 
(Code 1987, § 25-6) 
State Law reference- Drivers of state, county and city vehicles subject to traffic control law, G.S. 20-168. 
Sec. 38-7. - Exemptions for authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles, except as enumerated in this section. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when operating such vehicle in any emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: 
(1)  Park or stand, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits as long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions as long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(c)  The exemptions in this section shall not, however, protect the driver of any such authorized emergency vehicle from the consequence of his reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Code 1987, § 25-7) 
State Law reference- Exception of speed limit for emergency vehicles, G.S. 20-145; exceptions to right-of-way rule, G.S. 20-156. 
Sec. 38-8. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  The provisions of this section apply to: 
(1)  All operators of funeral homes located within the corporate limits of the city and all funeral directors and all agents and employees of such funeral homes; 
(2)  All funeral processions passing through the city, which are directed or organized by the operator of any funeral home located within the city or within one mile outside the city, any funeral director or any agent or employee of such funeral home, whether the processions originate at the funeral home or at any church or other place, whether within or without the city limits. 
(b)  Every operator, director, agent or employee of any funeral home within the corporate limits of the city or within one mile outside the corporate limits shall cause any funeral procession at any funeral directed by such operator, director or employee proceeding through or along the streets of the city to any cemetery, whether located within or without the city, to follow a route previously designated by the chief of police. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as provided by section 1-10. 
(Code 1987, § 25-8) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate processions, G.S. 20-169. 
Sec. 38-9. - Boarding and alighting from vehicle in motion. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1987, § 25-9) 
Sec. 38-10. - Riding on vehicles not intended for passengers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any vehicle, or any portion thereof, not designed or intended for the use of passengers. Such provision shall not be construed to apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to persons riding within truck bodies in spaces intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1987, § 25-10) 
Sec. 38-11. - Entering, jumping on and riding vehicle without consent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter, jump on or ride any vehicle without the consent of the owner or driver of such vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-11) 
Sec. 38-12. - Passengers to stay inside vehicle; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, when riding in or upon any vehicle, to allow any part of his body to protrude beyond the limits of the vehicle in or upon which he is riding, except to give such signals as are required by law. 
(Code 1987, § 25-12) 
Sec. 38-13. - Number of persons allowed in front seat. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or person in charge of any motor vehicle to permit more than three persons, including the driver, to ride in the front seat or driver's seat of a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-13) 
State Law reference- Overloaded or overcrowded vehicle, G.S. 20-140.2. 
Sec. 38-14. - Riding on handlebars, frame or tank of motorcycles and bicycles. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motorcycle or bicycle, when upon any street of the city, to carry any person upon the handlebars, frame or tank of any such motorcycle or bicycle, and it shall be unlawful for any person to ride in such manner upon any such motorcycle or bicycle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-14) 
Sec. 38-15. - Riding bicycles on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk or public walkway within the central business district. 
(Code 1987, § 25-16) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
Sec. 38-16. - Clinging, hanging and attaching to moving vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cling or hang onto any moving vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or toy vehicle to attach such bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates, toy vehicle or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1987, § 25-17) 
Sec. 38-17. - Blocking flow of traffic on street by railroad. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or any person in charge of any locomotive or train to allow any locomotive or train to stand across any street of the city in such a manner as to block the normal flow of vehicular traffic for a period longer than five minutes. 
(Code 1987, § 25-18) 
Secs. 38-18-38-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to install, change and remove traffic control devices, G.S. 20-141, 20-158, 20-169, 136-31; yield signs, G.S. 20-158.1; types of traffic control devices which cities may install, G.S. 20-169. 

Sec. 38-51. - Obedience required; exceptions. 
    Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated on or by any sign, signal, marker or other official traffic control device erected or placed pursuant to the authority of the city council shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. This section shall not be construed to apply when the driver of a vehicle is otherwise directed by a police officer or when an exception is granted to the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle under section 38-7. 
(Code 1987, § 25-36) 
Sec. 38-52. - Prerequisites to enforcement. 
    No provision of this chapter for which traffic control signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged violation, an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section in this chapter does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective without signs being placed to give notice thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 25-37) 
Sec. 38-53. - Traffic control devices in place on effective date of this Code. 
    All traffic control devices installed by authority of the city council and which are in place on the effective date of this Code shall continue to be official until such time as they may be removed by authority of the city council. Until such traffic control devices are removed, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any instruction or directive indicated on or by any such official traffic control device. 
(Code 1987, § 25-38) 
Secs. 38-54-38-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- City's traffic control authority, G.S. 160A-300; operation of vehicles and rules of the road, G.S. 20-138.1 et seq. 

Sec. 38-81. - Maximum speed limits. 
    At no time shall any person drive a vehicle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then and there existing. It shall be unlawful to drive a vehicle in excess of the following speeds, except as otherwise provided by official traffic control signs in place along the streets: 
(1)  Twenty miles per hour in any business district. 
(2)  Thirty-five miles per hour in any residential district. 
(3)  Forty-five miles per hour in places other than as named in subsections (1) and (2) of this section for: 
a.  All vehicles other than passenger cars, regular passenger vehicles, pickup trucks of less than one-ton capacity and school buses loaded with children; 
b.  All vehicles, of whatever kind, which are engaged in towing, drawing or pushing another vehicle, provided that this subsection shall not apply to vehicles engaged in towing, drawing or pushing trailers with a gross weight of not more than 3,000 pounds. 
(4)  Fifty-five miles per hour in places other than as named in subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section for passenger cars, regular passenger carrying vehicles and pickup trucks of less than one-ton capacity. 
(Code 1987, § 25-46) 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions and authority of city to impose certain speed limits, G.S. 20-141, 20-158, 20-169. 
Sec. 38-82. - Entering a stop or yield intersection. 
(a)  Every driver of a vehicle, upon approaching a street intersection where an official traffic control sign has been placed, erected or installed indicating stop, shall bring his vehicle to a full stop, clear of the lines marking the outside limits of any pedestrian crosswalk, or in the absence of a marked crosswalk, clear of the boundary of such street intersection, and shall remain at a full stop until such time as he can enter the intersection without interfering with the progress of vehicles or pedestrians approaching from his right or left. 
(b)  Every driver of a vehicle, upon approaching a street intersection where an official traffic control sign has been placed, erected or installed indicating yield, shall approach such intersection with caution and shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from either direction on the intersected street. 
(Code 1987, § 25-47) 
Sec. 38-83. - One-way streets. 
    Wherever official traffic control signs are placed, erected or installed indicating that traffic shall move only in a certain direction, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction. 
(Code 1987, § 25-52) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- One-way traffic, G.S. 20-165.1. 
Sec. 38-84. - Duty of drivers upon approaching crosswalks. 
    Drivers of vehicles approaching a crosswalk shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian in the crosswalk and shall take all precautionary action necessary to avoid collision with any pedestrian. Any crosswalk which is posted with a sign that reads "Stop for pedestrian in crosswalk" shall bring his vehicle to a stop when a pedestrian is in the crosswalk. 
(Code 1987, § 25-56) 
Sec. 38-85. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle upon any sidewalk or within any sidewalk area, except at regularly constructed driveways. 
(Code 1987, § 25-57) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-160(b). 
Sec. 38-86. - Approach of emergency vehicles; following or parking near fire apparatus. 
(a)  Upon the approach of any police or fire department vehicle, ambulance or rescue squad vehicle giving audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle, the driver of every other vehicle shall immediately drive their vehicle to a position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or curb, clear of any intersection or highway, and shall stop and remain in such position, unless otherwise directed by a police or traffic officer, until the police or fire department vehicle, ambulance or rescue squad vehicle shall have passed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, to follow closer than one block to any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive into or park such person's vehicle within one block where such fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Code 1987, § 25-58) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-157(a), (b). 
Sec. 38-87. - Interfering with firefighting equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle over a fire hose or any other equipment that is being used at a fire at any time, or to block firefighting apparatus or any other equipment from its source of supply regardless of its distance from the fire. 
(Code 1987, § 25-59) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-157(d). 
Sec. 38-88. - Driving through funeral processions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle through a funeral procession, except fire department vehicles, police patrols and ambulances, when such vehicles are responding to calls. 
(Code 1987, § 25-60) 
State Law reference- Regulation of processions by city, G.S. 20-169. 
Sec. 38-89. - Zone of quiet. 
    Whenever official traffic control signs are placed, erected or installed indicating a zone of quiet, it shall be unlawful for any person within a motor vehicle within any such zone to sound the horn or other warning device of such vehicle, except in an emergency, or to use a radio or other sound emitting device, or otherwise to cause any noise which can be heard by persons of ordinary hearing beyond either sidewalk adjacent to the roadway. 
(Code 1987, § 25-61) 
Sec. 38-90. - Play streets. 
    Whenever official traffic control signs are placed, erected or installed indicating any street, or part thereof, as a play street, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle upon any such street, or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street, or portion thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 25-62) 
Sec. 38-91. - School zones. 
    Whenever official traffic control signs are placed, erected or installed indicating that any street, or part thereof, is a school zone, all drivers of motor vehicles using such street, or part thereof, shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon such street, or part thereof, for the protection of children. 
(Code 1987, § 25-63) 
Secs. 38-92-38-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Violations of city ordinances prohibiting parking, G.S. 14-4(b); authority of city to regulate, restrict and prohibit the parking of vehicles, G.S. 160A-301. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-121. - Stopping in street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver to stop a vehicle in any street, except for the purpose of parking as prescribed in this article, unless such stop is made necessary by the approach of an authorized emergency vehicle, funeral or other procession which is given the right-of-way; the stopping of a public conveyance; the lowering of railway gates; the giving of traffic signals; the passing of some other vehicle or a pedestrian; or some emergency. In any case covered by such exceptions, a vehicle shall be stopped in a manner so as not to obstruct any footway, pedestrian aisle, safety zone, crossing or street intersection, if such can be avoided. 
(Code 1987, § 25-81) 
State Law reference- Stopping on highway prohibited, G.S. 20-161. 
Sec. 38-122. - Interrupting passage of other vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park or stand such vehicle on any street so as to interrupt or interfere with the passage of other vehicles. 
(Code 1987, § 25-82) 
Sec. 38-123. - Prohibited in certain places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  Within an intersection; 
(3)  On a crosswalk; 
(4)  Within 30 feet of any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a street or roadway; 
(5)  On either side of any street approaching a railroad underpass or overhead bridge, or within 50 feet, in any direction, of the outer edge of such underpass or overhead bridge; 
(6)  On either side of any street approaching a grade crossing within 50 feet of the closest rail, provided that, where permanent structures are located along the street and closer than 50 feet, parking may be permitted in front of such structures, unless otherwise prohibited, if such parking does not interfere with the view in either direction of an approaching locomotive or train; 
(7)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction, when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(8)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure, or within any underpass structure; 
(9)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped, standing or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(10)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(11)  In front of a driveway or in a manner so as to block a driveway; 
(12)  At any place at which the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle is prohibited by an official traffic control device; 
(13)  At any place where the curb or street is painted yellow, except that a vehicle may be stopped at such place, not in excess of three minutes, for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1987, § 25-83) 
Sec. 38-124. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle upon any street for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale; 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
(3)  Storing of such vehicle by garages, dealers or other persons when such storing is not incident to the bona fide use and operation of such automobile or other vehicle; 
(4)  Storing of any detached trailer or van when the towing unit has been disconnected or for the purpose of transferring merchandise or freight from one vehicle to another; 
(5)  Advertising. 
(Code 1987, § 25-84) 
Sec. 38-125. - Vehicles backed to curb. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow a vehicle to remain backed up to the curb, except when actually loading or unloading. 
(Code 1987, § 25-85) 
Sec. 38-126. - Stopping vehicle with left side to curb. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop any vehicle with its left side to the curb in a business district, except that, on one-way streets, vehicles shall stop headed in the direction of traffic. 
(Code 1987, § 25-86) 
Sec. 38-127. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
    The displaying of lights upon a vehicle, when lawfully parked at night upon a street of the city in accordance with this article, shall not be required when there is sufficient light to reveal any person within a distance of 200 feet upon such street. 
(Code 1987, § 25-87) 
State Law reference- Lights on parked vehicles, city's authority to make exception, G.S. 20-134. 
Sec. 38-128. - Unauthorized moving of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to move a vehicle not owned or operated by him into any area where parking is prohibited or so far away from the curb as to be unlawful. 
(Code 1987, § 25-88) 
Sec. 38-129. - Loading and unloading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle within any loading zone marked in yellow paint on the curb or street, or sign posted as such by authority of the city council, except while loading or unloading cargo from or to the premises for which such loading zone is provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park or drive any vehicle on the sidewalks for the purpose of loading or unloading cargo, except in front of stores, warehouses or other places of business, unless such person shall first have procured a permit from the chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 25-89) 
Sec. 38-130. - Bus stops and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus at a bus stop, or other than a taxicab at a taxicab stand, when such bus stop or taxicab stand has been signposted as such by authority of the city council, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at such bus stop or taxicab stand for the purpose of and while actually taking on or discharging passengers and when such stopping does not interfere with the use of such bus stop by a bus or the use of such taxicab stand by a taxicab. 
(Code 1987, § 25-90) 
Sec. 38-131. - Lawful time limit. 
    When, by any provision of this article or an instruction, notice, directive or signal given on or by any official traffic control device or parking meter, the lawful parking of a vehicle at a certain place is limited to a certain period of time, the moving of a vehicle from such place and its immediate return to such place or to another place in the same block for which the same lawful parking time limit is in effect shall be deemed as one continuous parking period. 
(Code 1987, § 25-91) 
Sec. 38-132. - Parallel parking. 
    Where not otherwise provided and where the street is not marked to show how vehicles are to be parked, it shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to park a vehicle parallel to the curb and not more than 12 inches from such curb. 
(Code 1987, § 25-92) 
Sec. 38-133. - Angle parking. 
    Where a street, or portion thereof, is sign posted or marked so as to indicate that parking at an angle is required, each person parking a vehicle shall park the vehicle at the required angle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-93) 
Sec. 38-134. - Parking within lines. 
    On any street which is marked off with lines indicating parking spaces for vehicles, it shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to park a vehicle between such lines. 
(Code 1987, § 25-94) 
Sec. 38-135. - Reserved parking places. 
    Where a street, portion of a street or other public place is, by authority of the city council, signposted as reserved for the use of public officers or employees, physicians, specified classes of vehicles or other specified persons or vehicles or for specified uses, no person shall park a vehicle at such space, except a person for whom, or a vehicle or use for which, such reserved space is signposted. 
(Code 1987, § 25-95) 
Sec. 38-136. - Parking commercial vehicles in residential areas. 
    The parking of any commercial vehicle, larger than a standard size pickup truck, on any residential street in the city, except for the purpose of making deliveries or picking up items for transportation, is hereby prohibited. Any vehicle making deliveries and/or loading items may park only long enough to load and/or unload such vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 25-97) 
Sec. 38-137. - Violations; penalties. 
    The penalty for a violation of any provision of this division shall be $10.00. 
(Code 1987, § 25-96) 
Secs. 38-138-38-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING LOTS AND ZONES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to install and regulate parking meters and regulate parking, G.S. 160A-301. 

Sec. 38-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking space means any space within a two-hour parking zone which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by painted lines or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the street. 
    Two-hour parking zone means and includes the following streets and parking lots: 
(1)  Both sides of Atkinson Street from Fairley Street to Church Street; 
(2)  Both sides of Biggs Street from Church Street to Cronly Street; 
(3)  Both sides of Church Street from Biggs Street to Main Street; 
(4)  Both sides of Cronly Street from Atkinson Street to Biggs Street; 
(5)  Both sides of Fairley Street from Gill Street to Main Street; 
(6)  Both sides of Main Street from Church Street to Railroad Street; 
(7)  Both sides of McKay Street from Main Street to Biggs Street; 
(8)  The northern one-half of the Cronly Street parking lot, located at the southeast intersection of Cronly Street and Main Street, bounded on the north by the southern right-of-way line of Cronly Street; on the east by the western right-of-way line of Biggs Street; on the south by the northern property line of the Old Belk's Store property, which is located 128.21 feet south of, and parallel to, the southern right-of-way line of Cronly Street; and on the west by the eastern right-of-way line of Main Street; 
(9)  Both sides of Roper Street from Atkinson Street to Biggs Street; 
(10)  The Roper Street parking lot, located at the southwest intersection of Roper Street and Market Street, bounded on the north by the southern right-of-way line of Roper Street; on the east by the western right-of-way line of Old Market Street, now Biggs Street; on the south by the northern property line of the Morris Funeral Home property and the John E. Phillips property; and on the west by an alley running north and south, the eastern line of which is approximately 105 feet west of Market Street. 
(Code 1987, § 25-111) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to establish, regulate, etc., off-street parking facilities, G.S. 160A-302; public enterprises including off-street parking facilities, G.S. 160A-311 et seq. 
Sec. 38-162. - Purpose. 
    This entire division shall be deemed and construed to be an exercise of the police powers of the city for the preservation and protection of public safety and all of its provisions shall be liberally construed with a view to the effectuation of such purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 25-112) 
Sec. 38-163. - Enforcement; marking of tires. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department of the city to enforce the provisions of this division. Officers of the city police department are authorized to mark the tires of vehicles parked in the two-hour parking zone to determine the amount of time the vehicle is parked in such space. 
(Code 1987, § 25-113) 
Sec. 38-164. - Designated spaces. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby directed and authorized to mark off individual parking spaces on the streets and off-street parking lots of the city. Such parking spaces shall be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the curbing or surface of the street. 
(b)  At each marked off space, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a way so that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the designated space. 
(c)  The chief of police is hereby directed and authorized to place signs of a durable structure on the streets and sidewalks and in the public parking lots of the city designating two-hour parking. 
(Code 1987, § 25-114) 
Sec. 38-165. - Proper parking method. 
    All vehicles parked in any parking lot established by the city shall be parked within the traffic lines as marked on the surface of the lot. 
(Code 1987, § 25-115) 
Sec. 38-166. - Blocking driveways. 
    The driveways within the parking lots established by the city shall not be blocked or obstructed by vehicles, and vehicles shall not be parked on the streets or other places in a way so as to block the entrances to such driveways. 
(Code 1987, § 25-116) 
Sec. 38-167. - Buses and trucks in off-street lots. 
    Only passenger vehicles, ordinary size pickup trucks and panel delivery trucks shall be parked on any of the off-street parking lots established by this division. The parking of buses and other types of trucks on such lots is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1987, § 25-117) 
Sec. 38-168. - Loitering and littering. 
(a)  Loitering and littering on private and public parking lots within the city limits or a distance of one mile beyond the city limits is hereby declared dangerous or prejudicial to the public health or public safety of the citizens of the city. It shall, therefore, be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Loiter on any parking lot, public or private, within the city limits or a distance of one mile beyond the city limits. 
(2)  Scatter or litter trash, rubbish, refuse, paper, cans, glass, plastic or commercial handbills on any parking lot within the city limits or a distance of one mile beyond the city limits. 
(3)  Allow his property to be used for loitering or littering as specified in this section. 
(b)  Upon investigation and finding by the city manager that any parking lot, public or private, is being maintained in violation of this section, the city manager is hereby vested with authority to give written notice, which may be served personally, by registered or certified mail or in any other manner authorized by law, to the owner, occupant or person in charge of such premises. The notice shall specify the condition which constitutes the violation and shall direct the addressee to abate such violation in a lawful manner within ten days from the date of the notice. The notice shall also warn the addressee that failure to comply with the notice shall subject him to prosecution for his violation and, in addition, shall render him liable to the city for any costs and expenses which may be incurred by the city in the abatement of such violation and that such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien upon the property involved. If, upon the expiration of the time specified in such notice, the condition which constitutes the violation has not been abated in a lawful manner, the city manager shall provide for the abatement of such condition by the most expedient means and the costs and expenses thereby incurred, including any costs incurred in service of the notice, shall be collected by the city tax collector from any one or more of the addressees served with such notice and, if such costs and expenses are not paid within 30 days, the city tax collector shall make collection thereof in the manner provided by law for delinquent taxes or in any other manner authorized by law, and the amount of such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien in favor of the city upon the property upon which the violation was incurred. 
(Code 1987, § 25-118) 
Cross reference- Solid waste management, ch. 30. 
Sec. 38-169. - Sale of goods in off-street parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, any goods, wares or merchandise from any vehicle parked on any off-street parking lot established by the city or within the boundaries thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 25-119) 
Sec. 38-170. - City not responsible or liable for loss or theft in off-street parking lots. 
(a)  The city shall not be responsible or liable for the loss or theft of any vehicle parked on any off-street parking lot established by the city, or any part thereof, or any contents thereof, nor shall the city be responsible or liable for any damage to any vehicle, or to the contents thereof, while the vehicle is parked or within the boundaries of any such off-street parking lot. 
(b)  Persons parking vehicles on any off-street parking lot established by the city will do so at their own risk, with respect to such vehicles and any parts or contents thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 25-120) 
Sec. 38-171. - Overtime parking. 
    If any vehicle shall remain parked in a two-hour parking space beyond the two-hour period, then the vehicle shall be considered as parking overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time and such parking shall be deemed in violation of this section. Moving a vehicle from one two-hour parking space directly to another two-hour parking space located in the same block and on the same street as the first parking space or located in the same parking lot as the first parking space shall be deemed to be a continuous occupation of a two-hour space and, if the vehicle remains parked for a period of time in excess of two hours, when the time spent in the first space is added to the time spent in the second space and that total time exceeds two hours, then the vehicle shall be deemed to be in violation of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 25-121) 
Sec. 38-172. - Improperly parked vehicles. 
(a)  The operator of any vehicle which has been parked in a two-hour parking space beyond the period of legal parking time or which is parked in any space in violation of any other provision of this division shall, upon request of any police officer of the city, immediately remove the vehicle from the parking space. 
(b)  Any operator of a vehicle who shall fail or refuse, upon the request of any police officer of the city, to immediately remove the vehicle from the parking space upon which it is parked, when the vehicle has been parked in the parking space for a length of time beyond the legal parking time or when the vehicle is parked in the parking space in violation of any other provision of this division, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be fined $10.00. 
(Code 1987, § 25-122) 
Sec. 38-173. - Fines. 
(a)  Any person that shall park or permit a vehicle under his control to be parked in a two-hour parking zone for a period longer than two hours shall be punished by the following fines: 
(1)  A fine of $5.00 for every two-hour period that the motor vehicle remains in the parking space for which the original violation was noted, provided that, if a vehicle is moved directly from one two-hour parking space to another two-hour parking space located in the same block and on the same street as the first parking space or located in the same parking lot as the first parking space, as provided in section 38-171, such action shall be deemed to be a continuous occupation of a two-hour space for purposes of this section. 
(2)  An additional fine of $5.00 for every two-hour period that the motor vehicle remains in the parking space for which the original violation was noted, provided that, if a vehicle is moved directly from one two-hour parking space to another two-hour parking space located in the same block and on the same street as the first parking space or located in the same parking lot as the first parking space, as provided in subsection (1) of this section, such action shall be deemed to be a continuous occupation of a two-hour space for purposes of this section. 
(b)  The fines hereby imposed shall be paid into the office of the city police department, either personally or by mail, or placed in the fine boxes installed on the city streets, within a period of 72 hours after the owner or operator of the parked vehicle has been notified of the parking violation by parking tickets placed upon the vehicle by the city police department. 
Sec. 38-174. - Failure to pay fines. 
    Any person who shall fail to pay the fines imposed by section 38-173 within the period of 72 hours, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this division for which no specific penalty is provided, or shall counsel, aid or abet any such violation or failure to comply, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 25-124) 
Sec. 38-175. - Towing and storage of vehicles; charges. 
(a)  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove any vehicle from any of the city parking lots and city streets upon a violation of the provisions of section 38-171, and to tow such vehicle to the nearest garage or other place of safety or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department or otherwise maintained by the city. Such vehicle shall be held until claimed by the legal owner or until such vehicle is otherwise disposed of. 
(b)  Before the owner of any such vehicle is entitled to receive back the possession of such vehicle from the police department, he shall pay the following charges to the city tax collector: 
(1)  A towing charge of $50.00; 
(2)  Storage upon the vehicle, which is to be calculated as follows: 
a.  One dollar for up to five (5) hours; and 
b.  Two dollars per day, or any part of a day in excess of five hours. 
(c)  In addition to all other charges imposed by this article, the owner of such vehicle shall pay the sum of $10.00 as a penalty for violating the rules and regulations applicable to the parking of vehicles on the city parking lot. 
(Code 1987, § 25-125) 
Sec. 38-176. - Notice to owner of impounded vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to notify the owner of any impounded vehicle, in writing, by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, within 72 hours of the fact that his vehicle has been impounded, setting forth the reason for such impounding and the amount of the charges constituting a lien on such vehicle. 
(b)  If the vehicle is registered in this state or any other state, the registered owner of such vehicle, as shown by the records of the state of its registration, shall be deemed to be the owner of the vehicle and the mailing of the notice required hereby to such registered owner at the address shown on such records shall be deemed sufficient notification under this section. 
(Code 1987, § 25-126) 
Sec. 38-177. - Charges to be a lien on vehicle. 
    All towing, storage, violation and other charges incurred by the police department or the city and imposed upon the owner or operator of any illegally parked vehicle in connection with the impounding of such vehicle shall constitute a lien upon the illegally parked vehicle, and no such impounded vehicle shall be released until all such charges have been paid to the city tax collector and proper evidence of ownership exhibited. 
(Code 1987, § 25-127) 
Sec. 38-178. - Failure to pay storage charges and claim impounded vehicle. 
    If the owner of any impounded vehicle shall fail to pay the charges constituting the lien against the vehicle and claim the vehicle within 30 days after notice has been mailed as required by this division, action shall be instituted in the amount of such lien, and the vehicle shall be disposed of as provided by law. 
(Code 1987, § 25-128) 
Sec. 38-179. - Responsibility and liability for loss or theft of impounded vehicle. 
    Neither the city, nor any member of the police department of the city engaged in the enforcement of the provisions of this division, shall be responsible or liable for the loss or theft of any impounded vehicle or the contents thereof, nor for any damage to such vehicle arising from the removal of any illegally parked vehicle from the city parking lots as authorized in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 25-129) 
Secs. 38-180-38-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate speed of vehicles in city parks, G.S. 20-169. 

Sec. 38-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motorized vehicle means any self-propelled machine or one which is motor-assisted and designed and intended as a mode of transportation without regard to whether the machine is registered or licensed as a motor vehicle for the purpose of G.S. ch. 20 or the corresponding statutes of any other jurisdiction. 
    Parks and playgrounds means all properties maintained by the county for recreational purposes, including, but not limited to, ball fields, tennis courts, swimming areas and the county owned and county leased property which encloses such areas. 
(Code 1987, § 25-171) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-212. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to vehicles owned or operated by the city, its agents, servants, employees or emergency vehicles while such agents, servants, employees or emergency vehicles are within the scope of their employment by the city or the county parks and recreation commission. 
(Code 1987, § 25-172) 
Sec. 38-213. - Liability for damage caused by children. 
    Parents shall be held liable for damage caused by their child through acts in violation of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 25-173) 
Sec. 38-214. - Operation of motorized vehicles generally. 
    No motorized vehicle may be operated any place in any park or playground, except on drives, streets and parking lots or where otherwise expressly permitted. 
(Code 1987, § 25-174) 
Sec. 38-215. - Unlicensed motorized vehicles and drivers. 
    No person may operate any unlicensed motorized vehicle, nor may an unlicensed operator operate any motorized vehicle any place within a park or playground, including drives, streets or parking lots. 
(Code 1987, § 25-175) 
Sec. 38-216. - Motorized wheelchairs. 
    No provisions of this article shall prohibit the operation within parks and playgrounds of motorized wheelchairs by bona fide users of such wheelchairs. 
(Code 1987, § 25-176) 
Chapter 40 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; posting signs on trees, parks and utility poles, § 6-222; businesses, ch. 8; environment, ch. 16; solid waste management, ch. 30; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; telecommunications, ch. 36; planting street trees near utilities, § 42-37; franchises, app. B. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to operate public enterprise, G.S. 160A-312. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Extreme weather means extremely cold being below 32 degrees Fahrenheit and extremely hot meaning above 100 degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Improved street means any street having a wearing surface of concrete, asphalt, brick, stone, block, tar treatment or similar hard material. 
    Macadam street means any street with a crushed stone surface, either water, asphalt or tar bound. 
    Sewer means any sanitary sewer. 
    Sewer lateral means a pipe running from the sanitary sewer main to the inside of the curb, unless otherwise directed. 
    Unimproved street means any street having a dirt surface. 
    Water lateral means a pipe running from the water main to the meter.
