(Code 1987, § 27-1; Ord. No. O-2013-09, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 40-2. - Incorporation of provisions in agreements between city and consumers. 
    All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the city furnishes sewer or water services to any person or whereby the city makes any sewer or water connection or performs any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of sewer or water service. 
(Code 1987, § 27-2) 
Sec. 40-3. - Availability of service. 
(a)  Water and sewer services shall be available to all residential consumers within the service area for domestic use where existing facilities are available that do not have established assessment costs and to all industrial and commercial consumers within the established service area for domestic, commercial or industrial use. Where the site location necessitates an extension of the existing system, the cost participation will be negotiated. Service to any consumer outside the city limits is subject to approval by the city council. 
(b)  The city will furnish water at the system pressure. Water and sewer installation will be provided to the customer's property line, as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, § 27-3) 
Sec. 40-4. - Damaging and tampering with systems, fixtures, installations and meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any part of the public water or sewer system, or any fixture thereto or installation thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to purposely damage any water meter or water meter box, or interfere with any water meter or water meter box belonging to the city. If a water meter is found to have been damaged or tampered with, services will be disconnected and will not be reinstalled until all damage charges and tampering charges are paid in full, along with any delinquent bill. 
(Code 1987, § 27-4) 
State Law reference- Interfering with electric, gas or water meters, G.S. 14-151.1. 
Sec. 40-5. - Climbing elevated tanks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an authorized employee of the city, to climb, or attempt to climb, up the elevated tanks of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 27-5) 
Sec. 40-6. - Throwing stones, trash, substances and filth in reservoirs and settling basins. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw stones or trash or any substance or filth in the reservoir at the pumping station or into any of the settling basins or reservoir at the filter plant. 
(Code 1987, § 27-6) 
Cross reference- Solid waste management, ch. 30; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Contaminating public water system, G.S. 14-159.1. 
Secs. 40-7-40-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require water and sewer connections, G.S. 160A-317. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-41. - Required. 
(a)  Sewer. Every person owning a house, building or facility from which there is a discharge of liquid waste, when such house, building or facility is situated on property to which city sewer service is available, shall, within 30 days from the date when sewer service is available, have sewer connections made to the house, building or facility, provided that the house, building or facility can be served by a gravity sewer line installed in accordance with the state building code. For purposes of determining whether a house can be served by a gravity sewer line, where a portion of the house is at an elevation which is too low to be served, if the primary living areas of the house can be served, the house is deemed to be served. In lieu of connecting to such sewer line, the person owning such building shall pay the monthly minimum sewer charge, as set by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office, until such time as the person owning such building connects to the city sewer system; provided, however, that where the building is connected to city water, the monthly sewer charge shall be determined by the volume of water registered on the water meter serving the building. 
(b)  Water. Every person owning a house, building or facility which is situated on property to which city water service is available shall, within 30 days from the date when water service is available, have water connections made to the house, building or facility, provided that the house, building or facility is within 300 feet of the water line. In lieu of connecting to such water line as required in this subsection, the person owning such building shall pay the monthly minimum rate for water usage, as set by the city council from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office, until such time as the person owning such building connects to the city water system. 
(Code 1987, § 27-26) 
State Law reference- Authority for cities to require connections, G.S. 160A-317. 
Sec. 40-42. - Separate and independent connections; exceptions. 
    Every house or building abutting any water or sewer main and requiring a water or sewer connection shall be separately and independently connected, except in cases where laterals have already been laid in macadam or improved streets from such main, and provision has been made for such house or building, in which case the connection may be made to an existing lateral. If such house or building is on a macadam or improved street where laterals have not been laid, the connection may be made to any convenient lateral. When two or more houses or units are connected with the same water lateral, a separate meter shall be provided for each such house or unit. 
(Code 1987, § 27-27) 
Sec. 40-43. - Application for connection. 
(a)  Every application for a sewer or water connection shall state the following: 
(1)  Name of the owner of the lot; 
(2)  Name of the street on which such lot is situated; 
(3)  Number of the house, if there is a house on the lot or, if there is no house, a description of the location of the lot; 
(4)  Number and kind of connections desired; and 
(5)  Character of the surface of the abutting street. 
(b)  Every such application shall be: 
(1)  Signed by the person making the application; 
(2)  Accompanied by the proper fee for making the connection applied for; and 
(3)  Filed with the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-28) 
Sec. 40-44. - Application approval. 
    Every application for a water or sewer connection, to be made in conformity with the provisions of this article, shall be subject to approval by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 27-29) 
Sec. 40-45. - Work to be done by city. 
    Upon approval of any application for a sewer or water connection, as provided in section 40-44, the city shall do the excavating, lay the pipe, install a meter, where necessary, make the connection to the main, fill the excavation and replace the surface of the street. 
(Code 1987, § 27-30) 
Sec. 40-46. - Outside corporate limits. 
(a)  No connection of any water or sewer line or system outside the city shall be made to any part of the city's water or sewer system without special permission from the city and on such terms as the city council shall prescribe. 
(b)  The permission for persons living outside the corporate limits of the city to make connection with the sanitary sewer lines of the city will be conditioned upon the premises being supplied with city water and upon the plumbing being installed in accordance with the plumbing code. All plumbing work installed must be done by qualified persons. 
(c)  Applications for such connections shall be made at the consumer billing department's application window and water service will not be turned on until the certificate from the plumbing inspector is received, stating that the plumbing has been properly installed. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to change the rate or to refuse to give service where conditions set forth in this section are not met or where conditions are such as to make such service impractical. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to obligate the city to purchase any water or sewer line that may be constructed outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(f)  As far as applicable, the provisions of this article shall apply to water and sewer connections outside the city. 
(Code 1987, § 27-31) 
Sec. 40-47. - Charges. 
(a)  Establishment. Connection charges shall be established by the city council and kept on file in the offices of the city clerk and the consumer billing department. 
(b)  Payment. Payment for a water and/or sewer connection, upon written request of the property owner, shall be made by making an initial payment of one-half the cost of the connection and paying the remainder of the charge in 12 equal monthly installments, plus an interest rate of ten percent. Such charge shall be added to the utility bill each month until paid in full. 
(Code 1987, § 27-32) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to fix and enforce sewer and water rates and charges, G.S. 160A-314. 
Sec. 40-48. - Laying laterals. 
    Water or sewer laterals laid as a part of any water or sewer main improvement shall be laid only to the inside of the curb unless, in the resolution ordering the improvement, the city council specifically directs otherwise or the city manager directs otherwise. 
(Code 1987, § 27-33) 
Sec. 40-49. - Connection location. 
    Every sewer connection made directly to a main shall be made at the Y provided for the lot to be served. If no such Y has been provided for such lot, such connection may be made directly to the main at any convenient point. 
(Code 1987, § 27-34) 
Sec. 40-50. - Ownership of equipment. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes and other equipment used by the city in installing any water or sewer connection shall be and remain the property of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 27-35) 
Sec. 40-51. - Responsibility for maintenance of connections and laterals. 
(a)  Water and sewer connections at the mains and water and sewer laterals shall be kept in repair by the city and at the expense of the city. Necessary renewals of such water or sewer laterals shall be made by the city. 
(b)  Every leak or break in a water or sewer lateral shall be promptly repaired by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 27-36) 
Sec. 40-52. - Responsibility for maintenance of service lines. 
    Renewals or maintenance of water or sewer service lines from the point of connection at the lateral on the premises side, including any part thereof which may be in the public right-of-way, shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Code 1987, § 27-37) 
Sec. 40-53. - Water connections for irrigation purposes. 
(a)  Separate water connections may be made for water which is to be used for irrigation purposes only. It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from an irrigation tap for any purpose other than for irrigation as described in this section. All irrigation taps will be billed on a yearround basis and taps will not be discontinued during the nongrowing season. 
(b)  The fees for separate water connections made for irrigation purposes shall be set by the city council from time to time and maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  The rates for water used for irrigation purposes under this section shall be set by the city council from time to time and maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  Any person applying for an irrigation tap shall file an application as provided in section 40-43 and, in addition, shall sign a written statement that such person freely, voluntarily and knowingly consents to agents of the city coming upon his premises at any time for the purpose of inspecting the irrigation tap and the lines running from such tap to ensure that all such connections are in strict compliance with the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1987, § 27-38) 
Secs. 40-54-40-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BACKFLOW PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 40-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air gap separation means the unobstructed vertical distance through the atmosphere between the lowest point opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the receptacle. An approved air gap separation shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe. In no case shall the air gap separation be less than one inch. 
    Approved means, when used in reference to a water supply, a water supply that has been approved by the state department of environment, health and natural resources, division of health service. 
    Backflow means any flow of water, liquid, gas or other substance, or any combination thereof, into the distribution piping of a potable water supply from any source. 
    Backflow prevention assembly means an approved assembly or method used to prevent backflow from occurring in the potable water supply. 
    Back-pressure backflow means backflow caused by a pump, elevated tank, boiler or other means that could create greater pressure within the consumer's water system that is greater than the supply pressure. 
    Double check detector assembly means a specially designed assembly composed of a line size approved double check valve assembly with a specific bypass water meter and a meter sized approved double check valve assembly. The meter shall accurately register in U.S. gallons for only very low rates of flow and shall show a registration for all rates of flow. The assembly shall only be used to protect against a nonhealth hazard. 
    Double check valve assembly means an assembly composed of two independently acting, approved check valves, including tightly closing shutoff valves attached at each end of the assembly and fitted with properly located test cocks. 
    Potable water means water from any source, which has been approved for human consumption by the appropriate agency of the state. 
    Private water system means a system of pipes or other associated facilities that is not part of the city's public water system and is used to move or receive water, regardless of the source of water in such system. 
    Reduced pressure principle assembly means an assembly containing within its structure a minimum of two independently acting, approved check valves, together with an automatically operating pressure differential relief valve located between the check valves. The first check valve reduces the supply pressure a predetermined amount so that during normal flow and at cessation of normal flow the pressure between the checks shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the pressure differential relief valve, by discharge to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the checks less than the supply pressure. The assembly must include properly located test cocks and tightly closing shutoff valves at each end of the assembly. 
    Reduced pressure principle detector assembly means an assembly composed of an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly with a bypass water meter and a meter sized approved reduced pressure principle assembly. The meter shall register accurately for very low flow rates and shall register in U.S. gallons at all flow rates. 
    Water supply, approved, means any public potable water supply which has been investigated and approved by the appropriate agency of the state. The system must be operating under a valid health permit. 
(Code 1987, § 27-40) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 40-72. - Purpose. 
    The backflow prevention program is designed to protect the potable water supply of the city, by requiring the use of appropriate backflow protection methods. The possibility of contamination will be minimized by confining within the customer's private water system the contaminants or pollutants which could, under adverse conditions, backflow through uncontrolled cross connections into the public water system. 
(Code 1987, § 27-39) 
Sec. 40-73. - Elimination of cross connections. 
(a)  No private water system may be connected in any manner to the public water system unless the requirements of this division and other applicable laws have been satisfied. 
(b)  Only an approved assembly can be installed to meet the requirements of this division. The installation of any backflow prevention device/assembly which is not approved must be replaced with an approved backflow prevention assembly. 
(Code 1987, § 27-41) 
Sec. 40-74. - Installation, testing and maintenance of backflow prevention assemblies. 
(a)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Only backflow preventers approved by the city, American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE), American Water Works Association (AWWA) or United States Code (USC) shall be used, whichever is most restrictive. 
(b)  All backflow prevention assemblies required by this division must be installed and maintained on the customer's premises as part of the customer's water system. 
(c)  Ownership, testing and maintenance of the backflow prevention assembly will be the responsibility of the customer. Each assembly required in this division must be functioning properly at all times. 
(d)  A certified tester shall conduct testing of backflow prevention assemblies, at the customer's expense. Testers shall provide a current certificate from an approved school before being allowed to test assemblies. Tests shall be conducted upon installation and annually thereafter, with a record of all testing and repairs retained by the customer. A copy of the certified record for each test or repair must be sent to the city by such customer within 30 days after the completion of each test or repair. Such records must be maintained on forms provided by the city. 
(e)  Each backflow prevention assembly required under this division must be accessible to the city. 
(f)  The customer shall provide for the parallel installation of an approved backflow prevention assembly when it is not possible to interrupt water service. A bypass around a backflow preventer, when the assembly is in need of testing, repair or replacement, is not acceptable. 
(g)  Double check valve assemblies must be installed in drainable pits whenever below the ground installation is necessary. 
(h)  Reduced pressure principle assemblies must be installed in a horizontal position and in a location in which no portion of the assembly can become submerged in any substance, under any circumstances. Pit and/or below grade installations are prohibited. 
(i)  Any time that repairs to backflow assemblies are deemed necessary, whether through annual testing or routine inspection by the owner or the city, the repairs must be completed within a time specified in accordance with the degree of hazard. Health has 14 days for repairs and nonhealth has 21 days for repairs. Failure to comply with such time limit can result in termination of a customer's water service. 
(j)  Upon determination that a backflow prevention assembly is required to be installed on a customer's private water system, the customer will be notified, in writing, of the approved backflow prevention assembly which is required. On existing systems, the customer will have the following time periods within which to install the specified backflow prevention assembly: 
(1)  Health, 60 days. 
(2)  Nonhealth, 90 days. 
(k)  All new construction plans and specifications shall be made available to the city for approval and to determine the degree of hazard. 
(l)  The customer shall notify the city when the nature of the use of property changes so as to change the hazard classification of the property, if necessary. 
(Code 1987, § 27-42) 
Sec. 40-75. - Health hazard facilities. 
(a)  All health hazard facilities must have an approved reduced pressure principle assembly as a minimum containment assembly. 
(b)  Health hazard facilities include, but are not limited to, any private water system used or designed for use with a booster pump or which may become pressurized for any reason to the extent that back-pressure may occur; private water system which contains water which has been, or is being, recirculated; building with five or more stories above ground level; brewery; car wash facilities; bottling plant; chemical plant; dentist's office; dry cleaning plant; fertilizer plant; film laboratory; fire sprinkler or standpipe system with chemical additives; hospital, clinic or medical building; irrigation system with chemical additives; laboratory; commercial laundry, except a self-service laundry; concrete/asphalt plant; metal processing plant; morgue or mortuary; nursing home; pharmaceutical plant; power plant; swimming pool; sewage treatment plant; tire manufacturer; veterinary hospital or clinic; restaurant; battery manufacturer; exterminator and lawn care company; dairy; cannery; dye works, etc. 
(c)  If a cross connection inspector does not have sufficient access to every portion of a private water system to permit the complete evaluation of the degree of hazard associated with such private water system, an approved reduced pressure principle assembly must be installed. 
(Code 1987, § 27-43) 
Sec. 40-76. - Nonhealth hazard facilities. 
(a)  Nonhealth hazard facilities include, but are not limited to, fire sprinkler systems without booster pump facilities or chemical additives; connections to tanks, lines and vessels that handle nontoxic substances; lawn sprinkler systems without chemical injection or booster pumps; and all industrial and most commercial facilities not identified as high hazard facilities. 
(b)  All moderate hazard facilities must have a double check valve assembly as a minimum containment assembly. 
(Code 1987, § 27-44) 
Sec. 40-77. - Lawn irrigation systems. 
    All existing lawn irrigation systems must have a double check valve assembly as a minimum containment assembly. 
(Code 1987, § 27-45) 
Sec. 40-78. - Fire sprinkler systems. 
(a)  All unmetered fire sprinkler systems without booster facilities or chemical additives must have a double check detector check valve assembly as a minimum containment device. 
(b)  All unmetered fire sprinkler systems with a booster facility or chemical additives must have a reduced pressure principle detector assembly as a minimum containment device. 
(Code 1987, § 27-46) 
Sec. 40-79. - Right of entry. 
(a)  With the permission of the occupant, such permission not being unreasonably withheld, an authorized agent of the city shall have the right to enter any building, structure or premises during normal working hours to perform any duty imposed upon him by this section. Such duties may include sampling and testing water, or inspecting and observing all piping systems connected to the public water supply. Prior notice of such entry will be given unless an imminent hazard has been reported. Refusal to allow entry for such purposes may result in termination of the water service. 
(b)  At the request of the city, the customer shall furnish any pertinent information regarding the piping system and chemical storage on such property where cross connections are deemed possible. 
(Code 1987, § 27-47) 
Sec. 40-80. - Responsibility of customer. 
(a)  The customer shall be responsible for the elimination of, or protection against, all cross connections on his premises. 
(b)  The customer shall maintain any backflow prevention assembly within his premises in a good operating condition. The customer shall correct any malfunction of the backflow preventer, which is revealed by periodic testing. 
(c)  The customer shall be responsible for the payment of all fees for annual testing, retesting in case the assembly fails to operate correctly and repairs. 
(d)  A customer must immediately notify the city if he has reason to believe that backflow has occurred from his private water system. 
(Code 1987, § 27-48) 
Sec. 40-81. - Unapproved source of supply. 
(a)  No person shall connect, or cause to be connected, any supply of water not approved by the state to the public water supply system. 
(b)  Where a connection to a city water line is made and the property owner continues to have a well or other source of water, it shall be unlawful for the plumbing servicing any building upon such property to be connected so that any water outlet within the building may be served with water from any source other than the city connection, and it shall also be unlawful to have plumbing cross connected or installed so that water from the city water system or the private water system may in any way become intermingled. 
(Code 1987, § 27-49) 
Sec. 40-82. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  A written notice of violation shall be given to any person who is determined to be in violation of any provision of this division. 
(b)  Such notice shall set forth the violation and the time period within which the violation must be corrected. The violation must be corrected within a reasonable time, as specified in the notice, not to exceed 30 days from receipt of the notice. If the city determines that the violation is occurring on a customer's private water system and that such violation has created or contributed to the existence of an imminent hazard, the customer may be required to immediately correct the violation. 
(c)  Water service may be terminated to a customer if the customer fails to correct a violation or to pay any civil penalty or expense assessed under this section. Termination of water service will be without prejudice to the city's ability to assert any other remedy available to the city against the customer or any other person responsible for the violation. 
(d)  The violation of any provision of this division shall subject the violator to a civil penalty. Each subsequent day that a violation listed in this subsection continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Unprotected cross connection involving a private water system which is a health hazard, per day ..... $1,000.00 
(2)  Falsifying records which are required to be submitted by this division-Tester may be removed from the approved certified tester list and/or ..... 500.00 
(3)  Failing to test backflow prevention assemblies as required ..... 100.00 
(4)  Failing to maintain backflow prevention assemblies as required ..... 100.00 
(5)  Any other violation of the provision of this division ..... 100.00 
(e)  The city may increase any civil penalty assessed under this section by $100.00 or 50 percent of the maximum civil penalty associated with the violation, whichever is greater, for a second violation of the same provision within a two-year period. Water service may be terminated after a third violation of the same provision within a two-year period. 
(f)  Any person violating any provision of this division shall pay to the city all expenses incurred by the city in repairing any damage to the public water system caused, in whole or in part, by such violation and any expense incurred by the city in investigating such violation. All such expenses are deemed to be a part of the civil penalty assessed with the violation. 
(Code 1987, § 27-50) 
Secs. 40-83-40-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SYSTEM[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to acquire, operate, regulate, etc., water supply and distribution systems, G.S. 160A-312 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-111. - Opening account. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use city water prior to opening a water account at the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-51) 
State Law reference- Interfering with meter, G.S. 14-151.1. 
Sec. 40-112. - Application for service. 
(a)  Application for services shall be made to the consumer billing department. No application for services shall be granted until the applicant has made the deposit required by section 40-113. Applicants should have two types of identification and, if such applicants are renting or leasing, they will need to furnish a copy of their lease or the name, address and telephone number of their landlord. 
(b)  A person applying for a water connection shall agree that he will not remove or tamper with, or permit to be removed or tampered with, any of the city's property on his premises, except by a duly authorized agent or representative of the city. 
(c)  The city may refuse to furnish new service to any applicant until the applicant has paid the city all indebtedness due the city for: 
(1)  Any and all delinquent utility accounts in the name of the applicant. 
(2)  Any and all delinquent utility accounts in the name of any other person who currently resides with the applicant if the applicant and the other person resided in the same household when the delinquency occurred. 
(3)  Any and all delinquent utility accounts in the name of the owner(s) of the property the applicant is seeking to occupy. 
(Code 1987, § 27-52; Ord. No. O-2015-11, § 4, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 40-113. - Deposit. 
(a)  When any person makes application for water service to be furnished, such person shall make a deposit to guarantee the payment of charges for water. If, at the expiration of the time limited by this article for the payment of charges for water for any month, such person has failed to pay the charges due for that month, a portion of the deposit, as may be necessary, shall be applied to the payment of charges for water. The water, therefore, shall be cut off from such premises and shall not be turned on again until the balance of the deposit is increased to the original amount of the deposit. When such person has the water finally cut off, upon payment of all charges for water due, he shall be entitled to the return of his deposit or any balance thereof. 
(b)  The deposit required by subsection (a) of this section shall be set by the city council from time to time and kept on file at the consumer billing department and the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  The deposit required by subsection (a) of this section for residential customers may be waived by the city if the customer has a good history of payment of utility bills with the city or furnishes evidence of a good history of payment of utility bills with another utility company. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "a good history" means when the customer has paid all utility bills during the most recent 12-month period, with none of the payments being delinquent. 
(d)  Any customer may receive, upon request, a refund, without interest, of the deposit required by subsection (a) of this section upon having a good history of payment of city utility bills as defined in subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1987, § 27-53) 
Sec. 40-114. - Service regulations. 
(a)  The city council and city manager, by authority of the city council, may from time to time promulgate water system service regulations to implement the provisions of this article. The subject matter of such regulations may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The metering of premises served by the city water system and the number of customers to be served by any one or more meters; 
(2)  The types of service to be provided to various classes of customers; 
(3)  The use of water heaters and other appliances served by the city water system; and 
(4)  A miscellaneous charge which may be imposed with respect to subjects covered in the regulations. 
(b)  Regulations promulgated pursuant to this section shall take effect when placed on file in the office of the city clerk and have been published in such a manner as the city council may direct. 
(Code 1987, § 27-54) 
Sec. 40-115. - Metered rates. 
    Except as otherwise provided, water shall be furnished by the city to consumers at metered rates only. 
(Code 1987, § 27-55) 
Sec. 40-116. - Discounts. 
    In payment of bills for water or sewer service, no discount shall be allowed from the rates established under, or by, this article. 
(Code 1987, § 27-56) 
Sec. 40-117. - Water and sewer billing adjustment. 
    When a residential customer has a water leak and has it repaired, and provides to the city a statement verifying that such repairs have been made, the city will adjust one month's water and sewer bill in a 24-month period. The adjustment will be based on an average of the previous 24 months' history. In the event of a major billing error; the city will make an adjustment, plus or minus, for a period covering no more than the immediate preceding 36 months; provided, however, claims for major billing errors that have been adjusted and settled prior to the adoption of this revised ordinance are not subject to further adjustment and settlement. Any adjustments to the water and sewer bill for non-residential customers for water leaks shall be at the sole discretion of the city. The city will not grant an adjustment for any customer for a water leak caused by the negligence or intentional acts of a third party if the customer is able to identify the third party and recover the costs from the third party. The city will not grant an adjustment for any customer for a water leak on property that was vacant or unoccupied at the time of the leak. 
(Code 1987, § 27-57; Ord. No. O-2009-16, § 1, 10-20-2009; Ord. No. O-2015-11, § 6, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 40-118. - Residential schedule of rates. 
    The residential schedule of water rates shall be established by the city council from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-58) 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to fix and enforce sewer and water rates, G.S. 160A-314. 
Sec. 40-119. - Commercial schedule of rates. 
    The commercial schedule of water rates shall be established by the city council from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-59) 
Sec. 40-120. - Schedule of rates outside city limits. 
    The schedule of water rates for outside the city limits shall be established by the city council from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-60) 
Sec. 40-121. - Minimum charge where meter serves several premises. 
    Where plumbing facilities are connected to any water meter in a way so that more than one family unit, housekeeping unit or business may be supplied with water through such meter, the minimum monthly charge shall be multiplied by the number of separate family units, housekeeping units or businesses supplied. 
(Code 1987, § 27-61) 
Sec. 40-122. - Reading meters and rendering bills. 
    All water meters shall be read monthly and all water bills shall be rendered the first of each month. 
(Code 1987, § 27-62) 
Sec. 40-123. - Bill preparation and mailing. 
    All water bills shall be prepared and mailed to consumers by the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-63) 
Sec. 40-124. - Notice of accounts due. 
    Notice of accounts for water service due may be given by mail or otherwise. Failure of the water consumer to receive notice will not be accepted as an excuse for failure to pay a water bill when due. 
(Code 1987, § 27-64) 
Sec. 40-125. - Dates bills due and past due. 
    All water bills shall be due and payable on the first day of each month and shall be deemed past due on the 20th day of the same month. Failure of a customer to receive such bill does not relieve the customer from the responsibility of paying a utility bill when due. 
(Code 1987, § 27-65; Ord. No. O-2014-04, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 40-126. - Service charge for late payments. 
    A service charge shall be made in all cases in which a bill for water service remains unpaid on the 20th day of the month in which the bill is rendered. Such service charge shall be 1.5 percent of the balance after the 20th day of the month in which the bill is rendered, or a minimum charge as established by the city council from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the consumer billing department. 
(Code 1987, § 27-66; Ord. No. O-2014-04, § 2, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 40-127. - Discontinuance of service when bill not paid by due date. 
(a)  A reminder notice may be sent to the customer after the 20th of each month. If payment is not received by the fifth of the month following billing, services will be disconnected without further notice. Failure of a customer to receive such notice does not relieve the customer from the responsibility of paying a utility bill when due. 
(b)  If payment is not received by the specified by the specified cut-off date, service could be disconnected and an additional fee will be added to the account. If this is a business or medical alert account, a 24-hour notice will be given before disconnection and the service charge will be added to the account. If after the 24-hour period, payment has not been received, the customer will be disconnected and another service fee will be added. (Medical alert customers must have a written statement from a medical doctor stating they have a life-threatening problem without water.) 
(Ord. No. O-2013-09, § 2, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. O-2014-04, § 3, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 40-128. - Service charge for restoration of services. 
    If services are disconnected for nonpayment or a service call to disconnect services has been made, a charge will be added to the account and full payment or agreement of full payment will have to be made before services are restored. If the reconnection is made after normal working hours for the convenience of the customer, an after-hour charge shall be added to the account in addition to any other applicable charges. If the city discovers a service has been reconnected by anyone other than an authorized person, a tampering charge will be charged plus an additional service charge fee. If the meter is not in the appropriate place, there will be a charge for that meter, plus any other additional charges that may apply. If a meter from another location has been placed in the meter box, there will be an additional tampering fee charged based on the unauthorized removal of that meter from another location. In the event that tampering charges are imposed, services will not be restored to the premises until full payment or agreement of full payment thereof has been made. All tampering charges shall be the responsibility and liability of either the customer requesting services under section 40-112 or, in the event that tampering shall occur during a time when there shall be no customer requesting services under section 40-112, the owner of the premises to which the service was provided. The various charges referenced in this section shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such charges is on file and available in the city offices. 
(Code 1987, 27-68; Ord. No. O-2015-11, § 5, 7-21-2015) 
State Law reference- Unlawful reconnection, G.S. 14-151.1(b1). 
Sec. 40-129. - Testing of meter. 
    Any consumer of city water may have a test made of his water meter upon payment, in advance, of a fee as set from time to time and on file in the city clerk's office, for any meter one inch or less in size. The fee for a test of meters larger than one inch in size shall be the actual cost of such test, which cost is to be paid in advance after being ascertained upon application to the city manager. If such test shows the meter to be defective as set out in section 40-130, the fee paid for such test shall be returned to the person paying the fee. 
(Code 1987, § 27-69) 
Sec. 40-130. - Action upon findings of meter testing. 
    If, upon a test as provided in section 40-129, the meter is found to be incorrect and registers more than 21/2 percent too fast (i.e., the meter registers more than 21/2 percent more water than it should), then the city shall return the fee to the complainant and shall properly adjust and repair the meter promptly or furnish a correctly adjusted meter. If, upon such test, the meter shall not register more than 21/2 percent too fast (i.e., the meter does not register more than 21/2 percent more than it should), the fee shall be retained by the city to cover the expense of taking out and replacing the meter. 
(Code 1987, § 27-73) 
Sec. 40-131. - Maintenance of meters. 
    All meters, except as are required to be furnished by particular users of water, shall be kept in good repair and working order by the city, at the expense of the city. Meters furnished by particular users of water shall be kept in good repair and working order by the city, but the expense thereof shall be borne by such users. 
(Code 1987, § 27-74) 
Sec. 40-132. - Automatic sprinkler systems. 
(a)  Water will be furnished by the city for any automatic sprinkler system for free, provided that, in any case where there is a diversion of such water furnished for free from any such system, such free service shall be immediately discontinued and water shall thereafter be supplied for such system only through a meter and at the rates prescribed by section 40-121. 
(b)  Application for any such free water for an automatic sprinkler system shall be made in writing. Such application shall set forth all information as may be necessary for the purpose of determining the location, size and character of the sprinkler system. 
(c)  The city manager may require the installation of a detector check type meter in instances in which water is furnished under this section. 
(Code 1987, § 27-75) 
Sec. 40-133. - Circuses, road shows, etc. 
    Water from a hydrant will be furnished to circuses, road shows, carnivals, fairs or other similar temporary users at a per diem rate, to be paid in advance, and to be determined by the city manager upon the basis of the estimated quantity of water needed. When such water is to be furnished, an employee of the public works department shall be stationed at the hydrant designated for such purpose, during such hours as may be agreed upon by the city manager, and only such employee shall open, close or draw water from such hydrant. 
(Code 1987, § 27-76) 
Sec. 40-133.1. - Landlords. 
(a)  After city personnel discover three separate tamperings at a specified location: 
(1)  The city may require the landlord to be a contracting utility customer as a condition precedent to receiving services. 
(2)  Any past due amounts, tampering fees, repair fees and service fees must be paid in full prior to the restoration of services. 
(3)  If the specified location is conveyed by deed to a new and different owner, and the specified location is thereafter leased to a new and different tenant, the new tenant may apply for services as the contracting customer in accordance with the procedures of section 40-112. 
(b)  The city may also require the landlord to be a contracting utility customer at any location that has a history of nonpayment for services or fees resulting from high water usage when such high water usage is the result of the negligence of the landlord in maintaining the specified location, including, but not limited to, faulty or inadequate plumbing and failure to repair a water leak. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-11, § 3, 7-21-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2015-11, § 3, adopted July 21, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as § 40-134. At the editor's discretion, to prevent duplication of section numbers, these provisions have been included as § 40-133.1. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION ORDINANCE 

Sec. 40-134. - Declaration. 
    Whenever the water supply of the city's public water system is low and/or declining due to conditions which may adversely affect the continued availability of water for human consumption, sanitation, health and fire protection, it may become necessary to declare a water shortage and implement conservation requirements under the standards set forth below. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-135. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following terms, words and phrases and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely discretionary. 
    City is the City of Laurinburg. 
    Customer is a person in whose name a water connection is made and to whom a bill is issued, whether such connection is inside or outside the corporate limits of the city. 
    Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, limited liability company, professional association or organization of any kind. The term person shall also include customers. 
    Water is raw or treated water from the city's water supply system. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-136. - General. 
    A water shortage shall be declared to exist when the reserve supply of water available to the city shall have reached the point where customers cannot be supplied with water to protect their health and safety without substantially curtailing the water demand. A water shortage shall also be declared to exist when production, transmission and storage facilities are incapable of meeting all daily water demands without substantially curtailing water demand. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-137. - Notice to general public of water shortage. 
(a)  In the event that a water shortage within the city water supply of any of the degrees of severity hereinafter set forth threatens the health and safety of the citizens, as determined by the city manager in consultation with the director of the water treatment plant, the city manager is authorized and empowered, after communication to the mayor and the city council, to give notice to the general public of the existence of such state and the severity thereof. In order to protect the health and safety of the persons supplied water by the city, the city manager may place into effect the restrictive provisions hereinafter authorized by the execution of an executive order. Notice of such executive order shall be given by public press announcement, and the order shall become effective 24 hours following the press announcement. 
(b)  Once a stage of water restriction is declared, the director of the water treatment plant shall review the number of days of water supply available to the city at least once every seven days. A declared stage shall remain in effect for a minimum of 30 days; provided, however, that if conditions as listed in section 40-138(a) warrant a more restrictive level may be enacted immediately. At the end of 30 days and following the periodic supply review, the director of the water treatment plant shall notify the city manager of the city's system capacity and operational time of the water treatment plant in light of the criteria set out in subsection 40-138(a), and the city manager shall declare the appropriate stage of restriction, if any, to be in effect. 
(c)  In addition to the other powers contained in this division, the city manager, when notified by the director of the water treatment plant that there is a serious and immediate threat to the city's water system because of reduced water quality, treatment capacity, treated supply recovery time or any other imminent condition, may temporarily impose restrictions on automated and manual sprinkling. Such restrictions may include, among others, limitations on methods of sprinkling, the hours and days, and whether such sprinkling may occur at all. In such event, the notice provisions contained in section 40-137(a) shall apply and the enforcement provisions of section 40-140 through 40-144 shall be applicable. The city manager, or city council, may terminate, by written notice, such restrictions when the threat has been abated. Any violation of this subsection by a customer shall be treated as a stage II level B violation for the purposes of imposing civil penalties. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-138. - Compliance required in the event of a water shortage. 
(a)  In the event the city manager shall sign an executive order and issue the notice described in section 40-137, it shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of water from the city's water system for any of the purposes hereinafter set forth until such time that this article is amended or repealed or until the city manager has declared such provisions no longer to be in effect. In exercising this authority, considerations shall be given to the following criteria: groundwater supplies and draw down rates (well pumping ability), capabilities of the water production, distribution and storage system, outlook for precipitation, daily water use patterns and the availability of water from other sources. 
(b)  To the extent that compliance will not endanger the health of the patients or residents of the institution, hospitals, nursing homes and health care facilities shall comply with all restrictions imposed on residential and non-residential customers as may be applicable to each individual institution. Furthermore, each hospital, nursing home and health care facility shall survey its water usage patterns and requirements and implement such additional conservation measures as may be possible without endangering the health of its patients or residents in order to achieve a further reduction in the institution's water usage. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-139. - Restrictions applicable to various levels of available capacity. 
    The severity of the water shortages shall be determined primarily by the city's system capacity and operational time of the water treatment plant in light of the criteria set out in subsection 40-138(a). The restrictive measures in effect at each stage are as follows: 
(1)  Stage I water restriction alert . In the event that daily water demand is approaching 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time, the director of the water treatment plant shall notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification, the city manager shall declare a stage I water restriction alert. After complying with the notice provisions contained in section 40-137, the following voluntary water restrictions shall be requested. 
a.  Residential, commercial, manufacturing, and institutional customers shall be strongly encouraged and recommended to enact voluntary water conservation measures including the following: 
1.  Inspect and repair all faulty and defective parts of faucets and toilets; 
2.  Use showers for bathing rather than bathtub and limit showers to no more than five minutes; 
3.  Do not leave faucets running while shaving, rinsing dishes or brushing teeth; 
4.  Limit the use of clothes washers and dishwashers and when used, operate fully loaded; 
5.  Limit lawn watering to that necessary for plant survival; 
6.  Water shrubbery the minimum amount required, reusing household water when possible; 
7.  Limit vehicle washing; 
8.  Do not wash down outside areas such as sidewalks, patios, driveways, etc.; 
9.  Install water flow restriction devices in showerheads and other water using devices; 
10.  Use disposable and biodegradable dishes when possible; 
11.  Install water saving devices in toilets such as early closing flapper valves; 
12.  Limit hours of use for water-cooled air conditioners; 
13.  Do not fill swimming or wading pools; and 
14.  Temporarily delay new landscape work until the water shortage has ended. 
b.  If it will not affect public safety or the operation of fixtures, equipment or health devices, water supply line pressure should be reduced where feasible to reduce water consumption. 
c.  Public buildings, institutions, dormitories and similar facilities shall be encouraged to conserve by reducing pressure at plumbing fixtures and by installation of restricting devices. 
d.  Water conservation should be followed during all phases of construction-related activities. Where appropriate, water needed should be obtained from supplemental sources. 
(2)  Stage II water shortage level A warning . In the event the previous voluntary restrictions are not sufficient to eliminate reductions in the water supply reserves and the director of the water treatment plant, using those criteria set forth in section 40-138(a), shall determine that daily water demand is exceeding 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time and that there is not more than 150 days of water supply available to the city's water system, the director of the water treatment plant shall notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification, the city manager shall declare a stage II water shortage level A warning to exist. After complying with the notice provisions contained in section 40-137(a), the following mandatory water restrictions shall be imposed. It shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Use water to water lawns, grass, shrubbery, trees, flowers and vegetable gardens except by hand-held hose, container or drip irrigation system; provided, however, that such plantings may be watered by any customer by manual or automated sprinkling one day per week with each customer being allowed to do such sprinkling on the day of their city garbage pick-up. Customers who do not have garbage service or who have multiple pick-ups during the week shall be permitted to sprinkle on Wednesdays only. Provided, however, that a person regularly engaged in the sale of plants shall be permitted to use water, by any method at any time, for irrigation of their commercial stock in trade. 
b.  Public and private customers owning golf courses and institutional customers owning athletic fields which are separately metered may water courses and fields by any method between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. the following day and shall reduce water usage by 40 percent of their average usage during the corresponding billing period for the most recent 12-month period in which no stage of restrictions was in effect. If no meter readings are recorded or otherwise available for a customer's billing period, an average of similar users shall be established for the customer by the city's utility department. 
1.  It shall be the primary responsibility of each customer to meet its mandated water use restriction by whatever means possible. 
2.  Each customer shall provide access to city personnel for the purposes of meter reading and monitoring compliance with this division. 
3.  If the mandated reduction in water usage cannot be obtained without threatening health or safety, or if there has been a significant change in the customer's circumstances, the customer may apply to the city manager, or his designee, for a variance of the mandate. Any appeal of the administrative decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be to the Superior Court as provided by law. 
Other restrictions in stage I shall remain voluntary. 
(3)  Stage II water shortage level B warning . In the event the previous voluntary and/or mandatory restrictions shall not be sufficient to eliminate reductions in water supply reserves and the director of the water treatment plant, using those criteria set out in section 40-138(a), shall determine that daily water demand is exceeding 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time and that there is no more than 125 days of water supply available to the city's water system, the director of the water treatment plant shall so notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification, the city manager shall declare a stage II water shortage level B warning to exist. After complying with the notice provisions contained in section 40-137, the following mandatory water restrictions shall be imposed. It shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Use water to water or sprinkle any lawn, vegetable garden, grass, shrubbery, trees, or flowers except by a hand-held hose, container, or drip irrigation system; provided, however, that a person regularly engaged in the sale of plants shall be permitted to use water for irrigation of their commercial stock in trade; provided further, however, that public and private customers owning golf courses and institutional customers owning athletic and playing fields which are separately metered may water the courses and fields by any method pursuant to the same terms and conditions set out in section 40-139(2)b. except that the mandatory water use reduction shall be 60 percent. 
b.  Operate water-cooled air conditioners or other equipment that do not recycle cooling water, except when health and safety are adversely affected. 
c.  Use water to wash automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes, or any other type of mobile equipment, except that parts of vehicles may be washed where required by federal, state, or local laws or for safety reasons; provided, however, that any commercial or business operated car wash facility shall be permitted to use water for such purposes. 
d.  Use water to wash down outside areas such as streets, driveways, service station aprons, parking lots, office buildings, exteriors of existing or newly constructed homes or apartments, sidewalks, or patios, or to use water for similar purposes; provided, however, hand washing of exterior surfaces of a building for the purpose of preparing them for painting shall be permitted; provided further, however, licensed commercial pressure washers shall be permitted to operate. 
e.  Operate or introduce water into any ornamental fountain, ornamental pool, or ornamental pond or other structure making similar use of water. 
f.  Serve drinking water in restaurants, cafeterias, or other food establishments, except as requested. 
g.  Use water from any public or private fire hydrant for any purpose other than fire suppression or other public emergency or water resources department need. 
h.  Use water for dust control or compaction. 
i.  Use water for any unnecessary purpose or intentionally waste water. 
The owner or occupant of any land or building who receives water from the city and also uses water from a well or other supply shall post a sign thereon, in a conspicuous place, furnished at no cost by the city water resources department giving notice of the use of well or other source of water supply. 
All industrial, manufacturing, and commercial enterprises and all customers with swimming and wading pools and tennis courts shall reduce consumption to any degree feasible with a goal of a reduction of at least 25 percent of their usual usage. 
(4)  Stage III water shortage danger. In the event the previous (voluntary and mandatory) restrictions are not sufficient to eliminate reductions in water supply reserves and the director of the water treatment plant, using those criteria set out in section 40-138(a), shall determine that daily water demand is exceeding 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time and that there is not more than 100 days of water supply available to the city's water system, the director of the water treatment plant shall so notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification, the city manager shall declare a stage III water shortage danger to exist. After complying with those notice provisions contained in section 40-137, the following mandatory water restrictions, in addition to those imposed in stage II levels A and B, shall be imposed. It shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Use water to water lawns, grass, shrubbery, trees, flowers and vegetable gardens except by container, drip irrigation system or soaker hose; provided, however, that such plantings may be watered by hand-held hose equipped with a shut off nozzle two days per week (on Wednesdays and Saturdays); provided further, however, that water from saturated planting beds shall not run-off onto impervious surfaces such as driveways, sidewalks and streets. Soaker hoses shall not include any device that sprays water into the air. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, a person regularly engaged in the sale of plants shall be permitted to use water for irrigation of their commercial stock in trade. 
b.  Use water to fill or refill any single-family swimming or wading pool or water any tennis court if a residential customer. 
c.  Make any nonessential use of water for commercial or public use. 
d.  Exceed the following water usage mandate: Commercial and multi-family swimming pool customers shall reduce water usage by 25 percent and public and private customers owning golf courses and institutional customers owning athletic and playing fields which are separately metered may water the courses and fields by any method and shall reduce water usage by 80 percent of their average usage during the corresponding billing period for the most recent 12-month period in which no stage of this division was in effect. If no meter readings are recorded or otherwise available for a customer's billing period an average of similar users shall be established for the customer by the city's utility department. Such customers include governmental, commercial, industrial, institutional, public, social, multi-family, and all other such users. 
1.  It shall be the primary responsibility of each non-residential customer to meet its mandated water use reduction in whatever manner possible, including limitation of operating hours, or days, if necessary. 
2.  Each customer shall provide access to city personnel for the purposes of meter reading and monitoring of compliance with this division. 
3.  If the mandated reduction in water usage cannot be obtained without threatening health or safety, or if there has been a significant change in the customer's circumstances, the customer may apply to the city manager, or his designee, for a variance to the mandate. Any appeal of the administrative decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be to the Superior Court as provided by law. 
All industrial, manufacturing, and commercial enterprises shall reduce consumption to any degree feasible with a goal of a reduction of at least 50 percent of their average usage as compared with their usage during the corresponding billing period for the most recent 12-month period in which no stage of this division was in effect; provided, this goal shall not apply to those customers who wash parts of vehicles where such washing is required by federal, state, or local laws, or for health or safety reasons. 
(5)  Stage IV water shortage emergency. In the event previous voluntary and mandatory restrictions are not sufficient to eliminate reductions in water supply reserves and the director of the water treatment plant, using those criteria set out in section 40-138(a), shall determine that daily water demand is exceeding 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time and that there is no more than 75 days of water available to the city's water system, the director of the water treatment plant shall so notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification, the city manager shall declare a stage IV water shortage emergency to exist. Upon such declaration, the city shall be deemed to be in a state of emergency with respect to its water supply and residential customers shall reduce consumption to any degree feasible with a goal of a reduction of at least 25 percent of their average usage. After complying with those notice provisions contained in section 40-137, in addition to the restrictions heretofore imposed in stage II level B and stage III, the following mandatory water restrictions shall be imposed. It shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Use water outside a structure for any use other than emergencies involving fire or as needed by the water resources department to maintain the system, except that flowers, plants, and shrubs may be watered from a watering can or other container not exceeding three gallons in capacity with used wash water from inside a structure. 
b.  Operate an evaporative air conditioning unit which recycles water except during the operating hours of the business. 
c.  Use water to wash any vehicle for any purpose, whether inside or outside a structure, except that commercial and business operated car washes may do so as provided in subsection d. hereof; and provided, further, that parts of vehicles may be washed where required by federal, state, or local laws for health reasons. 
d.  Exceed the following water usage mandate: All non-residential customers shall reduce their water usage by 25 percent except commercial and business operated car washes and non-single family residential customers who operate swimming or wading pools or tennis courts shall reduce such usage by 50 percent of their average usage during the corresponding billing period for the most recent 12-month period in which no stage of this division was in effect. If no meter readings are recorded or otherwise available for a customer's billing period an average of similar users shall be established for the customer by the city's utility department. Non-residential customers include governmental, commercial, industrial, institutional, public, social, and all other such users. 
1.  It shall be the primary responsibility of each non-residential customer to meet its mandated water use reduction in whatever manner possible, including limitation of operating hours, or days, if necessary. 
2.  Each customer shall provide access to city personnel for the purposes of meter reading and monitoring of compliance with this division. 
3.  If the mandated reduction in water usage cannot be obtained without threatening health or safety, or if there has been a significant change in the customer's circumstances, the customer may apply to the city manager, or his designee, for a variance to the mandate. Any appeal of the administrative decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be to the Superior Court as provided by law. 
e.  Make any water service connections except as herein provided. Connections to the city water system shall be allowed, but not required, in the following cases if all other requirements of law pertaining to such connections have been met: 
1.  Lots upon which construction has been authorized pursuant to a valid building permit issued prior to the effective date of the stage IV water shortage emergency; provided, that this exemption shall apply for only so long as such building permit remains in effect. 
2.  Public and other schools satisfying the compulsory education requirements of the laws of the state, public facilities for sheriff, police, fire protection, hospitals, emergency medical services, and facilities of public service companies regulated as public utilities under the laws of the state. 
(6)  Stage V water shortage crisis. In the event previous voluntary and mandatory restrictions are not sufficient to eliminate reductions in water supply reserves and the director of the water treatment plant, using those criteria set out in section 40-138(a), shall determine that daily water demand is exceeding 90 percent of the city's water treatment plant capacity or operational time and that there is no more than 50 days of water supply available to the city's water system, the director of the water treatment plant shall so notify the city manager in writing. Upon such notification the city manager shall declare a stage V water shortage crisis to exist and residential customers shall continue to reduce consumption to any degree feasible with a goal of a reduction of at least 40 percent of their average usage. After complying with the notice provisions contained in section 40-137, in addition to the restrictions heretofore imposed under stage II level B and stages III and IV, the following mandatory water restrictions shall be imposed. It shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Serve food or beverages in restaurants, cafeterias and other commercial food establishments to customers using anything other than disposable plates, saucers, cups, eating utensils, napkins and tablecloths. 
b.  Use water to wash any vehicle for any purpose, whether inside or outside a structure, except those parts of vehicles may be washed where required by federal, state, or local laws, or for health or safety. 
c.  Exceed the following water usage mandate. All non-residential customers shall reduce their water usage by 50 percent of their average usage during the corresponding billing period for the most recent 12-month period in which no stage of this division was in effect; except that water may not be used to fill or top off any swimming or wading pool. If no meter readings are recorded or otherwise available for a customer's billing period an average of similar users shall be established for the customer by the city's utility department. 
1.  It is the primary responsibility of each non-residential customer to meet its mandated water use reduction in whatever manner possible, including limitation of operating hours or days if necessary. 
2.  Each customer shall provide access to city personnel for the purpose of reading and monitoring of compliance with this division. 
3.  If the mandated reduction in water usage cannot be obtained without threatening health or safety, or if there has been a significant change in the customer's circumstances, the customer may apply to the city manager, or his designee, for a variance to the mandate. Any appeal of the administrative decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be to the Superior Court as provided by law. 
d.  Make any new service connections to the city water system except for public and other schools satisfying the compulsory education requirements of the laws of the state, public facilities for sheriff, police, fire protection, hospitals and emergency medical services, and facilities of public service companies regulated as public utilities under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-140. - Compliance. 
    Compliance with the provisions with this division shall be enforced by personnel of the city's utility department, the Laurinburg Police Department and other such personnel as designated by the city manager. Failure to comply with any of the regulations of this division shall be unlawful and a violation of the chapter and all remedies authorized by law for noncompliance with the chapter, including the issuance of a civil penalty citation or action for injunctive relief, may be exercised to enforce its provisions. It shall be unlawful to fail to act in accordance therewith or to use water in any manner or attempt to evade or avoid such water restrictions. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-141. - Enforcement and civil penalties. 
(a)  Residential users. Any residential user who shall violate any provision of this division shall be subject to civil penalties. Civil penalties for a violation of Stage II - Levels A and B and Stage III mandatory restrictions shall be as follows: a warning for the first offense; a civil penalty in the amount of $100.00 for the second offense; and a civil penalty in the amount of $200.00 for the third and successive offenses. In Stages IV or V, there shall be no warnings given for violations by residential users of the mandatory restrictions of these stages, and the penalties shall be $100.00 for the first offense and $200.00 for the second offense and successive offenses. 
(b)  Non-residential users. Any non-residential customer who violates any provision of this division shall be subject to a civil penalty. Civil penalties for a violation of any mandatory restriction of any stage of this division shall be as follows: a civil penalty of $200.00 for the first violation; a civil penalty of $500.00 for the second violation; and a civil penalty of $1,000.00 for the third and successive offenses. 
(c)  Cumulation of violations. Violations shall be accumulated by all customers so long as this division, in any of its stages, is continuously in effect and until no stage of this division has been in effect for a period of one calendar year. Violations of any of the mandatory restrictions of any stage shall accumulate with violations of other stages. Should a customer move, or cease and renew service, during the period described herein, the customer's violations shall continue to accumulate as if such move or cessation had not occurred. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-142. - Criminal fines. 
    Upon a fourth violation of this division a criminal warrant shall be issued to the offending person. Any violations of the provisions of this division shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor punishable upon conviction by a term of imprisonment of up to 20 days and by a fine not exceeding a maximum of $500.00 as provided by G.S. 14-4 and in addition thereto such violation may be enjoined and restrained as provided in G.S. 160A-175. The issuing of a criminal warrant shall not prohibit the imposition of further civil penalties. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-143. - Discontinuation of service. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 160A of the North Carolina General Statutes and the city's water conservation ordinance, service may be temporarily discontinued for willful disregard of this division and a $55.00 reconnection fee may be imposed before restoration of service. In the event of continued non-compliance with this division, the removal of meter shall be deemed proper and service shall be discontinued and all tap fees and deposits forfeited. Reconnection shall only be made upon payment of current due amounts, and new tap fees and deposits shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-144. - Continuing and separate violations. 
    Each day's continuing violation of this division shall be a separate and distinct criminal and civil offense. Each violation of this division shall be a separate offense even if occurring on the same day. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-145. - Severance provision. 
    If any section, subdivision, clause, or provision of this division shall be judged invalid, such adjudication shall apply only to such section, subdivision, clause, or provision so adjudged, and the remainder of this division shall be declared valid and effective. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-146. - Application of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all such persons using public water both in and outside the city, regardless of whether any such person using water shall have a contract for water service with the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-147. - Termination of declared emergency. 
    Termination of any phase of the emergency provisions of this division shall be determined by the city manager, in consult with the director of the water treatment plant, when he finds that the water supply of the city's water system is no longer so low as to constitute a water emergency. 
    Upon termination of any emergency declared under this division, all fines or penalties incurred by any person or customer shall remain in effect until paid. Upon such termination, customers discontinued for violation of this division may have their service restored upon payment of the regular cut-on fees together with all unpaid fines or penalties. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Sec. 40-148. - Repeal of prior ordinances. 
    All ordinances and clauses of ordinances in conflict herewith are stayed while any stage of this division is in effect. Such conflicting ordinances and clauses shall become effective upon termination of such stages. 
(Ord. No. O-2005-05, § 2, 7-19-2005) 
Secs. 40-149-40-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, as amended, PL 92-500, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. (Supp. IV, 1974). 
    Billable excess biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means a user's loading in pounds of BOD, calculated using the billable flow and concentration of BOD in the waste in excess of 400 milligrams per liter (mg/l), as determined by the superintendent. 
    Billable excess total suspended solids (TSS) means a user's loading in pounds of TSS, calculated using the billable flow and concentration of TSS in the waste in excess of 400 milligrams per liter (mg/l), as determined by the superintendent. 
    Billable flow means a user's recorded water usage, as metered by the appropriate water utility, plus metered water from wells and other sources, less any sewer exempt metered data, times the local government approved percentage factor for wastewater entering the sewer system out of the metered water. Residential users on unmetered wells and users with no history of billable flow shall have their billable flow estimated by averaging the billable flow of other residential users of the same class. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l), utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius. 
    Building drain means the part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives sanitary or industrial waste only and is located inside the walls of a building and conveys the waste to the building sewer, which begins five feet outside the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal and conveys only sanitary or industrial waste. Such term is also known as a "house connection." 
    Classes of users means the division of waste treatment customers by waste characteristics and process discharge similarities or function, such as residential, commercial, institutional, industrial or governmental. 
    Collection sewer means a sewer, the primary purpose of which is to collect wastewaters from individual point source discharges. 
    Commercial user means, for the purpose of the user charge system, a user engaged in the purchase or sale of goods or in a transaction or business or who otherwise renders a service. 
    Easement means an acquired legal right, less than fee simple, for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Floatable oil means oil, fat or grease in a physical state so that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in a pretreatment facility approved by the city. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage means the animal or vegetable wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the commercial handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Health officer means any person designated by the city council to be responsible for maintaining sanitary conditions and reporting violations.
