Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; posting signs on trees, parks and utility poles, § 6-222; removal of floral designs, flowers, weeds and trees, § 10-55; environment, ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; shrubbery, hedges and vines, § 32-50; unified land development ordinance, app. A. 
State Law reference- Injury to trees, wood, etc., of another, G.S. 14-128; permit required to plant, trim or remove any tree or shrub on any state road, G.S. 136-93. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Injury to trees, wood of another, G.S. 14-128; permit required to plant, remove, etc., trees or shrubs on any state road, G.S. 136-93. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names and all areas owned by the city. 
    Street trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 26-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-32. - Public care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)  The city may remove, or cause or order to be removed, any tree, or part thereof, which is in an unsafe condition or which, by reason of its nature, is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Code 1987, § 26-2) 
Sec. 42-33. - Street tree species list. 
(a)  The city is responsible for establishing a special list of street tree species. 
(b)  The following is a list of the official street tree species as established by the city: 
(1)  Small trees. Dogwood, Carolina Cherry Laurel, Crepe Myrtle, Redbud, Callery Pear, Kousa Dogwood, Flowering Crabapple and Flowering Peach. 
(2)  Medium trees. Japanese Maple, Holly American and Yaupon. 
(3)  Large trees. Pin Oak, Red Oak, Red Maple, Sugar Maple, River Birch, White Pine, Poplar, Willow Oak and White Oak. 
(c)  Such list may be reviewed periodically to add or delete certain species. 
(Code 1987, § 26-3) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
Sec. 42-34. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 42-33(b), and no trees may be planted closer together than the following, except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect or the city's beautification director: 
(1)  Small trees, 25 feet; 
(2)  Medium trees, 40 feet; and 
(3)  Large trees, 50 feet. 
(Code 1987, § 26-4) 
Sec. 42-35. - Curbs and sidewalks. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs and curblines will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 42-33(b), and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: 
(1)  Small trees, two feet; 
(2)  Medium trees, three feet; and 
(3)  Large trees, four feet. 
(Code 1987, § 26-5) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32. 
Sec. 42-36. - Street corners and fireplugs. 
(a)  No street tree shall be planted closer than 25 feet from any street corner, when measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. 
(b)  No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fireplug. 
(Code 1987, § 26-6) 
Sec. 42-37. - Utilities. 
    No street trees, other than the species listed as small trees in section 42-33(b)(1), may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Code 1987, § 26-7) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 40. 
Sec. 42-38. - Tree topping. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Topping means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter, within the tree's crown, to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. 
(b)  Unlawful practice. It shall be unlawful, as a normal practice, for any person or city department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. 
(c)  Exemptions. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempt from this section, at the determination of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 26-8) 
Sec. 42-39. - Pruning. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches of such tree so that the branches shall not obstruct the light from any streetlamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Such owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when the tree or shrub interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Code 1987, § 26-9) 
Sec. 42-40. - Dead and diseased trees. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased tree on private property within the city when such tree constitutes a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city will notify, in writing, the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by the owners, at their own expense, within 60 days after the date of service of such notice. If the owners fail to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove the trees and charge the cost of removal on the owner's property tax notice. 
(Code 1987, § 26-10) 
State Law reference- Authority to abate public health nuisances, G.S. 160A-193. 
Sec. 42-41. - Stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1987, § 26-11) 
Secs. 42-42-42-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY TREE COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-111 et seq. 

Sec. 42-61. - Created and established; members. 
    When deemed necessary and beneficial, there is hereby created a city tree committee which shall consist of three members who shall be citizens and residents of the city and who shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1987, § 26-31) 
Sec. 42-62. - Term of office; vacancies. 
    The term of the three persons to be appointed as members of the city tree committee by the mayor shall be two years. If a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Code 1987, § 26-32) 
Sec. 42-63. - Compensation of members. 
    Members of the city tree committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1987, § 26-33) 
Sec. 42-64. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the city tree committee to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and, upon its acceptance and approval, shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The city tree committee, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Code 1987, § 26-34) 
Sec. 42-65. - Officers; rules and regulations; journal; quorum. 
    The city tree committee shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1987, § 26-35) 
Sec. 42-66. - Review; appeals. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree committee. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree committee to the city council, which may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Code 1987, § 26-36) 
Sec. 42-67. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree committee or any of its agents while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, park trees or trees on private grounds as authorized in this article. 
(Code 1987, § 26-37) 
Chapter 44 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 32; traffic, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate all vehicles operated for hire in the city, G.S. 160A-304. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 44-1-44-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate, etc., drivers and operators of vehicles for hire in city, G.S. 20-37, 160A-304; authority of city to levy tax on taxicabs, G.S. 20-97; financial responsibility of taxicab operators, G.S. 20-280. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 44-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certificate means a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the city council, as provided in this article, authorizing the operation of one or more vehicles for hire. 
    Cruising means the practice of driving a vehicle over public streets in search of, or soliciting, prospective passengers for hire. 
    Driver means any person driving a vehicle for hire. 
    Memorandum certificate means the card issued by the vehicle for hire inspector to an owner, for display within a vehicle, indicating that such owner has been granted a certificate of public convenience and necessity. 
    Owner means any person or firm to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity for the operation of one or more vehicles for hire has been issued. 
    Vehicle for hire means any self-propelled vehicle, except vehicles over which the state utilities commission has exclusive jurisdiction, which is used for the purpose of transporting passengers for a set charge or fee, including, but not limited to, taxicabs and buses. The term "taxicab" means any self-propelled vehicle carrying nine or fewer passengers and a driver operating upon any street, on call or demand. The term "bus" means any self-propelled vehicle carrying ten or more passengers and a driver, except buses over which the state utilities commission has exclusive jurisdiction, which is driven on regular routes on the streets of the city for the purpose of conveying passengers at a fixed rate. 
(Code 1987, § 24-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 44-32. - Vehicle for hire inspector. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of vehicle for hire inspector (referred to in this article as the "inspector"). The inspector shall be appointed by the city manager and shall enforce the provisions of this article and shall fulfill all duties required under this article, including the inspection of any vehicle for hire and the issuance of all driving permits. 
(b)  The inspector shall advise the city council with regard to matters covered or incidentally involved in the operation or administration of this article. He shall make recommendations with respect to the adequacy of service and whether or not there are too many or too few vehicles to serve the public's convenience or necessity, and he shall make such other reports and furnish such other information to the city council as may be requested from the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 24-2) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
Sec. 44-33. - Compliance with state regulations and requirements required. 
    There are state agencies which also have regulations for certain vehicles for hire, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle for hire pursuant to a certificate under the provisions of this article until such vehicle has complied with all regulations and requirements of any such state agency. 
(Code 1987, § 24-3) 
Sec. 44-34. - Information to be filed by owners. 
    Every owner shall file with the inspector the owner's name, business address, home address, if applicable, business and home telephone numbers and a list showing the serial number and make of all vehicles for hire owned and operated by the owner and names, license numbers and addresses of all drivers working for the owner, and, within three days after any change in connection with such information, the owner shall report such change to the inspector. If the owner is a partnership or a limited liability company, the names, business addresses, home addresses and home telephone numbers shall be given for each of the partners or members thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 24-4) 
Sec. 44-35. - Terminals on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle for hire pursuant to a certificate under the provisions of this article unless a terminal shall be provided on private property approved by the inspector. 
(Code 1987, § 24-5) 
Sec. 44-36. - Liability and property damage insurance. 
    Every owner of a business involving a vehicle for hire shall procure and keep in effect for each vehicle operated a policy of liability and property damage insurance with a company duly authorized to do business in the state, in the sum of not less than $100,000.00 due to bodily injury to, or death of, one person in any one accident, and $300,000.00 due to bodily injury to, or death of, two or more persons in any one accident, and $50,000.00 due to injury to, or destruction of, property of others in any one accident. Such owner shall deposit evidence of his compliance with this section with the inspector before beginning the service involving a vehicle for hire within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 24-6) 
State Law reference- Filing proof of financial responsibility with city council, G.S. 20-280. 
Sec. 44-37. - Employment of driver without permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for the holder of a certificate issued as provided in this article to permit any vehicle for hire operated pursuant to such certificate to be driven by any person who does not have a valid driver's permit issued under this article. 
(Code 1987, § 24-7) 
Sec. 44-38. - Driving without insurance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver to drive a vehicle for hire while knowing, or having reason to believe, that the owner has failed, neglected or refused to comply with the insurance requirements set forth in section 44-36. 
(Code 1987, § 24-8) 
Sec. 44-39. - Rates and maps. 
    Rates and maps are to be carried in vehicles for hire, as follows: 
(1)  Taxicabs. There shall be a map showing the delineation of the city into taxicab service zones established by the city council available in each taxicab for the use of its passengers, and cards showing the current zone rates established by the city council shall be displayed in all taxicabs. 
(2)  Buses. Buses shall display a map within each vehicle, which depicts the route that the bus will follow, a schedule indicating the time each bus will arrive and depart from designated stops and a rate card which is visible to the passengers, which fully lists all fees and charges. 
(Code 1987, § 24-9) 
Sec. 44-40. - Cruising. 
    It shall be unlawful for a driver at any time to cruise in search of passengers. 
(Code 1987, § 24-10) 
Secs. 44-41-44-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATES OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Requirement of certificate of public convenience and necessity, G.S. 20-87; authority to grant taxicab franchises and to limit number of cabs in operation, G.S. 160A-304. 

Sec. 44-61. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating any vehicle for hire in the city without having first obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the city council authorizing such operation. 
(Code 1987, § 24-12) 
Sec. 44-62. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring a certificate of public convenience and necessity for the operation of a vehicle for hire business shall file with the inspector a sworn application in substantially the following form: 
"TO THE HONORABLE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF LAURINBURG: 
"The undersigned hereby makes application for a certificate for the operation of a vehicle for hire business under and in accordance with the provisions of chapter 44 of the Code of the City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, and presents to the Honorable City Council the following information: 
"(a)  That the applicant is familiar with the provisions of the Code of the City of Laurinburg, North Carolina, and other ordinances of the City of Laurinburg relating to liability insurance, driver regulations, regulation of rates and other matters pertaining to the operation of a vehicle for hire. 
"(b)  That the individual, corporate or trade name and business address of the applicant is: 
_____
(Name) _____
(Address)  
"(c)  That the applicant is: 
_____1. An individual and sole owner of the vehicle for hire to be operated under the above name. _____2. A corporation chartered under the laws of North Carolina in the year _____, and officers of the corporation are: (Give names and business addresses). _____3. A partnership (attach hereto a copy of agreement of partnership) and names and business address of the partners are as follows: (List names and business addresses) 
_____ _____4. A limited liability company (attached hereto a copy of the operating agreement) whose managers and their addresses and telephone numbers are: 
_____
_____  
"(d)  That applicant operates in the following cities: 
(List) 
_____
"(e)  That applicant is requesting a certificate to operate _____ vehicle(s) for hire. 
"(f)  That in support of this application, there is attached hereto and made a part hereof the following exhibits: 
Exhibit A. A full statement of facts, not arguments or conclusions, which, if supported by substantial testimony at the hearing, will support a finding of public convenience and necessity for this operation. 
Exhibit B. A complete list of the applicant's motor equipment, showing the year, make, model and carrying capacity of each unit. 
Exhibit C. Financial statement showing assets, liabilities and net worth of the applicant. 
Exhibit D. For taxicabs, a map indicating the place from which the taxicab will be operating and, if such place is on private property, the written authorization to use such property from the private property owner. For buses, a detailed map indicating the proposed routes and schedules for each bus, including the precise location of each proposed stop. Accompanying the route map and schedule shall be an authorization from any private property owner for which a stop is proposed and a verification from the inspector that proposed stops along streets will neither endanger public safety, nor create unnecessary traffic congestion. 
Exhibit E. Statement of proposed fares for transportation of persons and property. 
Exhibit F. Statement of experience of applicant in conducting a business of this type. 
Exhibit G. If applicable, proof that the applicant has complied with the requirements imposed by the North Carolina Utilities Commission and/or North Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles and any other state agency which may regulate vehicles for hire. 
(Signed)  _____
(Name of 
Applicant)  
"Subscribed to and transcribed before me this the _____ day of ________, 20___. Notary Public in and for the County of ___________. 
(Signed)  _____
(Notary Public)  
My Commission Expires: _____ ."  
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the inspector to ensure the application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity is both complete and accurate before submitting it to the city council for further consideration. 
(Code 1987, § 24-13) 
Sec. 44-63. - Additional information. 
    The person filing an application as provided in section 44-62 shall also furnish any additional information that the city council and/or the inspector shall require. 
(Code 1987, § 24-14) 
Sec. 44-64. - Declaration and determination of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  Certificates of public convenience and necessity shall not be granted until the city council shall, after a hearing, declare by resolution that public convenience and necessity require the proposed vehicle for hire service. 
(b)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the operation in relation to which the application for a certificate was made as provided in section 44-62, the city council shall consider the following: 
(1)  Whether the demand of the public requires additional vehicle for hire services; the adequacy of existing mass transportation and similar services; 
(2)  The financial responsibility and experience of the applicant; the ability of the applicant to earn a fair return on the capital invested; 
(3)  The number, kind and type of equipment and the color scheme to be used; 
(4)  The effect which such additional vehicle for hire service may have upon traffic congestion and parking; 
(5)  Whether the additional vehicle for hire service will result in a greater hazard to the public; and 
(6)  Such other relevant facts as the city council may deem advisable or necessary. 
(c)  The burden shall be upon the applicant to convince the city council, by presenting the evidence required in subsection (b) of this section, that public convenience and necessity require the proposed vehicle for hire service. 
(Code 1987, § 24-15) 
Sec. 44-65. - Fees. 
    The owner of each vehicle for hire for which a certificate is granted shall annually pay to the city tax collector the currently required sum for each vehicle so authorized. Such fee shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any license fees and other charges established by proper authority and applicable to vehicles in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 24-16) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to impose $15.00 annual license tax on each taxicab operated in the city, G.S. 20-97. 
Sec. 44-66. - Issuance. 
    Having declared, as provided in section 44-64, that public convenience and necessity require the proposed vehicle for hire service, the city council shall grant certificates to such applicant who, in the opinion of the city council, is best qualified to render the best vehicle for hire service to the public, from among the applicants who have filed application for a certificate for such service, as provided in section 44-62, subject to such conditions as the city council may deem that public convenience and necessity require, provided that the: 
(1)  Owner of the business shall have complied with all of the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Vehicles in relation to which certificates were applied for, as provided in section 44-62, shall have been found to be in strict compliance with this article; 
(3)  Court record of the applicant is not such as would make it against the public interest for the certificate in question to be granted. 
(Code 1987, § 24-17) 
Sec. 44-67. - Memorandum certificates. 
    For each vehicle for which a certificate has been granted, a memorandum certificate shall be issued in such form as the city council may prescribe from time to time. Such memorandum certificate shall be displayed at all times in a conspicuous place in the vehicle for which it was issued. 
(Code 1987, § 24-18) 
Sec. 44-68. - Assignability and transferability. 
    No certificate may be assigned or transferred by the owner of the certificate. Should an ownership certificate be forfeited, cancelled, revoked or abandoned, the city council may, after investigation, determine that there is a need in the public interest for the continued use of the certificate and assign the certificate or issue a new certificate to the person who, in the opinion of the city council, is best qualified to furnish adequate transportation service to the public. 
(Code 1987, § 24-19) 
Sec. 44-69. - Change of ownership or title. 
(a)  Change of ownership of, or title to, any vehicle for hire shall automatically revoke any certificate previously granted for the operation of such service. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a change of ownership is deemed to have taken place, in addition to other methods usually employed, if the owner of any vehicle for hire leases the vehicle to any person under any lease or other arrangement whereby such person shall have the right, upon the payment of an amount of money or other consideration, to acquire title at any future date to such vehicle for hire. 
(Code 1987, § 24-20) 
Sec. 44-70. - Reasons for suspension and revocation. 
    Certificates may be suspended or revoked by the city council at any time for any one or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  The city council finds the owner's past record to be unsatisfactory; 
(2)  The owner fails to operate a business in regard to which the certificate was granted in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(3)  The owner shall cease to operate any transportation service for a period of 30 consecutive days without having obtained permission for cessation of such operation from the city council; 
(4)  The owner allows an unauthorized person to drive his vehicle for hire; 
(5)  Any other reason which the city council may deem to warrant suspension or revocation of a certificate; or 
(6)  Leasing a vehicle in violation of section 44-69. 
(Code 1987, § 24-21) 
Sec. 44-71. - Hearing in case of revocation. 
    No certificate shall be revoked by the city council unless and until 48 hours' notice of the hearing shall have been given to the holder of such certificate and such hearing is duly had thereon. Such hearing shall be held before the city council and the owner shall have the right to be represented by counsel. 
(Code 1987, § 24-22) 
Sec. 44-72. - Surrender of suspended and revoked certificates; cessation of service. 
    Certificates which shall have been suspended or revoked by the city council shall be surrendered to the city council and the operation of any transportation service in relation to which such certificate was granted shall cease. 
(Code 1987, § 24-23) 
Sec. 44-73. - Renewal; expiration; changes. 
    All certificates shall remain valid until such certificates are retired, revoked or suspended, provided that each certificate holder shall file an amended application with the inspector whenever a change from the original application occurs. A significant change in the original application may require that a new certificate be issued by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 24-24) 
Sec. 44-74. - Owners previously operating licensed business. 
    Owners operating licensed vehicle for hire businesses in the city on June 1, 1994, shall be presumed, in the absence of contrary evidence and finding by the city council, to have established prima facie evidence of public convenience and necessity for the licensing of businesses actually in operation on such date; however, owners will be required to comply with all other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 24-25) 
Secs. 44-75-44-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVERS' PERMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city as to permits, G.S. 20-37, 160A-304. 

Sec. 44-101. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle for hire within the city, or within a distance of five miles thereof, without first having obtained a vehicle for hire driver's permit as provided in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 24-40) 
Sec. 44-102. - Application. 
    An application for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as required in section 44-101, shall be made upon blanks furnished by the city for such purpose and shall state, among other things, the name, address, physical condition, physical description, former employers, present or prospective employer, court record and state chauffeur's license number. 
(Code 1987, § 24-41) 
Sec. 44-103. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be eligible to receive a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as provided in this division, nor shall a certificate holder permit any person to drive a vehicle for hire under this division unless such person possesses the following minimum qualifications: 
(1)  Mental and physical condition. 
a.  Drivers shall have no mental, nervous, organic or functional disease likely to interfere with safe driving. 
b.  Drivers shall have no loss or impairment of the use of the foot, leg, fingers, hand or arm, or other structural defect or limitation likely to interfere with safe driving. 
(2)  Eyesight. The eyesight of the drivers shall comply with the following requirements: 
a.  Visual activity shall be at least 20/40 (Snellen) in each eye, with or without glasses or corrective lens; 
b.  Form field of vision in the horizontal meridian shall be at least a total of 140 degrees; and 
c.  The ability to distinguish between the colors red, green and yellow. 
Drivers requiring correction by glasses or corrective lens shall use prescribed eye wear at all times when operating a vehicle for hire. 
(3)  Hearing. Hearing of drivers shall not be less than 10/10 in the better ear, for conversational tones, with or without a hearing aid. Drivers requiring aids shall wear the aids, in proper operating condition, at all times when driving. 
(4)  Liquor, narcotics and drugs. Drivers shall not be addicted to the use of narcotics or habit-forming drugs, or the excessive use of alcoholic beverages or liquors. 
(Code 1987, § 24-42) 
Sec. 44-104. - Proof of meeting physical and mental requirements. 
    Prior to the issuance or renewal of any driver's permit, the inspector may, in his sole discretion, require the applicant to furnish written medical proof that the driver meets the physical and mental requirements of section 44-103. Such written proof shall be transmitted by the doctor to the inspector and kept on file in the inspector's office. 
(Code 1987, § 24-43) 
Sec. 44-105. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The inspector shall investigate the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit in any way he sees fit and in order to confirm the facts stated in the application filed as provided in section 44-62. If the inspector shall find that such applicant is of good moral character, sound physical and mental condition, and without infirmities which might render him unfit for the safe operation of a vehicle, and such applicant is a citizen of the United States and is not a habitual violator of the traffic laws, then, unless such applicant shall be ineligible by reason of the further provisions of this division, the inspector shall issue the driver's permit. 
(Code 1987, § 24-44) 
Sec. 44-106. - Refusal to approve applications. 
(a)  If the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as required by this division, shall have been convicted two times of the crime of manslaughter by a motor vehicle; two times of assault with a motor vehicle; three times of speeding; two times of reckless driving; two times of violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs or three times of aiding and abetting in the violation of any such laws; or two times of violation of any of the provisions of G.S. 14-204 in regard to prostitution and assignation, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application. 
(b)  If such applicant shall have been convicted of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the six-month period immediately preceding the date of his application or shall have been convicted for the second time of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the two-year period immediately preceding the application, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application. 
(c)  If such applicant shall have been convicted of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the six-month period immediately preceding the date of his application or shall have been convicted for the second time of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the two-year period immediately preceding the application, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application. 
(d)  If such applicant shall have been convicted for the third time within the two-year period immediately preceding the date of his application of violation of any traffic laws or regulations other than as specifically named in this section, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application. 
(Code 1987, § 24-45) 
Sec. 44-107. - Fees. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as required by this division, shall pay to the city treasurer the currently required amount for such permit, which sum shall accompany the application. Such permit fee shall be for a permit to drive a vehicle for hire for the remainder of the fiscal year during which the driver's permit was issued. If no permit is issued to the applicant because of a reason as set forth in this division, the permit fee shall be retained by the city to defray the expense of the investigation of the applicant. 
(b)  If a vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division is suspended or revoked for any cause as provided in this division or if the person to whom the vehicle for hire driver's permit is issued voluntarily turns in such permit to the vehicle for hire inspector before the expiration of such permit, there shall be no refund of the fee paid for the driver's permit. 
(c)  If a driver allows his permit to expire by not renewing the permit on an annual basis, and he later applies for another driver's permit, the application shall be treated as a new application and the driver shall pay to the city treasurer the currently required amount as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Upon the annual renewal of a vehicle for hire driver's permit, the payment of the current renewal fee shall be required. 
(Code 1987, § 24-46) 
Sec. 44-108. - Issuance. 
    Upon the inspector's approval of an application for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, filed as provided in this division, the inspector shall issue, pursuant to this division and upon the payment of the required fees, a vehicle for hire driver's permit pursuant to the approved application. 
(Code 1987, § 24-47) 
Sec. 44-109. - Display. 
    At all times while driving or in charge of a vehicle for hire, each driver shall prominently display in such vehicle the vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division to such driver, so as to be easily visible to the passengers in such vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 24-48) 
Sec. 44-110. - Designation of owner for whom permit holder to drive. 
    A vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division shall specify the owner for whom the holder of the permit is to drive. No driver shall drive a vehicle for hire for any owner other than the owner designated in the vehicle for hire driver's permit issued to such driver without procuring a new permit from the inspector designating such new owner. 
(Code 1987, § 24-49) 
_____
Sec. 44-111. - Revocation and suspension. 
(a)  At any time after the issuance of a vehicle for hire driver's permit to any person, the inspector shall revoke or suspend the permit if the permittee shall be convicted of any of the following offenses, and such permit shall be revoked or suspended for the period set forth for each offense in the following table: 
Any Person Convicted For: Licenses Will Be Revoked For a Period Of: (1) Manslaughter by a vehicle First offense, 12 months 
Second offense, permanent (2) Assault with a vehicle First offense, 12 months 
Second offense, permanent (3) Speeding, within a 12-month period First offense, five days 
Second offense, 30 days (4) Reckless driving, within a 12-month period First offense, 30 days; 
Second offense, three months (5) Violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors First offense, 12 months 
Second offense, permanent (6) Aiding and abetting in violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors First offense, five months 
Second offense, 12 months 
Third offense, permanent (7) Operation of vehicle while under influence of an intoxicant or controlled substance First offense, permanent (8) Violation of any of the provisions of G.S. 14-204 in regard to prostitution and assignation First offense, 12 months 
Second offense, permanent (9) Any three convictions of violating any traffic laws or regulations within a 12-month period Twelve months (10) Any two convictions in any subsequent 12-month period Permanent (11) Operating after license suspended or revoked and before reinstatement Additional 12 months (12) Drivers of vehicle for hire who cruise and pick up passengers and charge less than the prescribed fees First offense, 60 days 
Second offense, 12 months (13) Felony Permanent (14) Violation of federal or state statutes relating to the use, possession or sale of intoxicating liquors or narcotic or barbiturate drugs Permanent (15) For making false statements in an application to obtain a driver's permit Permanent (16) For violating the provisions of this division, other than as set out in this section Permanent (17) Habitual use or addiction of intoxicating liquors or narcotic or barbiturate drugs Permanent  
_____
(b)  At any time after the issuance of a vehicle for hire driver's permit to any person under this division, such permit may be revoked by the inspector if the permittee is found to be persistently violating the provisions of this division or for any other causes which may be set out in the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 24-50) 
Sec. 44-112. - Renewal. 
    The holder of a vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division shall renew such permit annually on or before July 1. 
(Code 1987, § 24-51) 
Sec. 44-113. - Responsibility of owner of vehicle for hire. 
    The owner of the vehicle for hire shall be responsible to make sure all drivers working for him shall have valid driver's permits, and it shall be the duty of the owner to report to the inspector any violation of the regulations set forth in this division and, further, to report to the inspector any change in the mental and/or physical condition of any driver. 
(Code 1987, § 24-52) 
Secs. 44-114-44-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RATES OF FARE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city as to rates, G.S. 160A-304. 

Sec. 44-131. - Zone map. 
    The city and its surrounding land is hereby divided into zones for the purpose of establishing rates of fare for taxicab service in the area. The delineation of zones shall be as shown on a map entitled the City of Laurinburg-Taxicab Service Zone Map, which is, and shall remain, on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1987, § 24-64) 
Sec. 44-132. - Schedule of fares for taxicab service. 
    The rates of fare to be charged for taxicab service by any person owning or driving any taxicab within the city shall not be in excess of, or lower than, the current schedule of rates which shall be set from time to time by the city council and which are on file and available in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 24-65) 
Sec. 44-133. - Excessive charges. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of a vehicle for hire to charge rates of fare other than as provided in section 44-132. 
(Code 1987, § 24-66) 
Sec. 44-134. - Payment by passenger. 
    It shall be unlawful for any passenger in a vehicle for hire to pay rates of fare in excess of the rates of fare provided in sections 44-62(a)(f) (Exhibit E) and 44-132, or to fail, neglect or refuse to pay such fares as may be charged in accordance with this division. 
Sec. 44-135. - Display. 
    Every vehicle for hire operated within the city, or within a distance of one mile from the city, shall have prominently displayed at all times, so as to be easily visible to the passengers in such vehicle, the rates of fare charged for the use of such vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 24-68) 
Secs. 44-136-44-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Size, weight, construction and equipment of motor vehicles generally, G.S. 20-115 et seq. 

Sec. 44-161. - Conformity required. 
    No vehicle shall be operated as a vehicle for hire pursuant to the provisions of this article unless it conforms with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1987, § 24-84) 
Sec. 44-162. - Inspection. 
    No owner shall cause or suffer a motor vehicle to be operated as a vehicle for hire unless he shall first submit such vehicle to the inspector for inspection. 
(Code 1987, § 24-85) 
Sec. 44-163. - Repair and maintenance. 
    Every owner shall keep all such vehicles for hire in proper repair and a sanitary condition at all times. Any vehicle for hire found by the owner to be unsafe or unsanitary shall have such repairs and alterations made as may be necessary. An owner shall not operate, or permit to be operated, any vehicle for hire that is unsafe or unsanitary. 
(Code 1987, § 24-86) 
Sec. 44-164. - Right of entry of inspector. 
    The inspector may, at any time, after displaying proper identification, enter into or upon any vehicle operated under this article for the purpose of inspecting or reinspecting such vehicle or ascertaining whether or not any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city is being violated. 
(Code 1987, § 24-87) 
Sec. 44-165. - Vehicles found to be unsafe. 
    Any vehicle for hire operated under this article which, upon inspection by the inspector, is found to be unsafe or in any way unsuitable, or to be operated in violation of any of the provisions of this article, may be immediately ordered out of service by the inspector, and such vehicle shall be reinspected and approved before it may again be placed in service. 
(Code 1987, § 24-88) 
Sec. 44-166. - Marking and identification. 
    All vehicles for hire operated under this article shall be marked and identified as deemed advisable and at the discretion of the inspector. 
(Code 1987, § 24-89) 
Sec. 44-167. - Display of advertising matter. 
    No banners, cards or other advertising matter may be displayed on any vehicles for hire unless the display of such advertising matter meets the approval of the inspector, provided that the total cumulative area of such advertising, except that which advertises the vehicle for hire company operating the vehicles for hire, shall not exceed four square feet for taxicabs, eight square feet for vehicles, excluding taxicabs, up to 24 feet long and 16 square feet for vehicles over 24 feet long. 
(Code 1987, § 24-90)
